RATING: 8
[i]tl;dr: Small World may not offer a deep, agonizingly strategic decision space, but it is loads of fun to clash with your friends on a tiny map. This game has provoked a lot of negotiation, arguments, and enjoyment every time we've played it. I'm a fan.[/i]
[COLOR=#CCCCFF]____________________________[/COLOR]

[b]Read the full review [url=http://getonboard.games/2018/02/07/small-world-brilliant-bland-im-conflicted/]here[/url].[/b]

I like to think of Small World as a great hybrid between Risk and Catan rolled into one game that's really unique on its own. In Smallworld, you control a civilization on a board that's just too small to fit all the players. You must leverage your special ability and your race powers to go into decline at the proper time, unleashing a whole new race on the board. For glory! Each round, you collect victory points for the territories you control. After 9 rounds (in the 4-player), the player with the most victory points wins. 

I love the unpredictability of deciding when to go into decline: it makes for a great mechanic and can really upset the power balance significantly. Players who grab a good race/ability combo can upset the game, and all your decisions are affected by the fact that the board is just too small for everyone, and you will end up clashing with the other civilizations. 

One of the most unique things about this game is that it features four different game boards: a 2-player, 3-player, 4-player, and 5-player configuration. Not only does this mean that the map won't get familiar for a while, but it ensures that players are always bumping elbows, even in 2-player games. Additionally, we have the Realms expansion, which gives us a modular board for any number of players, as well as several scenarios to play through.

I'm looking forward to getting it to the table a lot at our game group, as well as learning all the different races and abilities. I can see this being our standard area-control game.

RATING: 9
Someone once described this to me as "Risk on steroids." Sure. I think that might suffice. You make armies, put them in regions. If you outnumber opponents, you win. There's luck involved with one of the battles, but mostly it's just your planning that counts. However, the armies are not created equal. Every army is unique with abilities and is combined randomly with a different effect. For example, giants get bonuses for attacking from mountains. If they happen to be flying giants, they can fly to all the mountains to mount attacks. Game strategy revolves around both picking armies that fit your style, then knowing when to abandon them to the un-mercies of the enemy and back a new, fresh civilization.

Despite its complexities, with an experienced player, new players can pick up the game in minutes. In about 10 minutes I had two boys about age 10 playing decently with me.

RATING: 8
Area control with a very laid back attitude. Quality components.

Update 5/2010:
This game could be even better, but that would require a couple of races more. You just see the same races too often.

2016-12-15
Small World brings you tough decisions every round packed into a streamlined experience with good looks. Rules are fairly simple but the possible combinations in the game are many keeping things fresh for countless of plays. I also have to admire the looks of the game. Small World features a rich colour palette with a lot of detailed cartoon art. But still the board does not look busy and all information is easily available at one look.

It is obvious that the game has been derived from Vinci, and in principle they play exactly the same. There are a few changes to Small World that, at least in my book, have cut off some of the unnecessary complexity and made the experience more pleasant.

Changes affecting tactics:
1) In Small World you no longer have a need to control regions connected to each other. This is one less restriction to worry about.

2) You may now establish a contact with your active and declined race. Yet another restriction you do not have to worry about any more.

---

Changes affecting amount of information:
3) When you send a race into decline you do not pick your next race on the same round anymore. Thus you are not giving any extra information to the other players so that they could prepare before your next invasion.

4) Small World has hidden scoring which I find great. Of course one could argue that scores could be tracked and thus the game should be played with open scores. However, I do not buy that argument. This memory element is there for a reason and that is to create surprises at the end game when you cannot be certain who is leading. Over the course of the game there are just too many events changing the scores up and down so that it is very difficult to track everything. If someone is capable of tracking the scores, I do not find it unfair. People are different and I see no reason to mitigate the gifts somebody has. 

---

Changes in components and playability:
5) The number of tokens each race receives is now printed directly on the race and ability tiles. You just sum up the two numbers. No need to remember variables that depend on the number of players.

6) All regions have the same base cost for conquering. Moreover, Small World includes tokens for regions that have an extra cost. This is nice, because you just have to sum up the number of cardboard and add it to the base cost. This makes it easier to calculate everything correctly because there are fewer rules to remember. This has a downside, though. More cardboard means a bigger mess.

7) While the aforementioned six changes are positive ones there is one big negative. Instead of utilising two sided discs in player colour to represent the active and declined race tokens on the board, Small World sports unique race tokens for each individual race. Not only makes this harder to follow who owns which region, it makes the setup, and especially the clean up a real pain in the ass. You have myriad of tokens everywhere and keeping everything in order is a chore.

Anyways, Small World is a great game that plays relatively fast and scales up and down well with the the player number. However, I strongly suggest getting at least one or two expansions to keep the things fresh. The downside of this is that you have more cardboard to keep in order. May the gods help you if you happen to accidentally flip the box over and scatter all the tokens across the room.

RATING: 8
I have lost every time I have played this game – and I don't care because playing the different combinations are just so much fun! The variety that can occur is amazing! And it is humbling to see your unstoppable army defeated by a combination you thought was sure to suck because that person just happened to have the right lands for it. Oh, the madcap fun! 

Granted, the reason I always lose is because I don't kill my races off fast enough – I hold on too long (oh my precious races!) and the game is all about knowing when to hold 'em and when to fold 'em when it comes to your races. But despite my character flaw in holding on too long, I still love playing this game.

I did play this game where I killed off my races at a good rate - the only reason I didn't win was because the first player got such an amazing lead on the rest of us that it was impossible to catch up.  But the game was still fun.  And that was the first time I had ever played without the maximum number of people.

RATING: 2
CULL
Very mixed feelings about this one.  The gameplay, the very idea of Small World, just seems wrong and stoopid.  Eventually it dawns on you that the players are like these detached gods who care little for the affairs of the races on the boards except to maximize their production.  That's just plain wrong -- why anyone would develop that concept into a game scares the crap out of me for humanity.  

And yet....the game itself isn't bad.  

So I'm very conflicted on this one.  I think the concept, the mechanics, and even the artwork are all problematic....but the gameplay can still be interesting and even fun.  But I have zero interest in any expansions or re-implementations.

-2 and 3 player games seem to come down to how the races lay, and after a couple plays it's pretty obvious what combos to pick for a 2-3 player game.
-4 and 5 player games tend to get killed with an AP prone person. 
-The sad thing is that even in 4 to 5 player games the most interesting choices are when to go into decline and picking the new races. Where to conquer is usually an easy decision to make. In my opinion if a game is going to be replayable there has to be interesting decisions more often than Small World gives them.

RATING: 6
The changes from Vinci are not entirely successful and some fail, reminding us why they are present in the other game.

The winner is often easily predictable, sometimes halfway through a game.

Ditching the adjacency/cohesion rules of Vinci allows a player to take over the board, and ultimately win.

The die can be too influential.

The range of power of Race-Special Ability combinations, from weak to strong, is too great, and their actual power may vary further depending on a myriad of factors, especially board position at the moment a race enters. Most are strong, at least to some degree, but several are too weak.

Some of the quantities in the game appear to be questionable at best. Merchants with two men, and putting only one money on passed-over combinations, are particular examples.

The Stout Special Power is strongly associated with the eventual winner, very probably because it effectively gives that player an extra turn.

The artwork is not always what it could have been.

It is hard to rate or to recommend this game as it can be good, but it sometimes starts good and ends poorly. It requires a little more work.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Another game that is hit or miss.  Although the vast majority seem to love this game and for good reason.  It's a brilliant introductory territory game.  Wonderful fantasy theme and lots, perhaps too much, eye candy on the board.  It's not as lucky as some think.  There's a LOT of diplomacy in this game.  You won't win a multiplayer games by doing your own thing.  You have to talk to people. Get them to attack other people while making yourself appear to be less of threat.  This is important on the board as well.  Don't pick the highest scoring faction, pick the one which will encourage players to attack others.  This is very true early on, where a high score can establish a player as a leader who then gets attacked throughout the game.  Better to stay in second and score around 10 coins consistently than pull a big round for 14 coins and get ganged up on. 

For those that don't like the fantasy or hidden scoring, I'd highly recommend Vinci with some custom maps.  Or, don't play with hidden scoring.  Makes the game far less random.

RATING: 7

Make sure your group knows all the board game strategies never reflect true-life feelings and that you're MEANT to attack the other players.

RATING: 7
The problem with Small World is that the game isn't actually about what it looks to be about on the surface.  At first glance the focus appears to be what's happening on the board, but the real decisions of the game revolve around choosing your races from those available and choosing when to send them into decline.  When making actual on-board decisions the best option is usually easy to see.  

But while I feel kind of betrayed by Small World, this deceptive nature is also what makes it work.  It's a light war game that can be played by people who don't like war games because in its heart of hearts it isn't one.  Also, the art's great, and just looking at the game laid out in progress on the table is a pleasurable experience.  It's simple enough to be played by non-gamers, but gamers don't seem to turn up their noses at it.  I'll rarely turn down a game if someone wants to play.

RATING: 8
A reworking of [GAMEID=60].  See [URL=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/389221]here[/URL], [URL=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/389096]here[/URL] and [URL=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/398713]here[/URL] for differences between the two and [URL=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/391216]here[/URL] for a FAQ re [GAMEID=40692].

For some reason, I like [GAMEID=40692] a lot more than [GAMEID=60].  Gameplay is much more visual and intuitive.  Stacking cardboard means not having to remember some of the nuances.  The graphics are vastly improved.  The game feels more fun, though a bit less tactical (not too much less, though).  The different maps for the different number of players makes an inordinate amount of sense.  Ditto for the different race tokens.  There's the potential for more and varied combinations of powers and races.  Keeping the score hidden means lead is by perception, making the game much tighter and more fun.

I really like [GAMEID=40692] and I wouldn't be surprised if I end up picking up a copy.  I hope they release expansions with more races and powers.

RATING: 9
FAVOURITE GAME - it is a funny and a very competitive area control game. You will choose a race with a special ability at the start of the game, then you start to occupy the territories of Small World very easily getting into combat with your opponents. What counts is that you have the most provinces at the end of your turn, so you can collect taxes which translates into victory points. At one point in the game you may go into decline and choose another race, so you will be able to get your hands on more units to conquer more territories. It is a turn-based game, usually lasting eight rounds. It is good partygame, thanks to it`s easy rules, fast pace and great deal of interaction between the players.

RATING: 7.8
The world is too small to accomodate all the races that is present in the game.  Players will have to first choose a race to start with and spread their 'civilisation' and conquer more regions even at the expense of killing and conquering fellow races.  In this way, the players will be able to gain victory points after each round.

Players can also put their races into decline which the population of the race starts to diminish.  By leaving footprints of the race in the board, players can gain victory points passively.  The game is played in a certain number of turns in which the game ends after the last round is played.

Good points:
The game is replayable with the randomness of races and powers that can be chosen.  Players will have to strategise and plan what they are going to do in the following turns to max out their victory points.

Bad points:
The game rely too much on the choosing of race and powers.  Once a player chose a correct race with a correct combined power, the battle is almost as good as determined.

RATING: 9
The rules are simple, and the game play is fast and dynamic. There are race and special ability combos that you purchase with victory points - you run these rampant across the map. The moment that you anticipate that your troops will be less useful, you put the civilization in decline and pick up a new race-ability pair. You can only have one race in decline at once, except if you have the OP ability called Spirit that lets you have 2. The production value is high on this Days of Wonder game with icons on race and ability tokens that tell you what they do, an extremely well down player aid, and different maps depending on number of players. Fantastic with 5 players that clocks in around the 1-1.5 hour mark. 

In one of our 5 player games, two people ended up being fairly shut out due to the poor combos that were available to them. In addition, the Cursed ability caused a bottleneck as the top combo after everyone had selected their initial one, so players were very reluctant to go into decline. 

UPDATE: Some of the races and abilities are stronger than others. The Sorcerers and Trolls are strong races. Fortified and Spirit are strong abilities. The expansions add variety and interest. 

Tracked on family list (grooven)!

RATING: 8

You get out of this game what you're willing to put into it.

RATING: 6
Was very disappointed by Small World. I expected to really like the mechanic of matching up racial abilities with special abilities at random in a queue, and I did! Problem is, the *rest* of the game felt fairly hollow to me. It seemed like all the tension and most important decision making went into analyzing the upcoming race choices and whether or not to go into decline (which itself is a rather boring mechanic). Once you pick a race, the choices on the map were unsatisfying to me. All build up and little payoff.

Plus, it took forever. I'm not sure if that's standard, but other Small World players I know have attested to taking a fair amount longer than the box says. Offers some fun in tinkering with a bunch of different race and ability combos, but longer than it's worth and not enough depth on the board to be more than decent for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
2-5(4)

I'm not really a fan of this two-player. There are some balance / first-player issues that get to me, and it's very much zero-sum so that catchup mechanisms don't apply (namely, leader-bashing).

Four-player, though, this is much more playable. There is some diplomacy and negotiation, which can stretch the game out, and perhaps may aggravate some players, but I don't necessarily mind. Imbalanced combos are mitigated, and there is a mechanism to check runaway leaders (even if the dreaded "bash the leader"). Downsides are that there are a lot of things to explain to a new player, reducing its suitability as a gateway game, and that there can be a bit of downtime between turns, especially if you have some AP players who are trying to math out the best ways to deploy. Felt a touch long, but it was a first play for two of us.

Not a favorite, but one that I'd certainly consider multi-player, and enjoyed much more than two-player. As a good conflict-/Risk-style game, this is worth a place in my collection.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Very easy to learn, and a varied and thematic set of races and abilities.  Also provides multiple boards for easy scaling to number of players. 

I'm not sure there's really much here in the way of gameplay, either tactically or strategically: while moving your armies, there seems to be either a blindingly obvious best move, or several identical moves; the only decision you actually make in this game is which opponent to mess with.

This means three things.  First, since there are no real decisions to make, combat is dull.  Second, there is a big gang-up-on-whoever-is-winning factor, since there's no real way to deter attacks against your opponents aside from creating a wall of guys at your frontiers, Risk-style (and, again Risk-style, an opponent can break through and gobble up your delicious unprotected interior).  Third, since there is also a significant difference in the power levels of the various races and race qualities, there's a big luck factor involved, with the player who happens to be ready to decline when Ghouls or Sorcerers are in the mix in much better shape than the guy who is seeing Dwarves and Wizards (who are boring as well as awful!)

I will give this game high marks for style, but style can't completely make up for dull gameplay.

RATING: 9
I really enjoyed my only play of Vinci, and this new version was just as good.

Not only are the core mechanics fun, but they're also fairly unique.  There are two things to like here.  

The first is the nice assortment of races and special abilities and how they randomly combine to create a wide variety of options.  Some are better than others, but the auction system keeps it fair.

The other is the decision of when to put your current civilization in decline and start again with a new one.  Not only is this timing on this a tricky call to make, it has the added bonus of letting to switch over to a completely different civilization and approach the board in an entirely new way.

The rules are also surprisingly simple and it make this game a comparably easy game to learn.

We did make the mistake of playing with 5 players though.  It's still a fun game, but this lead to too much downtime.

RATING: 5

RATING: 8
This is an awesome game. 

There's a strategic component, where you need to think about what races to pick and when to go into decline. This is pretty good and fun, but there are a few flaws. I think that as you learn the game better, you'll have a better idea what race you should pick in every common situation, and the game will become less re-playable as a result. However, there are a lot of good combos and idea to explore here, so I like it. 

Then there is the tactical elements--where to conquer on the board, where to reinforce your troops, how much territory to conquer, which territory to conquer. When you are making your strategic decisions, you must also take into consideration these things. 

The dice rolls for battles are an element of luck. While it is fairly small in this game, I'm not big into rice rolling to decide battles.

hurm.

the gameplay changes between this and Vinci are generally good.

almost every change is towards a cleaner, quicker, smoother game.

then... the graphic design clutters up the board, and the game slows down and becomes -harder- than vinci when you try to track who is who, and what the various races are scoring.

RATING: 8
I really like how this game is evolving upon more play.  Not much is as it seemed with the first couple plays.  Smallworld is turning out to be much more of an abstract wargame than a eurogame, in ways that I happen to like.  There is more of both strategy and tactics than I thought at first, and the 'luck' of the race stack is no worse than 'weather' in a hardcore wargame, and is fact a very good wargaming sort of aspect of the same vein.

Given that, this game apparently has no wargame stigma to the people that typically steer clear of wargames, making the player pool available much broader.

We play with visible points though.  I very much dislike quasi-hidden information.  If you've seen it once (the VPs) you may as well let them stay visible, unless the point of the game is memory, like for example, the game Memory.

I think I also prefer playing to a score rather than a number of turns.  This is because on a hard turn count the last run or two become purely tactical, where as with at least a little turn-end uncertainty and recourse, strategic play penetrates closer to the end.  And either way (to turns or to points) I prefer going longer than the default rules say, by about 50%.

So maybe I'd personally like Vinci even better.  I don't know.  But I have this one, and the players I play with like this one, so this is the one I'll play.

RATING: 7.5
Oleadas de razas estrambóticas invaden con fuerza un territorio muy pequeño, empujándose y luchando unas con otras, hasta perder empuje y desaparecer... Cada jugador toma el poder de dos o tres razas durante la partida y su objetivo es conseguir la mayor cantidad de puntos expandiéndose y cambiando de raza en el momento óptimo que será justo cuando la primera raza pierda fuerza y entre en declive.

Tiene reglas muy sencillas que se explican facilmente y cuenta con unos componentes estupendos, de carton duro, con bonitas ilustraciones. Tiene más ventajas, turnos cortos, que hacen que no exista apenas espera y que se siga la partida con interés ya que los movimientos de los demás interesan y mucho a tu propia estrategia y mucha interacción directa, que crea piques sanos y entendibles. Este es su punto fuerte: al estar todo orientado al buen rollo, al mundo muy pequeño, a las razas curiosas y graciosas, los piques son entendidos como cosas que tienen que pasar.

Por eso Smalworld es un buen juego y además divertido. Para mí recomendable. Mucho.

RATING: 6
I'm not quite sure what Small World is yet, but I think it might be the new Nexus Ops.

What I mean is this:  Whenever I meet someone who wants to try a new game but is mostly familiar with Risk, I tend to recommend Nexus Ops.

Nexus Ops is a fantastic game, but Small World might be able to accomplish the same task in half the time.  It's not as meaty as Nexus Ops but I suppose that's the trade off for the streamlined experience you get.

The great strengths of Small World:  Simplicity (the basic rules and flow of play is laughably easy:  pick up dudes.  put them down on the map.  get points).  Speed (I've played with 4 and 5.  Both games seemed to fly by even with new players).  Variety.  It's great fun to see how the different mixture of races and abilities affect the game board.

Creeping Doubts:  The game feels a bit "static" to me.  I'm not sure why.  It doesn't LOOK static.  Decisions:  I'm not sure that the decision-making is as rich as I'd like it to be.

My first game was fun.  My second game was better.  I sense great potential.


****UPDATE***
I should smack myself for the "the new Nexus Ops" comment.  Small World cant hold a candle to Nexus Ops.  BUT it is a great game for people who are new to the hobby.  I've introduced it to a couple different groups and it's almost always loved.  I keep it in my collection for that reason only.

Its not awful, there's just other games I like better.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Small World is one of my top favorite games of all time. I normally pick up games that have a good amount of variety so it never gets boring or really repetitive. Small World though does something a little different then other games that try to make it randomized in different ways. Throughout the game you will be grabbing fantasy races that have some crazy power to them. The powers are what makes the randomness of the game great. Every time you play you will have different powers attached to some kind of army of creature to push your opponents around. The part that gets me the most is the game is not determined by who killed the most enemies,or who was able to make a large clutter of tokens across the board. The game scores you on how well you used each of your tokens per round. Sometimes keeping to yourself or being peaceful will get you more points then pillaging fish people with orcs. Some people are not big fans of Small World because there are a lot of different things to know. Best advice is to just look at what powers come up and don't worry about the rest. Small world is a fantastic game if you want one with a lot of re-playability.

RATING: 9
[i]Posted: 1/18/10, Rated: 9[/i]

Let's talk about Batmen, shall we?  Or Flying Ratmen, if you prefer.  Somewhere between [url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0096895/]Tim Burton[/url] and [url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0468569/]Christopher Nolan[/url] lies the creatively twisted mind that brought us [i]Small World[/i].  Sure, it reimplements [i][thing=60]Vinci[/thing][/i].  I never played that game, but I seriously doubt that it had anything close to the level of whimsy as [i]Small World[/i].

The game play itself is quite simple: this is an engine management game, masquerading as a war game.  Yes, you have a bunch of cardboard chits.  Yes, you can attack each other with them.  However, the results are usually predictable: the number of chits needed to win a battle is easily determined.  Only the last attack of each player's turn can utilize a custom die to see how many "reinforcements" are available.  This structure rewards solid play, while still allowing for the occasional oddball result.  I really like that mix, as opposed to the alternative of randomly determining the result of every conflict.

The results are predictable unless your race has the "Berserk" attribute, in which case you roll the reinforcements die on every attack.  Here is where the game gets [i]ka-razy.[/i]  There are a plethora of special powers, which augment a race that has its own ability.  The two tiles fit together in a tongue-and-groove fashion to create a "some type of something" relationship.  There are some obvious synergies: Berserk Orcs.  Seafaring Tritons.  Hill Giants.  And then there are the screwball combos like the Diplomatic Ghouls: "Sorry about eating your mum's brains, old chap.  Let's let bygones be bygones, shall we?"  With fourteen races, and twenty special powers, the possibilities are endless.

Well, okay, not endless.  There are 280 of them.  The immense variability and unpredictability make you want to sit down with both stacks of tiles, and explore every combination.  It would take a literal day (24 hours), if you spent five minutes on each combo, and allowed yourself an additional 40 minutes for food and bio breaks.  Theoretically, of course.  No one would really do that.  Ahem.

As if that weren't enough, you'll see 15-20 such combinations during the course of a game, playing 4-5 of them yourself.  The number of different games you could play as a result would be...a lot.  Games with unpredictable swings, wild power couplings, all done with humor and style.  The quality of the artwork, and the selection of powers and races lend a narrative quality to the game.  It's as if there's a story lurking beneath the board, waiting to be told.  I love that feeling of transportation when playing a game, and it's worth a full point upgrade in my rating.

Just watch out for those Flying Ratmen.  Ratmen have no special abilities of their own (eerie, isn't it?  I mean Bruce Wayne isn't a "super" through genetics), but there are a [i]ton[/i] of them.  And when they're Flying, they could show up anywhere.  They're Batmen.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
One of my first 'heavier' games when I started the hobby, heavier in the sense of remembering all the races and their traits and interaction with one another. Otherwise, very easy to learn. Reminded me a lot of Risk (one of my childhood fav games) with much lesser luck and play much quicker. Area control game with high player interaction. There's just something fun about attacking your friends and they still have a chance to fight back by declining and choosing a new race for revenge.

28/8: This game is so highly rated probably due to my sense of nostalgia to it. I dropped the rating from 10 to 9.5 as this game depends a lot on the people you play with enjoying the process as well. Best to play with people that play it like Game of Thrones, negotiating who to attack who and forming 'temporary' alliances. 

18/9: Dropping it further to a 9 cause people you play with strongly influences your rating of a game. Very group-dependent game. However, this game will always have a special place in my heart.

RATING: 8
A light Euro style dudes on a map game from Days of Wonder. Components are stellar as usual with DOW. The rules are fairly easy to learn but give some challenge on how to plan out your strategy. Which race/ability combo to take is it's own little mini-game. When to go into decline and start over is probably the most important decision you will make the whole game. This is solid stuff and I would recommend it to anyone just starting up a collection. For Trade note: I would only trade the complete Small World package, not just the base game and not just loose expansions. If no takers in a few months, I will end up listing the lot on an Auction Geeklist.

RATING: 7
Rated a 7 based on it being a good game with a crapload of downtime.

One solid problem I have with this game is that you know when you're going to decline the next turn.  So you have to sit through x number of people to call out "decline" and do some book-keeping...  Then you can sort of decide on what race you're going to grab next and what you're going to do with them.  So there's these x player minute bursts of not doing anything.  

The downtime while waiting for people to shuffle their fiddly bits, sucks.

...and you decline at least in turn 3, and probably around turn 7-8.

1-6-2014 - ipad musings after a zillion plays

A solid 9 and one of the better games out there.  Absolutely great with the computer handling the boring work and the turns taking no time.

It's interesting to note that there's still some pretty good downtime waiting for the computer players to finish is crazy on the 4-5 player maps, and they're super fast.  Worse, is that it seems like there isn't a lot you can do to really pretend like you know what you're doing against the other players on a 4-5 player board.  2-3 players is really neat.  2 players is a fantastic fruity little chess match, and 3 players also holds many of the same redeeming qualities.  Downtime isn't nearly as bad.

I find myself gravitating towards the same races or qualities, but there's been some humorous combinations I've seen.  Diplomat skeletons, played right, can almost swallow a whole 3 player board and force the opposition to kill eachother.  I still chuckle about it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game really surprised me.  The rules don't make you think it will be very strategically interesting.  However, the mix of special powers and racial abilities really makes for some neat decisions.  Knowing which combos will be the most valuable, and how to best take advantage of those abilities is crucial to succeeding.  I'm also surprised how important it is to know when you should enter decline.

Although I wouldn't necessarily define this as a family game, it is quite simple to understand the basic mechanism of conquering territories.  I also really enjoy the flow of the game.  After that initial decision of what race you want to take, the turns can really fly by.  Also, because you have to go in decline on one turn but don't grab a new race until the next turn, players usually have plenty of time to make up their minds on which race they will take.  This eliminates a massive opportunity for analysis-paralysis, which I greatly appreciate.  I'm not sure if I love this game yet, but I certainly like it and want to play some more.

RATING: 6
I thought this game was great when I first started gaming.  And it is good...depending on where you are in gaming these days.  I now play mostly medium to heavy euros so the simplistic nature of Small World is quaint and largely unengaging.

Pros:
Great attempt at scaling (although the game is still better at higher player counts)
Solid Days of Wonder production
Whimsical, colorful, and humorous
Excellent for families

Cons:
Simplistic design with little depth - mostly a min/max exercise
Few important choices
Lower player counts lack the interaction and invariable negotiation (“No, invade THEM!”) that elevates the experience
Insert is useless if the box is stored on its side

I’m not getting rid of the game but it is mostly for kids and non-gamers now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Smallworld is a great, almost introductory, area control game. Imagine risk, except the battlefield scales well to the number of players and is balanced, the combat isn't random and is dead simple, there's no elimination, you get variable character powers, and you can decide at any point to be new characters. These things, coupled to a somewhat goofy fantasy theme and a playtime of 45-60 minutes, make this an absolute go-to for me.

RATING: 6
This is more of an area control style game than a conflict dudes on a map style game.  The beauty of the design is that you're never out of the game.  If your fantasy race has been pummeled to the verge of extiction, then you can put them into decline.  The following turn you can roar back onto the map with a head full of steam.  Really fantastic game with lots of variety.  Works great with any amount of players.  Get the expansions, they help increase the replay value so you're not seeing the same combos over and over again.

RATING: 7
After one play, I think this one deserves its reputation. It has high production values, plays relatively quickly and scales really well. 

Central mechanic is interesting; you have to run a constant risk/reward analysis of your current active "race" (gamers - can we get over this 19th century idea already? They're clearly species, which is something entirely different and poses its own complexities) to see when it's worth going into decline; hold on too long and you're stuffed, go too quickly and you don't reap the full reward. You also need to keep tabs on what power/race combinations are available, which adds to the assessment.

If this hits the table I'll definitely play, but I can't see myself buying it.

RATING: 7
In concept, Small World is a great game with a lot of variable play. The ever-changing factions, and deciding which ones to buy and when, are the high point of this game. Unfortunately, the gameplay of attacking and taking over territories tends to be a bit boring. This is because both players in a battle don't have to be involved. There is nothing a defending player can do to stop an attack. If the attacker has enough units, they win. The strategy is in setting up your defenses and knowing when to bail and bring in fresh troops. 

The game is fun, with a ton of variety. If the war mechanism was just a bit more interactive, I think I would play this all of the time.

RATING: 6
I admit that I'm in the minority on this one, even in my gaming group. I just don't think the game holds up after a couple of plays. The theme mostly comes from the charming artwork, not from the mechanics of the game. The different races and abilities give you a +1 here or a +1 there on the board. As your turn falls to you, the most interesting choice is what race to pick up, but then your choice of regions to conquer is more or less determined by the layout of the board optimized with your race's bonuses. Your success as the game continues has more to do with how the next player finds his optimal conquest path and so on. The theme slips away to simple arithmetic and reveals very few engaging choices. At the end a tally of gold determines the winner. It just seems to be a pretty shallow experience on all counts.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
First play with three of my sons was a blast!  The four-year old was able to easily keep track of what was going on, and with some guidance make some good moves.  The nine and eight year olds grasped the concept immediately and were right into it from the start.  Great, fun game, lots of strategy, yet so simple to learn.  I strongly recommend this for both family fun and gaming groups!

Simple rules, but this is another game with amazing depth despite the simple rules.  A minute to learn a lifetime to master?  Could be.

After multiple two-player games with an adult opponent, the game retains it's fun factor and strategy levels.  Still loving it!

More plays with adults have been played.  It's still a fun game, but it's beginning to fill the role as a filler game rather than the main event for the evening.  I still rate this game quite highly but since it's missing the epic feel that most of the main event games I play have it's not likely to be played as often as before.

The shine is certainly coming off this game for me.  I still play it with my sons, but it's not something I'll be pulling out to play with my gaming group any time soon.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
10 plays: 

I love playing this game, but it's a bit tough to get other people into it. The fantasy theme turns off some players, and it takes a few plays to feel like everything isn't arbitrary. Also, the endgame is weak because it's so often obvious who has won, and there's little anyone can do about that. But I've mostly played with 2 people. 

Also, the scoring in general make you slow down to count and collect point tokens. It's just clunky. 

That said, I adore the game design from top to bottom, and gameplay is simple and elegant, with plenty of room for strategy but not much analysis paralysis. And it's not at all fiddly, which I care a lot about. 

Seriously, though, the visual design, rules and component quality are a triumph. Just one of the most expertly designed games I've ever seen.

RATING: 8.5
VINCI redux with a lot more personality and with a somewhat simplified system, but new players may find the board quite busy and confusing. Some of the changes are interesting however and the games are shorter owing to the fixed turn track. This also means you will be turning over fewer "civilizations" so your initial choices will count for much more and your spot in the turn order may doom the game for you depending on the random combos that emerge in the early going. I'm enjoying it but, all-in-all, I'm not convinced that it represents a big improvement over VINCI.

Hidden vs open VPs is a "name your poison" thing so your view on this is going to be very subjective. In one (VINCI) you go after the leader you know as opposed to going after the one you think is leading (Small World). Whack the leader vs inadvertent King-making. As I said, name your poison...

Since our group loves this game, and I find myself playing it more often, it is certainly growing on me and I'm enjoying it well enough; but, I still don't understand how this game gets rated so much higher than VINCI which remains the better and more challenging game.

RATING: 5
I like Vinci, so expected to like this. Gameplay changes are generally good (although some like the hidden vps we play as a variant for Vinci already and I'm not a fan of the die roll).

But I don't like it as much ... why?

Firstly theme - I just prefer the ancient civilization setting rather than the generic fantasy setting of Small World. Waves of Barbarians attacking the crumbling empires works, but I find the theme in small world less engaging.

Secondly (and more importantly) I loathe the graphics. Board is cluttered, it is hard to see region types, we had a big discussion at the start of the game on which type certain regions were - not good! And then once you're playing, it gets progressively harder to track who is who and what races are scoring.

Thirdly, stupid counter tray which makes put away a toe-curling nightmare of a chore, just dump the thing and use bags (and as I don't own it chances are when I play it the counter tray will appear at the end and we'll all have 15 minutes of frustration putting the game away).

So overall, I'd much rather play Vinci!

RATING: 8
This is a really enjoyable game.  I own Vinci, and like that game a lot.  I probably prefer the map of Europe, but the created maps in Small World are also probably more balanced.

All in all Small World feels a tighter game, with a real strategic element.  Because the number of turns is defined, players need to have a good idea of when they plan to decline their Race even in the turn in which they choose it.

A tense and interesting game, a lot of elements need to be taken into consideration - terrain, other players race/special powers, the placement of units on the board, the the eventual waneing of your own races power.  Good fun.

RATING: 2
Small World:

1. Pick a character and say how funny the Witch Kobolds or Dog Shamans are. Ha ha!   The Kobolds are witches!  Ha ha!  How clever!  Ha ha!

2. Identify the leader. Prepare yourself for the whine.  Hear it yet?  No?  Here it is... "But I'm not the leeeaadder!!"

3. Put your Skeleton Hobbits or Gandalf War Bugs or Ghoul Basketweavers where the leader is.  Just stomp all over them.

4. Run out of places to move to in about 3 seconds, because the places to go to are as obvious as a FLAMING ARROW in your chest.

5. Miss a turn. How awesome... extra bonus downtime built into the design!  Give me more!

6. Go to 1, until your head melts out of boredom.

Of every game in this site, this game is the one that I differ with the majority the most.  

The whole idea of starting to build something and then giving it up way, way, way before it really goes anywhere just doesn't appeal to me.     It's like playing Agricola and giving up after taking a stack of wood.

After identifying a good character combo, it becomes "move onto board.  determine who you think is winning.  attack them.  spread.".   Then the player to your left executes the algorithm.  Then the other player.  Then you do it again.  Over and over and over again.  It's like watching paint dry.  Outside of role selection, there is no game here.  The entire game becomes people trying to argue that so-and-so is really the leader. 

Also not crazy about the theme.  Would never choose to play this game myself, but tend to be dragged in to play when others want to.  

Of all of the top 200 BGG games I have played (and it's a good number of them), Smallworld is my least favorite.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Love this game.  Fun, fun, fun, easy to learn (for most people), the right length (for most people), not too brain-burny, but still enough of a challenge to keep my interest.  Only played twice so far, one 4p and one 5p, but looking forward to more plays.  The simple mechanics would seem to give it some gateway possibilities, and it's light enough not to scare off people who aren't the least bit inclined to play something that looks like a wargame to them.  (Plus the art is cute, even if the board's a bit muddy.)

Downside: well, I'd heard this game could have problems with AP types, but I didn't believe it.  Now I do.  Played two games back-to-back.  The 4p game (all of us newbies) went very quickly; everyone caught on immediately, and we had great fun (and were quite surprised at the final scores.)  Then we played a second game -- two from the first game, 3 newbies.  Oy!

One of the newbies picked up instantly.  The other two, whom I'll call Slow and Slower, drove us to distraction.  Slow didn't pay much attention during the rules explanation -- he was distracted by the player aid, which has most of the rules on it anyway.  (I can't complain too much.  A rules lawyer by trade, he caught a few mistakes we made during the game.)  Slower couldn't get over the fact that things didn't work the way they SHOULD.  (He tried to push his pieces from region to another to attack, a la Risk, rather than from attacking from his hand -- every turn.  He complained bitterly that Tritons didn't automatically get the Seafaring ability, which they obviously should have.  Etc., etc.)  And while Slow took for-freakin-ever on his turns, he was a speed demon compared to Slower, who didn't see the point of even thinking about his turn until Slow (who was to his right) finished his turn.  (Oddly, this is a guy who's very funny in real life and in RPGs; BGs seem to turn him into the Grinch for some reason.)  S&S were both figuring ways to "fix" the "obvious flaws" in the game.  (I recommended they try Vinci.)

So, yeah, love this, but I'll be damned careful who I play it with in the future, I think.

Update: this gets fairly frequent play now, plus I've taught it to a number of people at conventions, and it still hasn't gotten stale.  Luckily, the players have mostly been fun.  I've even played with Slow again, and not killed him.

RATING: 6
It's an improved Vinci, but it still has the key element of Vinci that I dislike: the person who is picked on the least wins.  This makes the game all about politicking and diplomacy which is just something that I don't enjoy.  To win you have to tread the line of scoring enough points each round to get ahead of your opponents but not so many that you paint a target on your forehead. Some undoubtedly enjoy that kind of game, but not me.

The variable sized boards and fixed number of game turns are huge improvements over Vinci and the special abilities have been balanced a little better but there are still exceptions (Dwarves seem underpowered).  I enjoy the fantasy theme ("Look!  Flying Amazons!").  The hidden VP's are a double-edged sword: they speed the game up by eliminating the constant point min-maxing of Vinci but exacerbate the problem of someone getting clobbered into non-contention simply because one or two players "think" that player is in the lead.  The 80 minute playing time on the box must be for a 2-player game.  With 4 or 5 players expect to spend closer to 2 hours - add an hour if it is the first game for a majority of the players (studying all the special powers takes time).  

Unlike Vinci, I will at least play Small World if someone asks, so that really says something about how much better the redesign is to me.

RATING: 10
I continue to play Small World, and it continues to charm me. I think the things that make it so attractive are the constant generation of novel situations combined with the nicely-done theme and short playing time, especially with 3 or 4 players (I haven't played with 5, and am not especially eager to). I think if it were any longer it would crash. But it's not, and it's enough for each game to be different and for each decision about which race to play to be interesting and for those choices to play out in interesting ways with just enough tactical details. It's not a "serious" game with any seriously challenging elements or with clever theme or mechanics. But it's fun and engaging throughout, and this is something not to be sneezed at.
---
I'm a bit shocked to be rating Small World so highly, given my strong dislike for Vinci, and also given my generally not-great history with Days Of Wonder (I think this is actually the first game from them that has really charmed me). But I like Small World, as long as it doesn't become too much of a whine-fest (I find whining as a tactical play tedious; I don't mind a little bit of cajoling, but it needs to not get out of hand). It's fun, it's fast, there is some cleverness and strategy to picking your races and powers, and the various abilities have been well-chosen to be flavorful, diverse, and generally powerful enough to be interesting but not overdone.

Who knows if it'll hold up to a couple years of play; it seems somewhat doubtful, alas. But for the time being, I'm finding this to be quite good fun.
---
I really hated Vinci, but got a kick out of Small World. Really, the main differences are: it's much shorter; the scores are hidden; and the theme is fun and well-done. Not a huge amount, but it makes a huge difference. Still a light game, but fast-playing, nicely thematic, and fun. I suspect the sweet spot here is 3-4 players, where with 5 the downtime might become problematic. But I've only played with 3.
---
Why such limited use of dice though? It works well as designed, and dice would not be easy to graft on and might add problematic playing time. But still, it would be fun to see a version of this that is basically the same, but uses dice for combat.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Small World has several good improvements over its predecessor Vinci, but also some serious drawbacks. I still prefer Vinci.

Whether one prefers a fantasy theme or an historical theme is unimportant. However, Small World improves by eliminating certain too weak/too powerful skill combos, which may come up in Vinci. Also, the rules are much simpler in Small World than in Vinci.

However, therein also lies the drawback: The races and skills as well as the map are highly symmetric. There is much less competition for specific places, since only one race can make strategic use of mountains, only one race can use mines, etc. There is no concentration anywhere on the map - all feels the same somehow. So decisions like "Do I go for a quiet spot that yields less points or a crowded spot that yields many points, but which I might not hold long?" are entirely eliminated.

A player thus has more options where to go on the map, but they are all equally bland, so you don't need to plan ahead for your next civilization.

Furthermore, the overloaded graphic design makes the board unnecessary hard to read, e.g. one might mistake the sunny and the shaded side of a mountain as different regions, or distinguishing the races by picture from afar, especially the grey declined sides, is pretty difficult. They are all grey!



=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Really enjoy this, and have found that the tweaks to Vinci improved game play. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The best thing about this game is trying to find the interesting combos. I also appreciate how hidden points mitigates the bash the leader dynamic that would normally be found in a game like this.

The key tension points are figuring out how to best leverage the combos in order to maximize points, as well as when to decline (again, to maximize points). So, uh, rules manipulation and timing. Which makes the game sound very mechanical and solitary, which is odd, because you are running around killing each other all game.

The art, both in the portrayal of the Amazons and in the decision to only use males for every race that is dual gendered, is unfortunately sexist and was easily avoidable.

RATING: 6
Based on 1 play with 4 players including the Be Not Afraid, Grand Dames, and Cursed expansions:

By all accounts, this SEEMS to be the kind of game I would like. Short, light area control. It was fun to play and I appreciate the effort to streamline everything, but I feel like in many ways it was smooth and fast at the expense of interesting play. The game feels pretty much void of tense choices. I'm not sure it would stand up to repeated plays.

But first, the good:

There's two cool things at work here. The first is the variability of the races. It's just plain fun to see what comes up next. The way the number of troops you get is based on the mixup of the race/special power works really well. I can't imagine playing just the base game without all the expansions we had is as interesting in this regard, though.

But the main interesting choice you're making is when to decline your race. This is really the crux of the game. But in some ways it's really the only interesting choice you're making. Everything else (which race to choose, where to deploy troops) is sort of straightforward and mathy.

Generally I prefer thinking about short, turn-to-turn tactical choices rather than long term strategy - but this feels TOO short term for even my taste. Apart from deciding when to decline, it's ALL just making the best choice you can for this turn. I don't mind an abstract game but it feels like the game is trying to be themeatic and maybe switching between a bunch of races hurts the theme for me.

Also worth noting: the iconography in this game feels particularly esoteric. MUCH of our first game was spent digging through the rules to find out what certain races/powers did, and the game was only new to two of us.

Update: I keep turning down opportunities to play this. It's just... this game takes something like an hour to play, and there are so very many games that pack way more interesting decisions into that one hour. Hell, I even appreciate ten minute games that offer just one compelling decision to make over and over more than a game like this, where there is maybe one interesting choice to make, but it's not compelling enough to hold up the whole framework around it.

RATING: 5.5
A funny and beautiful game with a lot of player interaction! It's not one of my favorite games, but I don't have anything like it and I do find it pretty good. There are lots of decisions to make (which race to choose, when to decline, where to attack etc) which all help making Small World an engaging game. 

However, the actual gameplay is perhaps a little dry. You basically do the same stuff over and over, so I don't feel there is a sense of progress over the 8-10 rounds. The combat system is very easy to understand, but that's not a plus in my book; I think the system might be a little too boring as you basically just place some cardboard chits in every single conquest. It isn't even like the different factions get some bonus modifications for defending (except for the bivuaks, troll caves, dragon master token etc, but again, that's just basically some cardboard chit).

Small World scales well for 2-5 players due to the 4 different player boards, but whereas 2 is more chess-like, 5 is pure chaos. I think I prefer it with 4 or 5; with 2 or 3 players I would much rather play a different game. All in all a solid game, but it's not one I'm a huge fan of.

RATING: 7
My criterion for rating games


http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/147053/item/2300390#item2300390


1) Sense of wonder: Each game is different as the race/power combos show up differently and make the game feel different. However after a few games it gets to be a bit samey as the difference between the races and powers seems to get smaller.

2) Meaningful/fun decisions. Lots of fun decisions that affect the game as you go along. Should you attack the empty spots to get yourself more points? Or should you take out your opponents? Should you pay more to get that race you want or save your points and take a "lesser" combo? Should you go into decline or go one more turn?

3) Player interaction: A great amount of player interaction as you can really be totally wiped out if a couple of players gang up on you. So negotiation and strategy are vital to keep yourself alive.

4) Components/artwork: Fantastic artwork and components. Nice box insert. Days of wonders is amazing as always.

5) Game length/complexity:   Perfect game length and complexity. Just as you begin checking your watch the game ends.


Bottom Line: This is one of my favorite games and everyone I teach it to likes it. The area majority/combat player interaction coupled with cool races and powers added to awesome artwork, short game time, and middle complexity makes for a fantastic game. The sameyness of the game each time is the only thing that keeps it from being a 10.

RATING: 9

"8" rating after one play, and this could go up. Played as a two player game. What a well-thought-out game! The basic mechanic of grabbing territory is pretty straightforward, but there's all sorts of fun when you start throwing in the race/power combinations. Very enjoyable, and the theme keeps it fun, even though there's a heck of a lot of strategy to this.

Update: now give it a "9". Finally played with more than two people, and I got crushed. But that made we want to play again even more, which I consider a sign of a good game. The race and power combos really make this more of a thinking game than I expected.

Update: played this again after a fairly lengthy layoff, and it's still a 9. I love the crazy combos, especially with expansions included. Fun game with plenty of interesting decisions, and the only thing keeping this from a 10 is the "bash the leader" tendency.

Update: 10 plays now, and this is still a 9. Every time I play this, I enjoy it. And I admire that, with a few relatively inexpensive expansions, you can ramp up or down the complexity based on the players' preference. Couple this game with the "tales and legends" expansion, and every game proves to be unique. This is excellent gaming and highly recommended.

- the box is very badly designed; the coin slots in particular are a joke!
- you're given a blank race banner but no blank race tokens!
- there's not even room in the box for ONE expansion!

Of course, I've made some changes to my copy (the first thing I did was upgrade my Dwarves from 3 to 4!), but you only have to follow my variants if you play with me, so you can borrow my game and use the original rules, however flawed they are ;)

Added some race/badges from expansions (see below), plus:
Coming Soon:
- race: The Mermaids: they can conquer sea/lake regions but get -1 VP for each landlocked territory they occupy. 
- badge: Copycat: allows you to copy any Power from the badges available next to the board. Your active Race benefits from this Power's effect until the beginning of your next turn, or until an opponent chooses the combo with this badge. (When a Power's effect stops, you immediately lose all its Special Power tokens, if any.)

Take most of the good bits of Vinci, but not all of them, and then muddle them together with unforgivable randomness, horrendous distracting art, unnecessary hidden trackable information and a game arc that is now so short that is is overcome by the randomness of the random tile draws, thus reducing the significance and interest of the player's decisions in the game.  Not a good reciple. The results are fairly close to dismal, saved only by the few paltry gleams of quality still emanating from the Vinci skeleton.

The saving grace, such as it is, is that the game is also inoffensive.  There are decisions, even if not very meaningful ones, and the game delivers a consistent rate and character of those decisions within the framework of what pretends to be a respectable game.  The result, like the Emperor's new clothes, is less impressive than it portends, but also less offensive than it could have been.

RATING: 6
The production value is great....but the asthetic choices somehow create work for me in playing the game (in comparison with Vinci).  Its just hard to figure out which player is who on the map, with no identifying player colors. Its a minor issue, but I found it really bugging me.

I liked the original Vinci fine (although I did eventually trade off my copy), but the endgame was a mess...since everyone could see when you got close to that winning threshold. The good engine of the game kind of tended to break down at the endgame. Still fun to play, though.

Small World addresses that issue by using hidden VPs and a fixed number of turns. The VPs are trackable, so some will say they aren't really hidden. The fixed number of turns creates some turn issue balance concerns. But overall I don't think they're nearly as big a deal as the discussion on BGG makes them sound.

The fantasy theme doesn't bother me, but in total....there is something about Small World that I don't care for. I acknowledge that its the better, refined, game design compared with Vinci, but I like it less, somehow.

RATING: 7
I've never played Vinci. I remember seeing it around a bit several years back, but I never ran into anyone who was crazy about it. Combined with the 2 hour playtime, my utter apathy meter was showing 600 megawatts and I just never sat down to play it. I had seen Small World rolling across in the game forums, but I had completely ignored it after I heard the phrase "Vinci variant" attached to it. The Days of Wonder box and fantasy theming didn't make me more enthusiastic when I first saw it. Despite all of this, I eventually sat down to it because trusted gaming friend Josh Miller insisted that it could be worth my while. He was 100% correct.

SW (worst name of the year, easily) is a gamer's light conquest game. It's convoluted enough to drive away the casuals, but light enough to keep from sizzling brain tissue. The basic mechanics of the game are quite simple: you draft armies which are themed to fantasy races, they put cardboard chits on the board. You try to cover territory, and to sometimes kill off other player chits. There is almost no randomness in this, as you simply trade 1-1 chits in most cases when you are occupying a new area. Everything in the base system is simple: start on edges, move to adjacent areas, regather pieces and redeploy them at both the beginning and end of your turn, score a point for each territory, &c. Additionally, you are allowed to "decline" a civilization that has lost too many chits or which seems to have maximized its value. This entails reducing the chit piles down to 1 chit in each area, and flipping them to their grey side. These will sit around collecting VPs as long as they aren't killed off.

The reason why all of the base rules are simple is because of the major hook, the races and powers. The armies you are drafting are two part chits, one part denotes what the race is, the other what their special power will be. The two parts are each represented by separate chits though, so different combinations will happen each game. Sometimes your orks will have flying warthogs to pillage with, at other times they'll simply live in stylish tents during the halcyon Summer days of their youth. In general, the races have thematic special powers that can help them conquer territory or gain more points for holding certain types of terrain while the special powers similarly allow for more efficient attacking, extra points, and so forth.

I'm not generally a big fan of combat-oriented games, but this title hits just about every sweet spot I have in the genre. It has randomness in the race/power draft, but it doesn't seem to overwhelm the decision making and almost purely non-random board play (it's not 100% pure because there is a die roll that players can make to try and take one last territory when they don't have sufficient chits to do so otherwise, it's useful but not a live and die type roll). The race/power chit concept promises to give plenty of different combinations to toy with, and hence, a differently textured game each time. I will grant that certain combinations seem extremely powerful (i.e.: Sorcerers with Merchants in our last 4 player game led to havoc, the controlling player was able to score 18 each round for a few rounds in a game where 12 seems like it would normally be a very solid turn) but if they prove to be issues in the long run it wouldn't be difficult to institute house rules or to just ditch the offenders, as I assume there will be expansion races and powers both fan-made and official in the not too distant future.

In sum, for a game that I had no interest in playing, and was almost dragged to the table for, I ended up impressed. SW is an engaging, relatively short, and flat out fun release. Easily the best game that I've played in the DoW catalogue and there is definite longevity potential. Possibly too limited for regular play in an overall sense, but I'll be playing this quite a bit for the foreseeable future. If the game's overall replay ends up being good this rating will likely go up. Though the special power combinations seem like they will add life, my main concern is that the overall basic nature of the map play will mean that the game would feel very samey with too much play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An interesting beast. It's a psudo-skirmish game with a very light tone to it overall. The idea is players each take control of a random race with a random 'class' of sorts, which allot them a set amount of 'soldiers'. Players then get to place their soldiers around the map, taking over other players territory (Thus causing them to permanently lose soldiers). The more territory you own, the more gold you get (Not too dissimilar to Risk in a way). 

The interesting aspect though is the game isn't designed to allow you to keep the same race/class combo for the entire game. It's quite natural to have your 'civilization' decline and eventually be wiped out, in which case you buy a new one and continue on with the new combo until they too are sent into decline and you must replace them.

It's a very 'combat lite' game, which is nice for new playera and for vets who want an easy play. Rules are pretty simple, and some of the random combinations for Races and Classes can be stupidly good or just average at times. Yet some combos are just hilarious in concept, like Giants who are Sailors, or Hobbit Dragonriders.

Expansions breathe new life into the core game for a cheap price, usually offering 3 or so races AND classes to the game, making repeated plays of the game fresh as it feels you'll be surprised to get the same combo of Race and Class twice (Quite rare). 

Pretty family friendly all said and done, and enjoyable for casual players and seasoned tabletoppers as well.

RATING: 6
Yeah, it's better than Vinci. But I'm not sure that's saying much, since I will never play Vinci again. Actually, that's only partially true. I only vowed never to play again with public points. Or with people who play so slow (or who with photographic memories) who can track the hidden points. I detest the bash the leader, which is universal is the games (of Vinci) I played before switching to hidden points. Small World does this by default. The civs also just seem more fun, and killer (or loser) combos are eliminated by having a civ attribute and a civ modifier attribute (i.e. 1 attribute form each of two pools, rather than twoattributes form one pool). This is goodness. The other goodness is with a few extra bits to mark special abilities on the board, you can pretty much always do your turn without having to worry about anyone else's civ. E.g. things like defense bonuses have cardboard bits to indicate them. Even mountains. So just count the bits and go. At the end of the day it still feels pretty tactical, but it looks nice (ok, yeah, the board is a little garrish, but not like Metropolis bad, and not to the extent that it affects functionality--the pieces in decline also caused me no trouble--I don't understand the complaints) and plays very smoothly. Something which feels like a return to a core strength of a DoW game. And the separate boards for every player number (a la Evo--in fact the board even looks like an Evo board) means it plays pretty much equally all player numbers (modulo a few abilities that work better/worse with more/fewer players).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Neat original euro game concept.  Players pick unique races that are randomly matched with tiles that give various unique abilities.  Players place their race game pieces on the various board spaces each turn and score points for all areas they occupy.  Once a player's race diminishes, the player may opt to put the race into decline and then proceed on a future turn to pick a new race.  The game requires strategy and it is combat oriented as you should attack other players pieces to take their territories.  Dice rolling is used to resolve attacks.  There are several expansions out for Small World.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I enjoy the light level of conflict - not enough to cause bitterness between players.  I've upgraded my rating a little, as I like how much the game changes based on the number of players.  Replayability is strong with this game.

RATING: 7
Components: Great looking board and race/power tiles that do a great job of evoking the theme.  I really appreciate the sealable case for all the tokens.

Experience: It's fun to select a race from those available, and to wield their special powers and try to entrench them on the board, so that they might prosper even during decline.  Lots of tug-of-war going on, and opportunities for strong offensive and defensive play.  Still, for the most part, I expand my race as quickly and as far as I can, then send them into decline. Choosing a race is more interesting than actually employing that race.

Eagerness to Play Again: Soon

Plays: 6

RATING: 10
When you hear the name "Days of Wonder", its a good bet that the game looks great, plays great, and will hit with most gamers and non-gamers alike.  I've not played a DoW game I didn't love.  Small World is no exception.  The core mechanics are a snap to learn, and the handy reference sheets make learning the special powers no problem to pick up as you go.  There is limitless replayability, with the method that special powers are paired with the different races, making each game truly unique.  The comedic fantasy theme works well, and can provide laughs all on its own.  The fact that it comes with 4 unique boards to balance the game for 2-5 players is genius.

RATING: 8.5
I appreciate SW very much, turns flow well, easy rules (except some fiddly combos), tons of replayability, low luck factor, the (sometimes distorted) perception that everybody is in the game until the end. 
Fantasy theme also helps in my group, thou its fundamentally an abstract game.

First few games make it seem a very light strategy game but after that you really start admiring the small subtleties. What combo do I choose and what combo do I leave to the next player? Do I wait another turn for declining and settle for an average score or do I risk choosing a new race for a possibly better one? No simple task.

Also the meta-game has a HUGE importance in my group do to the hidden vp. There's always raging discussions during my games, players pointing out that somebody has gotten the advantage after a good turn and that player denying and debating that from now its only going to get worse etc. 
Typical sentence that comes out after a player has scored 10 vp in the last turn or has just got a combo with amazons is "There's a new enemy in town.." And this brings us to all sorts of different approaches and considerations, for instance, dwarfs - most unpopular of all races - might be chosen just to keep a low profile! 
I enjoy this meta-aspect very much (thou I often lose because of it). 
All in all an excellent game.

RATING: 7
A simplified, prettified version of Vinci.

Choosing race a turn after you decline is a massive improvement - giving folk a turn to make their decision and helping to minimise delays.

Some of the special powers - like the Elves/Skeletons/Trolls - are more exciting.

Mountains are the new forests, old mountains are defunct, cohesion is gone, cardboard exists to make counting easier...

There's still a bit of strategy to be employed here but it feels a lot closer to the light game that Vinci was trying to be.

2010-06-15
Even with the VP sweeteners, some race/power combos are far superior so there is a sizable amount of luck here.

The number of races/powers can slow the game down a bit as you try to evaluate them all.

Other than that, it's a light game that I would probably be up for reasonably regularly. I imagine it being slightly more fun once I've seen all the powers/races at least once.

RATING: 7.7
Perhaps this is the best that you can get, regarding only the area control mechanism.

A lot of things are very well designed in this game:
-The way by which the characteristics of the different species are settled is very ingenious and funny;
- The need to extint one of your two species before starting a 3rd one is nice;
- The ideia that an extint species can still provide income until being totally wiped out is also nice;
- The several specific powers of each race give strategic depth into the game;
- The combats resolve through simple dice throwings but these can be mitigated by the specific characteristics of the grounds and the species involved;
- The game has very easy rules, the characteristics of the species are easily understood by the way of the drawings and the game goes fast and can be over in about an hour.

A game always enjoyable of being played.

RATING: 8.5
There are many reasons I love this game, but one of the biggest reasons it is so good is the multiple boards for different player counts.  It scales perfectly because of that design, which makes it easy to pull out more often.  The fantasy theme, the nice/goofy art, the ability to change races mid-game and seek revenge, and the fact that the game lasts a set number of rounds makes this easy to introduce to new gamers.  The random combinations of races with special powers keeps each game interesting, although I have had the situation come up a few times where an "overpowered" combination comes up and skews the entire game, but that's a rare occurrence. I would highly recommend this game, and enjoy it each time we bring it to the table.
