RATING: 4
Smallworld, aka the last Days of Wonder money sucker "pimp my game".

Smallworld takes a classic german game, Vinci (which I rate 7), and tries hard to fix some of the minor issues of the game.

More specifically, the following "problems" are tackled:
a) bland and uninspiring graphics
b) poor scalability
c) occurrence of populations featuring overpowered combinations of abilities
d) occurrence of some "bash the leader" situations
e) convolution of some rules
f) possibility of "very long" games, not desirable in the new "cult of the short game"

Unluckily, almost all the fixes are not real improvements over the old game. indeed:
a) the map and the tokens now features cartoon style drawings. unfortunately, the races tend to be undistinguishable, especially when the races are declined, since all the drawings are green. This naturally worsen in not optimal (artificial) lighting conditions. (-0.5)
b) The multiple map is a genial solution to the scaling issue, and really solves the problem (+1)
c) the introduction of race+ability allows for more control on wild powers combination, yet greatly reduce the number of possible couples. I know that this will be solved with a plethora of expansions. I strongly dislike it, since reveals once again the greedy DoW policies (-0.5)
d) the "bash the leader" issue has been 'solved' with hidden victory points. This only turns the "bash the leader" to the even worse "bash the supposed leader", which poisons the game with a rather disruptive "Diplomacy" metagame (-1).
e) Rules have been dumbed down, removing the empire coesion and the forbidden active and declined neighboring rules. Several strategical choices are consequently considerably reduced (-1).
f) The problem of "long" games have been solved with a fixed number of turns. Unfortunately, the number is so short that there is not lot of maneuver space about decline choice(-0.5)
Conclusion: please give me back my old Vinci!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Works for everyone. Always fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
- Gameplay and replayability: 4/4. Small World is a thoroughly enjoyable game which plays quickly, without much downtime. The game requires strategy, but without hurting the brain too much. It has lots of interaction, making it a very social game. And last but not least, there is a lot of variety because of the different races. The expansions add even more variation, which only benefits the game.    

- Absence of luck: 4/4. Small World has a luck factor in that the available races are random. However, this is fully mitigated because of three observations. First, the player can choose between 6 random races, so you'd need a lot of bad luck to find absolutely no combination that has some strength. Secondly, it is very unlikely that one player has all the luck in the 3 times a race is to be selected during the game, while the other players have no luck at all. Third and most importantly, in a more-than-2-player game, when other players notice that someone is scoring heavily, they tend to attack this leader, leveling out his advantage. Therefore I dare to say that the luck factor never determines the winner. In a 2 player game, the luck factor is reduced to a minimum because during the first race selection, the chance that 5 out of the 6 available races are bad is almost zero.  

- Duration: 4/4. 45 minutes with 2 players, a bit more than an hour with 3 and 1.5 hour with 4. This means that you don't need to spend a whole afternoon, and it is even possible to play twice on a single evening. 

- Player range: 4/4. Equally fun with 2, 3 or 4 players.

- Theme and looks: 4/4. The fantasy theme is kept light and funny. It surprises me how well the races' special abilities integrate with the theme. Most of them feel natural and plausible, supporting the theme and making them easy to remember. But if there is one thing Small World excels at, it is the artwork. The race graphics are beautiful and the board is absolutely gorgeous. I keep looking for fascinating details I hadn't noticed before. Wow, just wow!   
- Set up/clean up time: 3/4. It takes some 5 minutes to set up and another 5 to clean up.

- Learning curve and documentation: 2/4. The rules can be easily explained, but a newcomer will need some time to understand the abilities of each race. Luckily the races come available one at a time during the game, so they don't have to be studied all at once. However, the problem is the rule book. The basic rules are clear, but the race specific edge cases are often explained too concisely, leaving room for interpretation and discussion. Also, you will often need to read both the explanation in the rule book and the one on the reference sheet, as they both provide only part of the information needed. 

- Durability: 3/4. Good quality components. The (very handy) box for storing the races seems a bit fragile though.

- Portability: 1/4. Not suited for traveling.    

- Like: gorgeous looks, strategic, light and fun to play, short, plays well with any number of players, lots of variation, tiny luck factor, fast setup. Small World has it all!

- Dislike: edge cases are badly documented and hard to remember, but now I'm nitpicking :-)

RATING: 7.5
[2009-10-16 Rating: n.a. -> 7.5]
Note: This is my rating after two games. It is likely to be changed after further plays, as I'm still a little unsure about this game right now.

At it's core, Smallworld is a rather abstract game about conquering and holding regions, as after a turn you are awarded coins (read: points) for each region you hold with one of your races. Be the one with the most coins at the end of the game - triggered after a set number of rounds - and you win. In order to prevent king-making, the coins are kept hidden. All this is spiced up by variable player-powers introduced through random race-power-combinations and your ability to decline a race and choose a new one. While you can't conquer any new regions with a declined race, they do give you points for the regions they are still in. So each turn you are faced with a nice dilemma: Do I put my current race into decline or not? Is there a new race available that will benefit me more in my current situation?

Comments:
---------------
* It's all about maximizing your score. Don't get to attached to your race as there is a real need to decline it in order to maximize your score. Because of this, I had the feeling, that I wasn't really achieving something. A turn was more like a puzzle or a one-shot opportunity: "Okay, given this situation, how can I get the most points". This effect is a little lessened by some of the race-power-combinations as you can divide them into different groups: Some are good to get points quickly, some are better in decline and some have a better staying power while active. So in a way, with the selection of a race-power-combination, you can kind of formulate a strategy. But I don't know, if this enough for me.

* I'm not so sure, if you can really plan ahead during the other players turns. In my only three-player game, the map changed significantly between my turns. All I had to do then, was to look innocent so no one would attack me. It was okay since I was playing with quick gamers. But I can see this become a problem in five player games where some of my opponents take forever for their turns.

* While the map looks beautiful, I would complain that it is sometimes quite hard to figure out what's going on. I read, that this was a bit clearer in Smallworld's 	predecessor Vinci. But maybe this was a design decision, since you can't see who is in the lead so easily.

RATING: 5
Players control races with abilities, and try to earn victory points by conquering areas of a map that is rather ... small!  Essentially a remake of Vinci, an excellent game from several years ago.  The theme has been ported to a fantasy genre, and several rules have been stripped out, the rule of cohesion being the most vital.  We're left with a very colourful game with a good dose of the whimsical (flower smelling elves, drunk dwarves, etc).  They have taken a few house rules we had been using for Vinci and added them here (hidden victory conditions - good!), which improves the game.  The addition of different boards for different numbers of players is also a good thing.  Graphically, it's very colourful and attractive, but terrible to play on - very hard on the eyes - Vinci is much better in that respect.  An excellent game, and great to see it back in print.  However, the presentation from a game play perspective is a step in the wrong direction from the original game.

RATING: 8
Idea:
Pick your race to conquer the world and when their power diminishes switch to another to continue conquering.

Mechanism:
 Each player first choose race. First race is free and next is 1vp token from you to that race. Then conquer regions. Each race is formed of base (troll/goblin/human etc) and ability (fortified/berserk/pillaging). Amount of men you get depends on those two, thus good abilities give less men and poor abiliites give more.
 After race pick you go for map and conquer regions, 2 men more than tokens on there (thus if map has 2 defenders on a mountain [which is token] and fort [token] they have strength of 4 and you need 6 to take over. After take over defender loses 1 and replaces rest.
 When your race diminishes so that you cant take more/enough regions you skip turn to decline that race and pick another. Declined race turns inactive and has only 1 dude/region but still scores for you. (key point here)

to who:
Those who like region control that do not handle (much) randomness (like El Grande). Game has pretty much replayablitity due base/ability combinations even though map is every time same (depends on number of players)

RATING: 8
LATE TO THE PARTY:  Waited years to play this game and not disappointed.  First game ran very long because we were all first-timers, but I'm sure will go faster next time and am anxious to play again even though I was slaughtered.  It's an area control game, but it's not about taking over the world, a la Risk, it's about getting the most points over a given number of turns. Because each player has unique "special abilities" which may include specific scoring bonuses, the winner isn't necessarily, or even likely, to be the one who controls the most area at the end of the game.  Since each player starts with two unique special abilities which are randomly paired each game and can be changed for other random pairs in the course of the game, it's a statistical certainty that no two games will play the same.  I really like that mechanic.

RATING: 9
When I hear people say that they don't like the game usually it comes down to the action on the board. Which is a bit of numbers crunching and really isn't that engaging but it plays well. But to be honest the game on the board is only part of the reason why I come to play Small Word. The other half, which gets looked over all too often, are the race and trait pairings which gives a unique game every time. For me the game is picking races that work together, that synergize. Picking the right race at the right time is what drives the game and largely contributes to success, not the actual play on the board. I come to draft races but stay for the light area control.

RATING: 5.5
This game lasted way too long for what it is, and unfortunately, most of the time was spent consulting the rulebook to figure out the intricacies of the various character races/classes.  Even by the final rounds we were STILL running to that rulebook to figure things out.  And since we only played with a few of the potential class combinations, I’m sure were we to play it again, we would still have the same issue.  The entire game felt like a bunch of players constantly repeating themselves: “What does this mean?...  What does this do?...  Oh, I forgot I could do this, this and this on my turn…”  In most games you learn the rules, and by the second or third round you pretty much have them down and can focus on strategy.  In this game, learning rules IS the game!   

You can’t really plan any long term strategy or even plan in advance of your turn since the board will change by the time your turn comes up.  This just slows the game down more.    

I like games whereby you have a lot of good choices on your turn.  Unfortunately in this game, again and again, players felt they really had very few options on their turn and often only had one.  When it would finally get to the point that there were NO options other than to stay put and just collect money, it was time to put your class into decline and start all over again!  

For some reason this game gets compared to Risk and is often touted as a better version of Risk.  I would play Risk any day over this game.  Risk has streamlined rules that everyone gets by the first turn and can focus on strategy and interact with other players.  Risk is game about diplomacy, Small World seems to be a game about reading rulebooks.

RATING: 9.25
I gotta say I *really* like this game.  The graphics are spectacular, the mechanics simple and the experience light and fun.

My wife gets annoyed that she can't hold on to a territory (a la Risk) or develop her civilization to her satisfaction.  Just when she starts to like them, they're greyed out!  And that's just the point.  Fast furious action that's over with before it starts. heh

It's a great entry level (kindergarten) game into the world of high end battling and a delightful romp.  If you're looking for something involved that you'll sit at for hours on end battling to the bitter end, look elsewhere.  If you're looking for a light experience or just dabbling in the world of war gaming, this is the one for you.  And dang it's fun.  Different every time you play.

Maybe with more maps and a few expansions I'd give this a full 10 stars.  Right now it's probably my #2 game behind Ticket to Ride. (I know, I need to get out more ... but hey, I'm only just starting!) ;oP

Pillaging Wizards ... that's just nonsense! lol ;oD

RATING: 4
Good.  I really like the different race/power combinations, and the balancing mechanic.  That's fun stuff.  And sending races into decline, and the different boards for different numbers of players.  It's a heartbreaker, in a way, because this game is close to being great, but falls short in at least two ways:

The art direction is overly cutesy and trite.  Telling a friend about it, I asked him to guess which two items the dwarf was carrying.  "Battleaxe and a flagon?" was the first thing out of his mouth, and of course he was right.  Gah.  Also, the supersaturated colors, while very pretty in isolation, combine to feel like daggers in the eyes.

The combat system needs to be a little more dynamic, maybe even Risk-esque!  The static element of it is fine, I guess, but feels a little dry for an epic clash of civilizations.  I don't really have a problem with determinism for abstract or economic games, but for games involving war, it really rubs me the wrong way.

Why not?...Probably because it didn't have elves, orcs, and wizards...So sad.

RATING: 8
This is a great light weight war/area-control game.  Players choose from different combinations of races and special powers that are randomly paired giving you mostly different combos every game.  When your chosen race is at the end of its usefulness, put it into decline and renew your conquest the next turn with a new race/special power combo.

Very simple base rules, but the racial and special power combos give it a lot of replayability.  The game has different maps for different numbers of players, and it plays quite differently as a 2 player game.  With more players, table talk and negotiations become crucial.  In my experience, a 5 player game does run a bit longer than I'd like and the down time becomes a little more noticeable.  4 players is definitely the sweet spot, but the game scales well with its different sized maps.

The game is easy to play, easy to teach, and the artwork is beautiful.  If you enjoy the game, I recommend getting the expansions that add more crazy races and powers.

RATING: 6
This is a light combat/direct interaction game to get people used to before ramping them up to something that has more depth.  I also like that it's a combat game where no one is completely 'down and out' due to being able to choose a new combination of race/power to rejoin the fray.  I love that it is mostly diceless and the dice doesn't have a huge impact on the outcome.  There is great variety in the combinations that show up but I do feel like 6 or more races and a few more powers would have been a better number to start with.  There is debate on the balance of turn order, but I use a blind-bidding auction variant for turn order at the beginning of every turn using your own VP.  My friends and I feel this makes the game far more dynamic in terms of strategy.  One of my complaints is that without the visual aid of colored cubes or another identifier, it may be difficult to see who owns what region, possibly causing people to not score a region or two they control.  My other nitpick is that the 'cheat sheet' for the race and powers sometimes only include one part of an ability that has two specific components (ie the Dragon Master power).

RATING: 7
This rating is strictly for 2-player.  I have not (and am not terribly interested in) playing it with more.

It's a good game.  It's light and relaxing, but not too light, with a manageable amount of luck and enough depth of strategy to keep it interesting.  Picking the races is interesting, as is the on-board tactics.  There is a balance between the need to score points and the need to kill the opponent's tokens so as to reduce their scoring potential; this balance is in turn influenced by which races are being played or are in store.  

The (rather generic and somewhat silly) fantasy theme is tolerable, and fits the overall feel of the game, although for me it is much less interesting or immersive than the historical armies of History of the World.  In most other ways, though, this is a superior game (the ratings come out equal only because we have houseruled History of the World extensively; for Smallworld there is no need for such tinkering).        

Update 9/6/2012
This has become one of my 5-year old daughter's favorite games.  She particularly likes to play it with 4 players on 2vs2 teams, a variant that works quite well.

RATING: 5
It's short, it's fast and it's simple. Could've been a good game but major flaws bring this down. 

1) Distribution of races and powers not very balanced and it boils down to timing your pick. 

2) Picking who to attack is completely arbitrary. You can't even pick the leader because you don't know who the leader is.

3) Trolls are potentially problematic, compounded by the short game length. Although players are limited to two races (1 active, 1 declined), there isn't much incentive to cycle through the races as the game is so short. So a Troll player can hold on to them declined and still collect a decent sum for them given that attacking them is a pain.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
In Small World, players vie for conquest and control of a world that is simply too small to accommodate them all.

Designed by Philippe Keyaerts as a fantasy follow-up to his award-winning Vinci, Small World is inhabited by a zany cast of characters such as dwarves, wizards, amazons, giants, orcs, and even humans, who use their troops to occupy territory and conquer adjacent lands in order to push the other races off the face of the earth.

Picking the right combination from the 14 different fantasy races and 20 unique special powers, players rush to expand their empires - often at the expense of weaker neighbors. Yet they must also know when to push their own over-extended civilization into decline and ride a new one to victory!

On each turn, you either use the multiple tiles of your chosen race (type of creatures) to occupy adjacent (normally) territories - possibly defeating weaker enemy races along the way, or you give up on your race letting it go "into decline". A race in decline is designated by flipping the tiles over to their black-and-white side.

At the end of your turn, you score one point (coin) for each territory your races occupy. You may have one active race and one race in decline on the board at the same time. Your occupation total can vary depend on the special abilities of your race and the territories they occupy. After the final round, the player with the most coins wins.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A great game for two people upwards of 5 players.  The most we've played with is 4 and it is a very different game than with 2.  You need to alter your strategy since you are unable to play every other turn.  Going into decline at the right moment is key with any more than two players.  The randomness of races and special powers make it very replayable.  We only have the Grand Dames expansion currently but looking to get the others.  Adding races only makes the game better by giving it more options.


Updated comment two years later:  With two players, the game can quickly reduce to put down squares and take coins.  Sometimes there is no incentive to attack the other player.  With more players, the board becomes fuller and expansion into other races is necessary.  A possible twist could be with the addition of Small World Realms to vary the game board between plays.

RATING: 5
Not bad because the system it builds on is good.  And I like some of the changes.  Even though I'm not a fantasy guy, I was won over by the new setting, which allows a lot more (mostly well-executed, although not entirely - hate the elves) expansion ideas, and this version of Vinci has an improvement or two over the original (I especially like the big clunky race/attribute pieces).

That said, it's a shame that they simplified the game so much.  My experience was very little tension over deciding when to decline and very little established narrative compared to Vinci.  I was prepared to not like the visual design, but I was unprepared for just how bad it is.  The board seemed to be vibrating with so many colors and shapes, and I literally was getting a headache from looking at it.  Vinci's clean design should have been maintained.

RATING: 7
I really like this game, but I don't get it to the table much. This is a gateway game - area control with a lot more direct interaction between players than Carcassonne. The ameritrash component of rolling the reinforcement die adds a greater range of tactical options and a small element of luck. The points difference at the end of the game can be quite small, sometimes making it difficult to work out who is in the lead. The expansions generally look a bit limited, but I've bought a few to increase the variety of races available.

The only detractor is that the board gets a bit busy and it is not so easy to determine which square is which.

RATING: 8
Small World is area control at its most simple and finest.  No time is wasted ramping up; it just gets to the good stuff and stays in high gear till the end.  On top of that you have permutations a plenty (280 potential race/power combos out of the box) and if that wasn't enough, you can get more species, more power and more maps!

If people want to play Risk, get them to play this, it doesn't overstay its welcome and it is not a crap shoot.

I am so glad to not have overlooked this absolute gem.

+ Small World: Grand Dames of Small World

RATING: 8
23/08/2012 - This is quite a fun game. You each pick a humanoid race and try and take over the (small) world by invading different territories. Each territory you occupy at the end of your turn scores you gold which are also the victory points. Each race has unique powers and also has a randomly selected ‘adjective’ to describe them that will that also give them a power. 

Having played the game once, It will hopefully be more straightforward to understand the relative advantages and disadvantages of the humanoids and adjectives.

19/06/2016 - 4 years between plays and I'm upping my rating to 8.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
.
I found this game to be fairly dry and boring. The theme, of a bunch of fantasy races squabbling over an overcrowded world, works well enough for the lightness of the core play. This is a light abstract area control game, make no mistake about that.You're not supposed to get too attached to your various civilizations, as they will ousted by newcomers within a relatively short period of time. This feature, works as much against the game as it does for it. That's the problem really, there nothing in here to really keep you coming back again and again. I suspect that most people will find this to be one of those throw away titles that they play a half dozen times and then relegate. I'll play this one if express a desire, but I'd never recommend it myself. 
.
If you strip the theme away entirely, you're left with a fairly solid abstract area control game. If you come to the game looking for some fantasy fun, then you'll find the fantasy theme to be paper thin. Fantasy fans look elsewhere. Abstract fans - give this one a whirl. Pretend it's not about elves, and dwarves, and the like, and you'll probably like this game a lot.

RATING: 7
Pros
-Nice cartoony artwork, fantasy theme works for me
-Fairly simple rules, moderate/fair game time
-Lots of variety and combinations for races
-Very nice reference sheet
-Different boards for different number of players
-Direct player interaction, allows for skillful plays
-Unique decline mechanic
-Mostly deterministic combat with a hint of luck (optional)
-Hard to tell winner until end in some cases
-Lots of expansions

Cons
-Need to constantly refer to reference sheet
-King making an issue
-Dwarves suck
-Somewhat simplistic
-Fiddly (esp. when changing races), time consuming to organize/put back
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fantastic fun game with a great theme that plays out very nicely.

Duration: Other players can calculate a lot and can make turns take ages, but the game isn't too long, you can play your turn quickly (and hustle the others), and the theme takes the edge off.
Design: This is fantastic, with a great mix of theme and mechanics. I enjoy how races in decline still score points, fill up the map, but can't do anything, and how each side has all sorts of weird powers. The underlying mechanics are very simple and straightforward and lean strongly towards action.
Strategy: Strategy is actually pretty simple, leading to a calculation-fest. Powers and race-selection stir things up a bit, and deciding when to go into decline is a major choice. I ease up and play the theme.
Components: Lots of different colourful bits, races and powers lead you to looking lots of things up. Using cardboard icons for developments and terrain makes combat resolution much quicker to work out.
Theme: Massively fun, integrated well.

Is this a good game for new gamers:Yes

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The first things you'll notice if you've played Vinci before are a) lots of fiddly tokens and b) the board that cannot match the clarity of the Vinci board, especially when players start to put all those fiddly tokens on it.

In play, however, two different points stand out more: The combinations of race abilities seem to be more balanced, even more so by the fact that repeatedly overlooked combinations are made more and more attractive, and the board is much tighter, helped by the fact that you can now let your new races settle right next to or even in your former territories.

I was a bit sceptical due to all the hype when Small World was published but after having played I must admit it really improves the original design.

RATING: 8
So, Small World plays just like Vinci, more or less.  On the off-chance you don't know what Vinci plays like, it's a game of rival civilizations, each with two randomly selected powers, all of whom vie over territory until they've spread out as effectively as they can, at which point each civilization goes into decline and another one starts right back up the next turn.  Small World adds a fantasy theme and a lot of nice graphical style, plus some other tweaks here and there.  I think I prefer Vinci in some ways - I like the simpler design style and there are less fiddly bits to deal with - but those are minor quibbles.  Also, Small World has expansions coming out soon, and if there's anything a board game fan likes, it's expansions.

RATING: 8
Small World is definitely a fun game.  I love the quirky Races that are created and the relative ease of play. There is some continued look-up stuff happening with all the special powers that are involved, but it is usually easy to follow and understand.  Enough luck comes out from the Races that appear and how that reinforcement die rolls, but overall the rest is under the player's control. Sometimes the decisions that need to be made are fairly obvious, but that doesn't necessarily take away from one's enjoyment of the game. It's quite a likeable, tactical, back-and-forth sort of game that seems fairly well balanced.

RATING: 6
After one play I'd call Small World a good game that I wouldn't mind playing again - maybe one or two more times.

Surprisingly however, I anticipate that it would start to feel repetative rather quickly.  

Yes, there are a score or more races and special abilities that can all be differently paired to make a very large number of different possible combinations of pieces to play.  However, the vairability just isn't enough for my tastes, In actual play they each still feels very much the same.  In my one play (with 3 players) each of us played 3 race/special abililty combinations.

For lovers of Vinci (the game for which this is a remake) I suspect that this will be an improvement - more races, better components and different maps for smaller and larger numbers of players.

RATING: 1
The artwork is great, and the race combinations mechanic is a neat idea; however, this game suffers from two big problems:

1) Too many little pieces! I hate games like this which take forever to setup and put away, and the board can be a visual mess when it has pieces on it. It's cluttered and gross.

It's nothing against Days of Wonder - I enjoy the Ticket to Ride games. Just not not this one.

RATING: 7
I guess this is Days of Wonder's take on wargaming.  This is a fairly lightweight combat-centric game in which points are awarded for the number of regions a player controls at the end of his turn.  Each player controls one race at a time, but can choose to allow a race to "go into decline" (hold territory, but not attack) while launching an offensive with a new race.  So the player has to make some interesting decisions about which races to choose and when to send them into decline.

Not really my thing, but I could be convinced to play this from time to time.

RATING: 9.5
Art & Production - :star::star::star::star::halfstar:
Theme & Narrative - :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar:
Mechanic Elegance - :star::star::star::star::star:
Replayability & Fun - :star::star::star::star::star:
X-Factor/Originality - :star::star::star::star::halfstar:

Grand Total - 22.5/25

A whimsical yet substantial area control game with diceless combat and cutesy graphics that potentially detract from its elegant, well designed heart. A game in which due to surpreme variability of Races and Powers consistently asks player to develop strategies on the fly and around the gaming table as opposed to turning up with a shrewd, pre-baked plan in mind. Those pre-baked strategies can still work but only if you succeed to adapt it to the ever changing, vibrant game state. For myself Small World represents the accessibility to depth golden ratio of board game design.

RATING: 9
Almost the whole game screams FUN.
Artwork of the box - FUN, race artwork and names - FUN, combination of races and properties - FUN.

You will be forced to interact with the other(s) during the game because the world is small and everyone wants the biggest chunk out of it.

One of the best things about this game is optimization. You have 2 double side maps. One for 2/3 players one for 4/5 players. The race tokens have their special place inside, each race with its own place. Every other token has its own place, so when you want to put the game back in the box it's easy and fast and you won't spend a lot of time sorting token when you want to play next.

I have already played it a couple of times and will do it more, even if just for the laughs if not for winning as well.

Also I'm eager to play with the expansions.

RATING: 8
It was Days of Wonder's new shiny.
I couldn't resist.

After playing this one, it fell rather flat for us.

The theme could have been anything, and felt kind of tacked on, as the fantasy flavour for this particular game just didn't do it for me. The light-hearted fantasy seemed to light for me, but just about any theme could have been stuck on this thing. The fantasy theme was a marketing gimmick, and I'm sure the non-themed Vinci worked just as good, probably better.

Don't even get me started on the army token container when those suckers fall over. What a pain, but I'm sure it's been elaborated on enough.

Maybe I expected more? But it almost seemed overly simple, and the fact that you never stuck with anything for any length of time really felt like an ADD gamers dream. I felt like I could never stick with my civilization long enough before I had to shift gears, put it in decline, and start another. I'm not sure why, but this just didn't sit well with me.

Likely non-gamers will like this one due to the simplicity of the rules, and funny art.

I grabbed the iOS version and have been playing it quite frequently. It seems I enjoyed this more than I first thought.
My initial impressions also seem to be founded on the fact that I totally suck at this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In Small World you’ll fight for control of a fantasy island that is just too small for everyone, but contrary to most civilization type games, you won’t lead your race to victory, various races will lead you to it.

Games usually last between 45 to 90 minutes and in that time players will cycle through 2 or 3 races.

You start with a race that has a special power attached to it (more on that later), enter the map through one of the border regions of the board, conquer some territories and at the end of the turn score 1 point for each territory. Eventually you’ll stretch out your race so much that you’ll have to put it into decline, you will still get points from the territories that race occupies but will have a chance to enter the board with a new race.

This ends up being one of the most important decisions in the game, knowing when to quit.


From 2 to 5 players.
Ages 10 and up.
Playing time: 45 to 90 minutes

RATING: 9
Small World is an extremely [i]fun[/i] game to play, whereas its predecessor Vinci felt kind of bland and generic and clinical.  Vinci was a marginal game in my collection - one that I owned, then traded away, then traded for another copy, then traded away again.  Small World is a core game in my collection, and won't suffer the same fate.  Although I will say that the repeated rise and fall of Vinci is much more thematic than the permanent place Small World has claimed!

There are a host of refinements and good design decisions that elevate Small World far above its predecessor. More evocative artwork and game materials.  More interesting and more varied traits for the empires.  Separation of the traits into races and special abilities.  A defined number of game turns.  Hidden victory points.  Different game boards for each number of players.  Less stereotyped board positions due to elimination of attack-from-mountain bonus.  Addition of reinforcement die for more drama.  Elimination of empire cohesion and declining empire adjacency rules.

In terms of rules, Small World is more streamlined than Vinci.  But the gameplay is not "dumbed down" at all.  I'd argue the opposite - that the Small World gameplay is amplified over Vinci.  I find the newer game to be more interesting, more variable, and more tightly focused around the strengths of the system: choosing your empire, sprawling across the board as quickly as possible, smashing the other empires, and timing when to send your empire into decline and start the cycle again.

RATING: 8
This is a great game to play with my wife on iPad. We were playing a lot of Ticket to Ride, but really enjoy the additional strategy that the game gives. I do wish the game was a little easier to grok when you first start playing. The biggest trick to learning it is knowing how to count troops needed to take over. A friend best described it as "count the pieces of cardboard" Meaning you count the number of layers of cardboard above the table: The board +1, the opponents stack of 2 guys +2, the mountain they are on +1, the bivovak protecting them +1 = 5, so I need 6 to take it over.   Once you get that down the game flow really kicks into high gear.

RATING: 7
I can't help but criticize this game from a competitor's standpoint. Winning Small World has so much to do with what the other players choose to do (or not do) that it often feels out of your hands. Some people love the game for this reason. I tolerate this aspect of Small World. I have to say that this is definitely emphasized if playing with inexperienced players. With experienced SW players, not as big a problem.

What I definitely enjoy is the number of options you have on your turn. You are in total control of how productive your turn is given your current position on the board. And, most importantly, for the time being, I find the game extremely fun.

7-24-2011:
Coming to the conclusion that I like this game best with 2-3 people. 2 is the best way to guarantee that the game is about strategy/tactics. The increased interaction in a 3 player game still makes it slightly better. But one player can still easily ruin the experience by creating a runaway winner. I've finally decided that in a 4/5 player game I spend half my time annoyed by the decisions others are making - attacking a weaker player and letting the leader run rampant. People just don't seem to get that you MUST attack people in the lead in order to compete in this game, even if it means scoring fewer points yourself. In a 4/5 player game, no one wants to be that person who has to attack a well fortified race. Things might change with 4-5 experienced gamers, but when do I ever play a light game like SW with 4-5 experienced gamers?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
My favourite area control game. It's medium weight and has a fun, cartoonish fantasy theme to it. What I love most about Small World is the ability to decline and pick an entire new race + power. This mechanic means you are never out of the game, you can always keep playing unlike some other area control games. 

Other great things about this game are the different maps that scale according to the number of players. And also the insert, which works really well, especially the token holder.

The one downside for me is that it doesn't really work all that well as a 2 player game. But overall I'm really happy with this game. One of the first games that I've purchased and still one of my favourites.

RATING: 9
Annak ellenére, hogy még mindig nem vagyok benne épp eredményes játékos, az egyik nagy kedvenc. A vizuális köret tetszetős, de a játékmenet fogott meg igazán. Az, hogy nincs minden játszmára alkalmazható konkrét stratégia. Elképzeléseink egyik pillanatról a másikra dőlhetnek meg, így mindig egy adott helyzetre próbálunk helyesen reagálni. Ez köszönhető egyrészt a kombinálható fajoknak és képességeknek, amik hol erős, hol kevésbé kiemelkedő kombinációkat adhatnak. De mit sem érnek irányításunk alatt a jobb kombinációk, ha azt nem a körülményekhez mérten használjuk ki. Így az is előfordulhat, hogy egy más esetben erős népséget egy kör alatt eltékozlunk és különlegességeit nem tudjuk kamatoztatni. Ezek mellett, mint területfoglaló játék az tetszik a Small world-ben, hogy valójában győzelmi pontokért megy a küzdelem. Ezért nem minden esetben vagyunk rákényszerülve, hogy tartsuk a térkép egy részét, ha a fajunk erre nincs rákényszerülve (pl. plusz pontot kap bizonyos terület típus birtoklásáért). Egy apró dolog viszont zavar benne: az eredményes játék nem feltétlenül a tapasztalaton múlik, vagy, hogy mennyire gondoljuk át mit csinálunk. Passzív játékkal is messzire lehet jutni. Volt hogy egy figyelmetlen játékos döntése nem magára vagy épp az első helyre esélyes játékosra volt kellemetlen hatással, hanem pont arra aki vissza tudta volna fogni az utóbbit.

Still fast, fun, and furious with the right group though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Nearly a decade ago, defunct publisher Euro Games released Vinci, a fabulous game of conquest and the rise and fall of civilizations.  Designed by Frenchman Philippe Keyaerts, the game included several clever innovations, and proved quite popular in gaming circles.  While there were complaints of ambiguous rules, public victory points, and its duration, it was -- and still is -- considered by many to be a wonderful example of a "Civilization-light" design.

Keyaerts' creation was so original and memorable, that it just couldn't be left alone.  Days of Wonder has released Small World, a revised and re-themed version of the game which has satisfied much of the critics' complaints, including significantly reducing the time required to play.  The new version is now set in a fantasy world literally overflowing with a wide variety of different races, including dwarves, elves, trolls, giants, sorcerers, tritons and more.  The small world in which they live and seek to expand is simply too small to allow all of them to survive and live comfortably, so the only result is conflict in a Darwinian "survival of the fittest" mode.

Small World maintains nearly all the flavor and features of the original, and is easier to teach and understand, and plays faster.  I do prefer the realistic feel of the original as opposed to the fantasy setting of Small World, but overall, I must admit that I now prefer the new version.

RATING: 8
Very simple conquest game that comes down mainly to picking up the best combinations of race and special powers, for the right cost and at the right time. Some tactical positioning and choosing who to attack, but there isn't really much more to it, not to mention a big potential for kingmaking. I'm not fond of the artwork and would have preferred a more serious approach of the Fantasy theme. I miss plastic miniatures, which are present in most big-box games of the same publisher and would have been really great here. I even think they did a lazy job in choosing the races (wizards and sorcerers?!). Nonetheless, there is something addictive to the game, and although I don't know if that will last much longer, I have enjoyed it much more than I thought I would.

RATING: 3
Wow, that got old *fast*.

For a game with a thousand tiny pieces I would expect some goddamn depth, but no. Small world has the simplicity (and tedium) of checkers with the fiddliness of... I don't know something more fiddly than any other game I fucking own. Want leaderbashing and kingmaking in a game? Small World has you covered, since bashing the leader is basically all you do. Want downtime? I mean [i]lots[/i] of downtime? Small World is your game! Not only do you have fuck-all to do during other people's turns, but every third turn or so, you'll go into decline and your turn will end immediately!

The whole decline mechanic is lame in my mind; your civilization isn't going to stick around anyway, so it's really hard to care about building your civilization. And thematically what the fuck is going on here? Are you the king of a tribe? Then why does your reign span multiple civilizations? Are you some kind of god that's creating these civilizations or something? Then why do you care about money? It's just confusing. I have never experienced a game wear out its welcome as fast as Small World did.

RATING: 8
The random joining of the powers and races makes replay completely varied.  In fact, I didn't really need the expansions, but I bought them out of love and loyalty and they are pretty fun, too.  Plus, this is yet another game where you can think for literally half the game that you have no chance to win, and then you make a few decisions (go into decline, pay to get this certain race/power combo) and at the end when you count your coins -- SURPRISE, you kicked butt.

It is basically a Euro masquerading as a light wargame. There is no dice rolling, there are no chokepoints, front lines hardly matter. And yet the designers managed to make special powers be extremely significant, and the game to feel like a wargame in the sense that you are taking territory away from your opponents and foiling their schemes. Once you get a resource (a coin), it is yours to keep. That means that you can go tactical sometimes and beat people who are being strategic; i.e., you can make some very large but very temporary gains, reap those coins, and then lose the territories back in the next few turns, but you remain competitive because you banked so much on your big push. That dynamic allows the designer (and the gaming community, which contributes the ideas for the expansions) to come up with some powers that are short-term and some powers that are long-term, which again leads to an extremely varied game.

And the game is quick to play!

The only negative: the stupid token tray with square sides, that invariably drive you crazy trying to get the tokens out.  They changed the tray in an expansion, but you have to deal with the original one regardless.

I'm really digging this one. I love the different combinations of powers and how much they change each game. It's a conflict game without feelings of betrayal and ganging up. It has a great mechanical structure to it. I think some people don't like it because they feel there aren't a ton of choices to make when it comes to actually moving your dudes around the map (and that's at least partially true), but the real game is about deciding WHOM to attack, when to take your civilization into decline (you get a turn of very few points, but you get a new strong civilization next turn), and most importantly, which civilization you want to use. You have 5 choices of race/power combinations but they each cost different amounts of gold. Having the most gold is how you win the game, so taking anything except the first civilization in the queue is going to mean sacrificing points now with the hope of getting more points later. There are tons of great decisions packed into a short playing time, and the cartoony theme really makes this fun for gamers and non-gamers alike.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fun but lots of pieces. Set up can be a detouring factor but
clean up is a breeze. It's one of those that cleans itself as you play. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Normally, I don't like "rash" games with pretty colors, however, since the theme and because of the combination of power provide a lot of interesting decisions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Very similar, but much much better than Vinci.  Improvements include:
- fixed number of turns (8-10, depending on number of players), not a fixed score to reach
- attack costs are easier to calculate (because of no bonuses for attacking from mountains, etc.
- no requirement for empires to be contiguous at end of turn
- only certain combinations of abilities are allowed, because race and special ability tiles are in separate draw piles
- different maps for different numbers of players
- hidden points -- well, debatable whether this is a good thing, but it does reduce the "hammer the leader on the last turn" problem of Vinci

There are still some difficult decisions in this game, and sometimes you're stuck in a difficult place with no way to win, which isn't fun.  But at least the game is over mercifully quick (under an hour?), and you can move onto another game!

Difficult decisions:
- Who should I attack this turn?
- Should I spread my attacks around evenly, or try to crush one opponent's old empire to force them to go into decline?
- How can I make it attractive for an opponent to go into decline?
- Is it worth it for me to go into decline, given that my current empire has so few tokens on the board that I'll get only 3-4 points when other players are getting 10-15 points?
- Should I go into decline now when another player is just about going into decline *after* me?  Going into decline first gives me first pick of new race, but going into decline second allows me to attack with a pile of new tokens and stay away from the new empire.
- Is it worth it for me to go into decline with only 2-3 turns left?  (Obviously pointless if this is the last turn.)
- Which empire should I choose, given what empires are on the board already, and what new empires other players are likely to choose next?

Other notes:
- beware the Flying Sorcerers!  They can pop up anywhere on the board.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
What happens when you combine the simplicity of Othello, and subtlety of the computer game 'Life', and a fantasy setting? You get Small World. It's an area control game, where you have a finite number of units to conquer and spread out as much as you can to get VPs. The number of units and their unique capabilities is dictated by the race cards coupled with a variety of special powers.  Races and powers can be coupled differently from game to game, making each combination unique and highly sought after. Some can be game-breakers. The play is fast, with a very simple decision tree: 1) Conquer and expand, 2) Gather VPs, OR Go into Decline. If your race has reached as far as it can into the map, it can choose to go into Decline, making the race go away, so to speak, so a new race+power can be brought onto the map. The race in decline continues to generate VPs as long as their counters remain on the board--think residual income/VPs.

Components are gorgeous, standard Days of Wonder fair. Rules are well written.

Game is short enough at 60 minutes, that it will get plenty of plays early on, but the trend seems to be burnout, as players get familiar with the board and race+powers. Still, the fact that the board changes to accommodate 3-4-5 players is a plus. We'll see if it has staying power.

Update (08/28/10) 3 plays: I still like it, but others in my group are burned out, or turned off by some of the outrageous race-skill combos, or the cutthroat nature of the game. I think it is a matter of learning to identify a very good combo when one sees one, grab it, and play it effectively on the board. Still, it is possible that one may end up with some lousy race-skill combos. The flip-side is that great combos result in very good scores, that invite leader-bashing (and subsequently not winning the game), and allowing some other sleeper player to win.

Update (01/22/12): Initial rating an '8'. Do I want to own this? No. Do I have a sense of urgency to play this?Not really, but I'm open to playing it from time to time. Downing to a '7'.

RATING: 8
A nifty little tactics puzzle.  Played quickly with the full compliment of five.  Everyone agreed that I won because I was allowed to go about my business unmolested.

[b][COLOR=#FF0000]NOTE:  THIS GAME REQUIRES MOLESTATION[/color][/b]

Looking forward to playing it again.  I doubt my rating will rise, though it could fall once the shine comes off...

UPDATE:  This is a great game.  Very simple rules means that it's worked as a (gasp!) [i]gateway[/i] game for absolute n00bz.  Also, the tactical and strategic depths are both deceptively shallow—meaning that the obvious simplicity of the "pick up/put down/score" gameplay hides deeper decisions...  When to bunch up into a hard knot and when to spread thin?  When to decline?  Who do you pick on, and how?  The timing of these issues is what decides the winner.

Also, there is no shortage of absolute dick-moves in this game—I recommend mouthguards and running shoes, or someone's gonna lose teeth.

[b]After 11 plays:[/b]  (+1.4 bajillion plays on the iPad app) show this thing has functionally infinite replayability.  [i]Love it![/i]

RATING: 4
JEM 8. szám:

Szűk szomszédságban megesik az összezördülés, tartja a mondás, ami többszörösen is megállja a helyét egy olyan méretű világban, ahol egy népligetnyi területen próbál többségi helyzetbe kerülni minden népség, ami valaha fantasy címszava alatt. És ehhez a hangulathoz a grafika óriásit dob az egészen. 
Bemutató / Small World
A Small World játékmenete nincs túlbonyolítva, és nem nehéz megtanulni a szabályait sem. A játék során különböző képességekkel megáldott fajokkal csatározunk egymás ellen. De nem ugyanazzal a népséggel játszunk mindvégig. A pontszerzés mellett a megfelelő időpontban való távozásnak is mesterévé kell valamelyest válnunk. Ha úgy találjuk, képtelenek vagyunk aktív fajunkkal eredményesen játszani a továbbiakban, hanyatlásba fordíthatjuk, egy kör múlva másikat választva helyette.  
Több körre kicentizni stratégiánkat felesleges, mert itt egyik másodpercről a másikra dől meg a stratégiánk. A körök fogynak, így teljes hadjáratok kidolgozására ritkán van lehetőség, és felesleges is, mert a túlélésért fogunk egymással küzdeni. 

A fajválasztás adja meg a Small World sajátos ízét. Minden fajnak megvan a maga erőssége, sajátos képessége. A fajlapkákhoz képességek lapkái is kapcsolódnak érdekes és használható, vagy mihaszna népségeket létrehozva kombinációjukkal. A sorban az első fajt ingyen vehetjük el, minden továbbiért egy pontnyi érmét kell letennünk az azt megelőző fajkártyára, amit az kap meg, aki azt a fajt választja. Egy új faj a határ menti területek egyikén kezdi meg Small World térképére vonulását, és innen tovább a szomszédos területeken át. 

Nagyon népszerű játék, amelyet a rajongók a hangulata illetve az erős konfrontáció miatt szeretik. Nekem egyik sem jött be, és bár elismerem a játék előnyeit, de nekem mint megrögzött euro játékokért rajongónak ez nem tetszett.

RATING: 6
A reduced version of Vinci that benefits from being lighter and shorter. All the interest lies in the combination of race and special ability and there's fun in choosing your next race to play. Like its predecessor it's a highly mathematical game of eking out small advantages, putting your empire into decline when there's more to gain by starting another. It also retains the huge chaos factor in who gets attacked and who gets left to go on scoring. It's left entirely to the players to balance the game, the degree of wisdom involved in this being the main determinant of the outcome. One to enjoy, not one to take seriously.

RATING: 7
"It's a small world of slaughter after all," or so the box cover says. And it's right! Small world is such a cut-throut game. You start out with a random assortment of fantasy races to choose from (each of which have it's own special rules), combined with that, the races are paired with a random assortment of abilities. Orcs become Pillaging Orcs, Hobbits into Flying Hobbits (personal favorite), ect.

This is an area control game where after each turn you total up points for all the regions you control and any special bonuses from races and abilities. These points are kept secret and after 8 rounds, the person with the highest number of points wins.

This game has great replayability due to the randomization of races combined with abilities. Though it does take a little while to play, it is best played with the full compliment of 5, though 4 works just as good. But even if you have 2 or 3 players, it does come with special boards for those amounts.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pros: Fun. Addictive. Tons of variety and customization. Quick to teach and easy to play. Everything a good game should be, and what I've come to expect from DoW. I picked this game up on a whim, having never played it before and knowing little about it, and I am thrilled I did. The interchangeable nature of the races and powers (280 possible combinations with the base set alone) means it's never the same game twice. I find even non-gamers can enjoy this, including people (like myself) who don't generally care for direct conflict / war simulation games like Risk or Axis and Allies. SW is much more simple than those, while still having that thrill of territory conquest. I have played with 2-4 players and find it scales very well, and is just as fun with 2 players, even if it loses some of the multi-front interaction of a larger game. Be sure to remove the Diplomat power for 2P.

The races and special powers fall largely into 3 categories: Offensive bonus, Defensive bonus, or Terrain Type bonus. I play equally frequently with all 3 types, and it is fun adjusting my play strategy multiple times in one game as I switch old races for new ones. 

Cons: In general the female races of this series are rather sexualized, and some people I game with have found this tasteless. That and the sorcerer character looks a little too convincingly like a devil worshiper! Artwork aside, this game is fun and one I will come back to again and again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
First played April 23rd, 2009. Taught in 10 min, played in 1hr with 4 players. This game has good luck strategy mix. It's worth a play if you know someone who has it. A center board has teritories on it and is populated with a few decline races. Mountains defend at one more. 5 random races and 5 random special atribute are placed in groups of one each next to the board. Each race has a special ability (destroy 2 armies, recieve 1 army, etc) to go along with the special atribute tile (+1 for hills, etc). Each player is given 6 VPs. On each players first turn then pick a race groups. These groups are order and if you take the lowest of the 5 groups it's free. For each one going up, you pay one VP for each one you pass by. Later, when another player takes that race, they will recieve the VPs that another player placed. After you pick a race or on your next turn, you battle with your active race. You will generally have 9-11 armies to start. On your first turn, you entry from the sea or land, unless your race doesn't allow that). You win the battle by placing two armies down for an empty tile and one additional tile for each army or mountain on that territory. Some races give you extra defense or deny other players from attaching, etc. If you already have armies on the board, you may take all but one off of each territory and use for battle. If you take the last one, you will no longer control it. Each battle must be adjacent (unless you have a special ability). On your last battle, you may battle with less and use the die to assist your battle totals. Die is 0,0,0,1,2,3 pix. At the end of your turn you get VPs for each territory you own and perhaps some bonus VPs for certain conditions. In later rounds, you my choose to place your active race in decline. That will be your entire turn, except for collecting money for active and decline races. Once you send a 2nd race into decline, the previous race is replaced with generic decline race and you no longer get VPs for that race. Winner has the most VPs at the end of round 9.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
A solid game. It suffers a little from being way too cut throat with two players, and even three depending on which civilization/bonus combos come up. The game gets a little monotonous if you play it a lot. You have the exact same options every turn, there are no cards to gain bonuses or throw the other players for a loop. Every time I play, it just feels like a tug-of-war between me and whoever is near me on the map and I ultimately can never gain much more headway than my initial land grab with that civilization. It gets very same-y after a while. You end up investing a lot of time in setup for how long it lasts too. What this game really needs is a modular map (there is a fan-made expansion to achieve this.) The board being exactly the same every time makes no sense for a game like this. Even the special regions that confer bonuses for certain combo cards stay the same exactly every game. I wish that the special regions were decided by tokens instead so that at least something changed a little on each session. Same with the positions of the starter "NPC" units. Otherwise the game just gets very boring after your fifth play-through.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Area control game from Days of Wonder, which certainly enjoys the outstanding production values that their games have a reputation for.  The amount of tiles you get is amazing, and the boards (two double-sided boards in the box!) are vivid and beautifully drawn in the fantasy style.

The game involves picking a race and special power combo (which are drawn together for all players to choose from) which grants you a certain number of tiles of that race used for invading the areas on the board.  The mechanics are very simple, the invasion cost is 2 tiles plus one tile for every tile already in that area (if any), but the race and special powers offer discounts for invading, or grant more victory points for controlling certain areas.

A game in which the theming is phenomenal and the gameplay is fluid and easy to learn.  Highly recommend this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 1
I regret buying this game. At first, the concept seemed really awesome, with race and ability combo always being different and the art style looking so rich. The gameplay sucks though, I tried getting into it but it's so dull, nothing exciting ever happens. You don't know who's leading unless you write down the points that everybody gets and although each races are have different abilities, they all feel "passive".

You either can do the action or you can't, and you go for the best move every turn, but in the end not enough amount of luck can make anything really turn around, nothing ever gets exciting, you always know what to expect and at the end when it's time to reveal the winner, everyone's like "Oh, ok."

The best emotion I felt from playing this was feeling glad that the game was over, and I didn't care if I won or lost because you can't get a feeling of accomplishment from this. It's long and boring and it sucks. I'll probably use the material to invent some game of my own because otherwise it feels like a waste of money.

I played another game from the same company, Five Tribes, this one is awesome. I just don't understand how they could release Small World, or how after testing it, anyone could feel enough to think it was a good idea. It feels like half a game, like it's missing the most important thing of all...

RATING: 8
Fun game, NOT A GATEWAY GAME.  This can be a gateway game if your group has previous experience with D&D, video game rpgs, or if you are trying to convert risk players into better board games.  I don't recommend it as a gateway game because there are a ton of special powers in the game that are randomly combined.  It's not only overwhelming for non gamers, it's really hard to discern which power combinations are better.  

This is a game that I have to put on the shelf for now, until my groups have become more accustomed to board game mechanics.  I just feel like it is way too much to start people out on.

That being said, I do really really really like this game.  I used to really enjoy risk before I got into board gaming, so this is right up my alley, and the special powers are a lot of fun.  Just be cautious who you try this with.

RATING: 7
This is a very good game where every player takes control of a different race with an special attribute and tries to expand over the board conquering as many locations as possible. The game is very straightforward, you just have to put tiles over each location and then just count how many points have you achieved, it may sound as easy but the thing is that the game has strategy and every occupation has to be considered carefully. 
I think that the two best mechanics are: the race+attribute combination and the decay. The first one allows the game to be replayable, the second is maybe the key of the game. You just can't conquest the world with one race, sooner or later, the race loses its capability of expansion and needs to be replaced by another, at that point, the race has to be set into decay. Knowing when is the best moment to do it and which race take as a new active one, is the most important strategic aspect of the game.
Positive:
1. Easy to explain and play
2. The different boards that adapt the game from 2 to 5 players
3. The decay mechanic
4. Race+attribute combo
Negative:
1. It is pretty possible to have a race and attribute combination excessively powerful. That can break the round
2. The game is very easy to play, but is important to play it quick. There are not that many things to think about
3. Due to the way the game is, it may be overlooked by experienced players

RATING: 8
My kids love this game. It's a game that looks more complicated than it is. It's a very light and simple game with an amazing game mechanic of variable races and powers that randomly change in each game. That makes this game very replayable and entertaining. At times you'll see a race and power combo that is overpowered (Merchant Skeletons are crazy!)but getting to know those powers allows players to get better each game- which also lends you to want play again. The great art work and components are well organized in the box insert. You could call this a funny, fantasy version of Risk, but this game is more balanced, more accessible and more fun than Risk. Great family game, but don't expect a highly strategic gamer's game. It's comfortably in the Family Game/Party Game category for me.

Initial Rating: 6.0 (July 2010)

As its usual from a Days of Wonder game, I heavily dislike Small World. It was advertised to me as a Risk variant with much less luck. I would play any Risk over Small World any day. Also usual from DoW, the game is gorgeous, but I feel it has very obvious decisions. Very shallow and boring for me. All the players attack the perceived leader (I have come to dislike this), so the player who lay low the best, will be the winner. The best combo race vs cost is painfully obvious.

The race combos are very unbalanced. The game feel very repetitive after two turns.

I recognize it is a good family game (as all DoW games I have played) or to introduce new gamers to our hobby. For now, I refuse to play this other than in an iPad.

RATING: 7
Another instance of game designers and companies confounding my expectations.  I thought a redone Vinci couldn't possibly work.  Turns out a lot has been fixed.  Maps now scale with number of players, which is a very good thing.  The adjacency rules between active and declined civs no longer apply; these rules always struck me as due to counter limitations anyway.  The reduced penalty for skipping civs makes skipping more viable.

My reaction to the hidden VPs (assuming no one's tracking) is mixed.  On the plus side it's no longer a huge get-the-leader fest like Vinci was.  It's not always obvious who the leader is, though a good player should have some idea.  But with that introduces more diplomacy as players try to make their case for why they shouldn't be attacked.  In many games diplomacy is a nice addition but in Small World it's a nice term for "whining," and I've certainly done my share.

In the end I fall on the Small World side of the SW/Vinci debate, I think.

I'll have to play a couple more times to decide whether this is a 7 or an 8 for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Finally got around to playing this after seeing all the hubbub about it in the "Is Small World a wargame?" anguish and subsequent nerd rage. 

It's a finely-produced mini-civilization game. I enjoyed all the different races and the way you combine them with abilities--they give you plenty of combinations for replayability. The rules are straightforward and a double-sided player aid is really all you need. The art is a bit busy. Maybe it's just too many colors with too much saturation. It doesn't seriously detract from the game, just not quite my stylistic preference. 

It's not a wargame. Not even remotely close. Sorry. The fact that people can call the interaction between two races "combat" just astounds me. I'm not sure what to call it...maybe "replacement"? Combat to me implies that both sides are involved. That isn't what goes on here at all. You can optimize every play you make, and the "decision" of when to put your race into decline isn't much of one, because you'd have to be really thick to miss the right time to do it. 

Now that I have a daughter, I would evaluate this completely differently as a way to spend some good quality time with your family, especially children old enough to play. My comments above should be considered as a reaction to playing it with your standard game group of adult men and women. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.25
This is essentially a variant of Risk, but with some important differences.  

First, it's built in a fantasy world, complete with dragons, orcs, elves, and dwarves, etc... There are actually a good amount of differing races, each of which have their own personal benefit and will require you to slightly adjust your strategy.  Moreover though-- and herein lies half of the genius in its design-- the game setup combines these many races with a various special power of some kind or another which ultimately makes the game unique and different for each play.  

The other half of the genius of Small World is given away by its title: the board and its marked areas are most definitely small.  The board you will use (all of which are included) is decided simply by how many players there will be.  This is because, unlike Risk, there will be very little room for expansion without direct contact of another player after the first turn or, in some cases, even on the first turn!  The result is that you will be interacting and competing for territories with everyone else early and often.  

Finally, the racial decline feature is a great addition that allows for a player to choose when they want to retire, i.e. put their current race/power combo into "decline," thereby giving them the opportunity next turn to select a new race/power combo while still collecting victory points for the declined race, so long as they remain passively in play.

Small World isn't the most complex game or the most interesting if you're looking for large amount of detail or multitude of choice.  Once you grasp the central idea of the game, any decision making is mostly effortless and can sometimes feel unrewarding since What Small World does, it does well.       
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2

If someone tells you it doesn't have strategy to it, don't listen to them.  It does.

RATING: 6
New Comment:

Small World is more about comedy than anything else. In the right environment, I suppose it could be a dream come true. As a game, it's a bit simple and even with all the "combinations" of races and powers, it feels repetitive. I don't play this for an engaging game experience. I play it because there are flying tritons and commando giants. I do give DoW credit for parodying the fantasy genre; it was ripe. 

Gameplay description: you draft a race with a specific augment. You put ~10 counters on the board. You have to outnumber other players with your counters to take over territory. Your race slowly weakens as you get thrown out of provinces. After 2-3 turns, they hit a breaking point, so you retire them and draft a new race. There's obviously a bash-the-leader style inherent to this type of game. There are some tactics to which territory you try to take and hold, especially if you can sequester a retired race. But the gameplay is pretty thin.

RATING: 5
Small World is a well-built but rather boring machine, a bit like the Euro game equivalent of a wood-paneled station wagon. That may be a bit too harsh, but Small World fits into the Days of Wonder paradigm of nice-looking, easy-to-learn games with a small number of decisions to make. Even by these criteria, Small World is not a wildly successful game. It's less physically appealing than many DoW games, and the decisions are even fewer than average. Perhaps the only decision I find truly interesting is when to put a race into decline, and even that is fairly obvious unless time is almost up. The race and special ability combinations seem fairly balanced, which is a pretty neat trick considering how many there are (though with only three tokens inherently, the Dwarves do seem rather weak). There is also some amusement factor in odd juxtapositions of race and power, such as Skeleton merchants. The actual gameplay moves pretty quickly, but it has to or else its thinness would become even more obvious. Deterministic combat can be all right--I like Imperial quite a lot, for example--but it feels about as dry as day-old toast here. Maybe it's the fact that combat doesn't feel like anything and the game is set in yet another generic fantasy world, but I kind of just want to play my turn and move on. Small World does a very good job of doing what it sets out to; it's just not something that I'm particularly excited about.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Small World is an impressive feat of doing everything completely wrong
when trying to update an existing game. The graphic design is not only
garish, but actively user-hostile. Vinci might have been ugly, but at
least it had some clarity.

The rules were changed to try to patch the worst problems of Vinci,
but ended up just replacing them with larger ones. Hidden but
trackable VPs were probably supposed to take care of the pathological
"beat on the leader" aspect of the game, but instead it just adds a
tedious memory component if you want to play well, or just totally
unbalancing the game if it's not tracked.

The other rules changes don't work at all either.  The fixed number of
turns means that there is way less uncertainty about the decision of
going into decline. Removing the cohesion rule might have simplified
the game, but it also removed pretty much the only rule in Vinci that
made the board play interesting in any way.

SW is utter dreck, and I can't really see any reason to play it rather
than Vinci.

RATING: 7
Not having previously played Vinci, it's hard for me to compare, though I understand that points were not hidden in Vinci - this would definitely affect the speed of play, an important element that I like about Small World, as I can see how open scores would slow down the game.  

I don't particularly care for the theme or the artwork - I'm not too big on fantasy themes, so I'm not excited about the theme, but it's not too big of a problem for me either.  I can understand some people's complaints regarding the messy board, but I don't really care about that.  I do appreciate the box insert, complete with counter tray - a really nice touch that is sort of a hallmark of Days of Wonder games, nice attention to detail.

The game itself isn't too exciting, but I like the decisions regarding decline, as well as the amount of player interaction.  There is enough randomness as well to make it unpredictable.  And with the large number of races and special powers, the replayability is high.  It's a fun diversion, but I'm not sure it's a truly great game yet.

RATING: 6
Picked it up second hand. I've tried it a few times now, it never seems to land that well with the groups I play with.

It seems to be incredibly popular in the community because of the tongue-in-cheek theme and simple, easy-to-learn mechanics. I guess that makes sense, but the theme alone isn't wowing me in the same way it does others.

The game just doesn't seem to have enough interesting decision-making to really call it a full game. It boils down to:
1. race selection,
2. where you start your invasion with said race,
3. when you put your race into decline, which can be sometimes linked to #1.

You will probably put 1-3 races into decline in a game. Which means at most 11 interesting moments in the game per player. And #1 is basically a couple minutes spent reading/remembering the rules for each race and special ability that's available, then picking what seems best. That doesn't sound like much compared to just about anything else that plays in 60-90 minutes. With a bunch of experienced players, this game would probably play in about 30 minutes, and there wouldn't be much to it.

The redeeming factor is the number of jokes you can make about whats going on on the board. But there are tonnes of other activities which facilitate that better... and to be honest I'd rather just get drunk and probably will the next time I play Small World.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Note: definitely better with more than 2. It's OK as a 2-player, but with less to dilute the advantage of going first - and only one other person to hammer you if you're lucky enough to have one really pointy ear, like I do - I just don't think it really works.

I won my first game of this, and I might have to lose at it a few times before I can claim an opinion approaching objectivity, but I really enjoyed my first game. I started out as Mounted Humans, with whom I had a poor first few rounds; then moved on to Berserk Ghouls, who I found useful for their special power keeping their pieces on the board, even in decline. It was really my Wealthy Sorcerers who made the game for me, though. I managed not to lose too many pieces as I expanded across the top of the board, and pretty soon I was most of the way down, converting one of my opponent's pieces into my own for the last two turns. 

I like the race selection mechanic. It's worthy of emulation, and creates the sense of playing in a world peopled by empires rising and falling. The fact that you can cut and run on your civilization makes for an interesting balancing act. You don't generally get to be Italy, and just go into decline and stay that way for two millennia. The Spirit ability never showed up in this game, but it could be interesting if it's in early enough. 

I'm afraid there are a few combos in here that might break it, but overall, Smallworld is devilishly fun. We played with five, which may be less than ideal - I think I might prefer four.

--

Update: this game hasn't aged all that well for me. I'm less and less interested in fantasy themed games as time goes on, and to me, the expansions erode rather than improve the base game.
