RATING: 9
I've played the game more now, and I still find it addicting and enjoyable.  I'm not really too sure what there is I could complain at, the game aims to be a fast-paced fun little strategy game and I believe hits the mark perfectly.  

If I were to try and nitpick, it seems that often the key to winning is to figure out who is in the lead, and then beat them down as much as possible.  Figuring out when you've hurt them enough and when to switch to the next target can be tricky, and is in my opinion where most of the "strategy" of the game lies.  Because of this, newer players playing with veterans can lead to somewhat of a lopsided game, since the newbies may not be able to pick up on this right away, or keep track of who's in the lead very easily.

RATING: 6
I really wanted to like Small World, but for me it falls short. Typical of Days of Wonders games, it looks great and plays fairly quickly. The name is appropriate, because this game is all about too many unique races being crammed into a Small World, and fighting for control. The game is exceptionally well-designed, with multiple maps for different player counts, and interesting combos of races and abilities waiting to be unleashed against your opponents. However, the game falls flat for me.

For all the cool thematic fantasy races and the colorful setting, the gameplay does not deliver a thematic fantasy experience. It is a dry, strategic numbers game. Every turn is one of bean-counting and optimizing the ability of your units to take and hold regions. As a pure strategy game, it is quite well done. The choices are interesting and the gameplay is quick. However, this contradicts the potentially rich fantasy theme. Your Commando Amazons are nothing more than a stack of cardboard, and every bit of terrain, or defense, or every unit on a region is a piece of cardboard.

I love thematic Eurogames, and I wanted Small World to be one... but it isn't. It's not a bad game, but it wasn't what I wanted it to be.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A game of conflict for 2-5 players (or 6 with certain expansions). Players choose a unique race paired with a special power and over the course of the game a player will put their original race into decline and continue with a brand new race, possibly several times. Points are earned each turn for territories controlled on the always crowded board.

It's a pretty simple game but each race will be paired with different special powers from game to game so you have to re-evaluate and consider new combinations each and every game. Choosing your race/power combo and timing when you go into decline (to pick a new race/power combo) is an essential element to doing well. However, the game is also about territory control and since there is very little luck in the game planning ahead and anticipating (or encouraging) opponents moves pays off.

Some players claim it is obvious what the best move is each turn but it's really not about getting the highest score you can on each turn, it's about consistently scoring. A high score this turn that leaves you exposed and out of position for the next two is not necessarily as good as a moderate score this turn that leaves you in a strong position. 

I like the game because it offers new combinations of powers to consider each play and it rewards strategy and thinking ahead while keeping a very simple/streamlined rule set.

RATING: 6
Before anything, let me state this: Small World is an abstract in disguise. While this is true for all games, the fact is Small World is an area control game with pretty illustrations.

The game's meat resides in the decline mechanism: players can skip a turn to make their current race enter in "decline". Races in decline still count towards area control for their original owner, but can't be moved and loose all special abilities. The key of the game is exploiting the decline mechanism to the maximum.

Another important mechanism, though not as crucial, are the races' special powers. Not only each race has its own characteristic power, but each will also be accompanied by a unique characteristic which will grant him another special ability. Players need to gauge the impact the available combinations may have on the board.

Despite conflict being its main focus, Small World is quite friendly. Firstly, combats aren't particularly deadly. Secondly, even if a player is wiped out he still has the chance of making a comeback with another race. Due to this, it works like charm as an introductory game for fantasy geeks, as it's eye catchy easy to learn.

But its cute appearance is a ruse: the game is extremely unforgiving. Enter decline a turn later than you should and your chances to win the game will be drastically reduced, enter sooner and you will be at a disadvantage too. I wouldn't mind this at all if not for the fact a player may not be able to tell when exactly he should enter in decline. It's always obvious in retrospective, but in advance? Sometimes it's plain impossible, which leads to a false perception of depth, as entering in decline is more of a "push your luck" move than an informed choice. While most declines are a matter of skill, I'd say one out of every four declines is a matter of pure luck. Considering the severity of the consequences, it's not a percentage I feel comfortable with.

Small World is a fun and light area domination game. The decline mechanism is both what makes and breaks the game.

RATING: 9
The game is very simple, almost silly at first glance but it's great. It's full of interaction and there's no tactics that let you win- you always depend on others' choices and the better you score in one turn the more beating you'll get from your opponents because there can be only one winner in the end. So you have to keep balance between playing carefully without becoming too big threat to others and being able to strike a blow in the right moment to get most points. 
It's like a miniature of a strategic war game which takes about 1,5 an hour instead of 6-8 hours.
The game is very well done, the artwork is funny but nice and consistent. The game feels rather light though it gets people angry sometimes. Great replayability.

RATING: 10
This game hits the table way more often than all my other games, both among gamers and non-gamers. I found it to be a good gateway game: it has a great theme and is quite easy to learn, the ability to go into decline and pick a new race allows players to make up for mistakes made earlier in the game, the dependence on other players' actions and a tiny bit of randomness keeps people from over-thinking and micro-managing for hours, so the downtime is minimal, even with 5 people, and there is enough strategical thinking involved for the game to be still interesting for me after like 100 plays. Simply put: the perfect game :)

It's made even better by adding some of the races/powers from the expansions, and removing the underpowered dwarves.

RATING: N/A
Great game, with tons of fun combos to experiment with! Unfortunately, a lot of people are blind to its true depth. If your strategy is to "spread out as thinly as possible as quickly as possible, go into decline, wash, rinse, and repeat," then you pretty much fail to see the game. A lot of "hardcore" gamers have dismissed this game as something much shallower than it really is, some even going so far as to call it a gateway game that becomes "solved" after a few plays (which is simply beyond absurd). It has a great deal more strategic depth and psychological intrigue to it than that!

RATING: 6
First of all, I played vinci and I made a free re-edition of the game before small world was released. So by taking a look at small worlds it's like wanting to know what does the original designer has changed compared to my re-edition.

Die roll for the last attack: Nice idea since it allows you to get rid of your leftovers tokens, but the odds are so low. 

Hidden scoring: Many people said that hidden scoring is better. It could be true indeed. This is why I added it to my re-edition of vinci.

Fixed turns: I have nothing against a fixed amount of turns, but 9 turns is not enough. In vinci, the average amount of turns was 15 which gives you much more time to decline and get new civilizations. In the last game, I could use only 3 civilizations which is way not enough.

Theme: I like the retheming of the game even if there is a lot of fantasy games out there.

Component design: The game has too much colors and graphics, it's really hard to analyze the board and it is especially hard to analyze where each civilization is an who owns it. For example, all decline tokens are gray, and the color of tokens is not associated to the players so you need to check which player owns which civ. Also the civ colors are very light making them hard to be recognized.

No component reuse: There is no reusing of components, they sometimes made components that could only be used by a specific race ability. The problem with this is expandability and the price of the game. If you want to add new races and abilities, you also need to add new tokens instead of reusing the old ones. But that it still a publisher's choice.

Fixed troops amounts: The number of troops you get does not change with the amount of players. The problem is that the coverage of the map won't be the same according to the number of players. So there will be more or less empty space.

Rule of Cohesion is removed: I got nothing against that, it just makes the game simplier.

New map: Taking a fictional map was good, but why not have a modular map to make sure that every game is different. It would have also be possible to adjust the game better between 4-5 players and 2-3 players.

Price for the civilizations: I am not sure that paying from 1 to 5 points to get better civilizations is enough. In the original game you paid from 2 to 10 and ended with somewhat the same score. So I think it is not expensive enough.

In overall, I prefer my vinci re-edition that smallworld.

RATING: 6
Small World was one of my gateway games. When I got into boardgaming early this year, this was the third game I bought after Tsuro and Ticket to Ride. But while I still enjoy Tsuro and TTR and I still play these games regularly, Small World started hitting the table less and less. While it's a gorgeous looking game and the gameplay is straight forward, I also came to the realisation after 15 plays that the game was.... rather dull. 

The deterministic combat, the placement of chits, the counting of area's that you control... It's all a bit dull because when it's one player's turn the other players aren't engaged. They don't have to be because there is nothing for them to do when it's not their turn. I kept hoping that the next game with the next group would be the exciting game that would make Small World come alive for me. It never happened. So it was time for me to find a new home for my copy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Wonderful bits (tiles are easy to remove when you buy the game, special tile shapes, nice and sturdy boards, etc.).

More varied (in terms of theme, and tactics) than Knizia's Samurai, but lighter.  Lighter than Caylus Magna Carta or even Through the Desert.

After playing a few games: I don't feel like I'm much in control, when playing; I don't have much visibility.  For instance, the "wipe race out" effect prevents any great story arc to take place: each time you pick up a race, you almost have to start afresh.  Plus, it is somewhat hard to count on any specific race+ability combo, as other players might get the race that you had in mind before you know it.  This makes the game somewhat lack strategy (but tactics is present during each conquest).

Update after playing 35 games, mostly on iOS: the race choices are the main choices I need the game, and they are meaningful. This is where the main game is (with just two or three moves in a given game!), along with the choice of going into decline. The rest consists in having a correct strategy and tactics for the occupation of regions, but this is easier and less rich (but interesting: how to group or spread your troops, how to shut off the opponent, where to position reinforcements given where your opponent might want go, etc.).

The game is light because choices each turn are limited or don't have many obvious consequences. This feeling is compounded by the fact that I don't see clearly in the consequences of my choices, so I am not very much immersed in the game. 

The races are relatively varied, and the expansions add some really interesting twists (Cursed, Grand Dames, … Fear…). 

That said, playing fast on the electronic version is nice: 15 minutes makes the game denser and therefore more interesting. This is a great way of exploring the interactions between races and an overall strategy. 

It may be that I don't have enough practice and am not able to make longer term plans.  Maybe knowing the races and powers better would help me better judge the potential power of each combo, and make more strategic plans.

There is no real story arc (even Agricola or Race have more of this). Instead, the game can be summarized as the couple of races each player got.

The iOS version is a BGG 9, for me, thanks to its identical experience, but condensed in 20 minutes. 

 Globally, I feel that beyond some basic strategies related to regions (mostly based on protecting your in-decline race with your active one, and avoiding the sides if possible in preparation for future new races), the most important choices are the races. Since there are only two or three such choices in a game, this is how much demanding it is. This is why I prefer the constant decisions of Race for the Galaxy, and why I am not such a big fan of being stuck in corridors in Space Hulk, as the order of the line of space Marines is a choice done only rarely. 

Less "lethal"/aggressive than Colossal Arena.

RATING: 7
Las claves del juego son 2: 

1) Elegir ciudadosamente qué raza en qué momento (para hacer muchos puntos de una tacada o bien para contrarrestar a los rivales) SIN QUE IMPORTE demasiado el coste de compra de dicha raza, pues la mayor parte de los casos, si es la raza adecuada en un momento dado esa inversión resultará rentable.
Hay que tener en cuenta qué combinaciones son útiles para hacer muchos puntos y cúales para neutralizar al rival. Para hacer esto último, si es necesario abandonar las regiones que ocupas y empezar de nuevo en otras más próximas al rival (ó en las que está él) no lo dudes, hazlo.

2) Saber cúando poner en declive tu raza activa; si exprimes demasiado tu raza activa puedes obtener menos ganancia de dinero en algunas rondas y ponerte en desventaja con respecto a los rivales.

Nota: Una forma fácil de ayudarte a tomar estas decisiones consiste en, si tienes buena memoria, ir calculando la diferencia de dinero entre tú y tus rivales(en positivo o negativo), o bien, el total de puntos de cada uno ronda a ronda, como prefieras.

RATING: 9
This game is amazing. If anyone plays Risk, this is the answer to it. The first thing that i noticed is that one gives back coins to skip certain classes, and all coins are secret, so the person thought to be ahead never is. Also the combinations are amazing, so one race/ talent might never show up. Add in a couple of fun expansions and this game is MASSIVE, much bigger than the 10 turns allows. We often play this game once a night, two or three player, although keeping track of all of the pieces can be a challenge. I would love to give this game a ten, but one player usually runs away with it, scoring tons of points off of one or two good runs. Interestingly the games are usually pretty close, and the strategy is complex. It takes about five minutes to learn and everything is well labeled and divided. Also the instructions are laid out so everyone can see what every creature does whenever they please. This is a must have, if only to play every once in awhile.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The slightly cartoony artwork was attractive enough to get her interested (she got a kick out of the "It's a world of slaughter" tagline).  I think this approach made the fantasy theme a lot more approachable than usual.  However, the gameplay didn't quite work for us.  We both liked the variety of ability/race combinations, which helped keep the game fresh.  Being able to decline your race and enter the game with fresh troops is another aspect that reduces the mean-ness of the game.  In contrast, the battle aspect felt a lot more like chess---since it was deterministic, it felt more like an optimization puzzle.  

With two players, the game felt even more calculating and zero-sum, although still with some interesting decisions---do you conquer new territories (usually for cheap) or attack your opponents (usually more expensive but costing them points).  As a result, the game loses some of the fun and becomes more mechanical.  My wife in particular didn't enjoy that.  We're eager to try this with more, since that might introduce enough randomness to make things more interesting.

RATING: 6
Technically I was playing with a significant rule wrong, but I think I have enough of a feel of the game that I can give at least a tentative rating. The special powers of this game and how the combinations always change can be really cool, and there is a little bit of a spatial aspect with some races getting bonuses for certain regions, and central regions generally being harder to get conquered. However, I didn't like how abstract the combat was, and really disliked how busy the board looks. If it wasn't for the business, this game could be quite easy to teach to new gamers, but due to it it makes the game look a lot more complicated than it actually is, and it is really easy to miss some of your pieces (and this is coming from someone who generally will sacrifice some function when it comes to good art).

RATING: 9
This really is a brilliantly designed game, Winning requires cool, detached deliberation and abstract reasoning, but it has all the life and color of some of the most whimsically decorous Ameritrash games. Perhaps the best part of it, though, is its cleverly shaped learning curve - learning the rules that one needs to know to start playing is ridiculously easy, but figuring out how each of the races and powers can help and hurt you once you've started is a deep and intellectually demanding enough task to make the game hugely replayable. 

My only very minor quibble is that the mechanism of putting races in decline makes it hard for the player to feel that there's any consistent flavor to his own style of play, in the way that a player of Puerto Rico can say to himself "I'm the Indigo guy!" or a player of some deep co-op game (Battlestar Galactica, say) can exhibit a consistent pattern of making one specific type of contribution to the team. This isn't the sort of thing that's likely to bother Euro fans very much, though.

RATING: 6
A very simple area control game.  You get a race with a special characteristic.  You use that race to conquer lands in a "small world".  The mechanic is simple to take territory where it is one more unit than the territory and the number of other "cardboard" pieces on the board.  You can then send the civ into decline as your whole move on turn and get a new civ.  Players should "kill the leader" but hidden vp's make it ambiguous.

RATING: 9.5
Brilliant game!

All the subtlety of a Euro wrapped in a Fantasy Wargame.

The Humour is childishly funny (Flying Dwarves, Seafaring Halflings...)

The Strategy is not just restricted to:
"Run around with BIG armies and conquer as many regions as you can, then when your army starts to weaken it put into decline, get a  new army and start all over again"

You could do this but remember it's not RISK !

If you do play it as a simple RISK style Crush and conquer you'll find yourself been outscored by more crafty opponents.

The twist each fantasy race adds to the game is excellent.

RATING: N/A
SEEMINGLY THE BEST STORAGE SOLUTION:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/image/473555/small-world
https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/594677/how-i-conquered-small-world

Days of Wonder Tutorial:
http://www.daysofwonder.com/smallworld/en/

This is an area control game similar to war games like risk. BUT due to the light theme and unique gameplay, the games feels more enjoyable for most (except war game purists). As Scott Nicholson puts it, a person who enjoys the first 30 minutes of Risk and then gets bored is the type of person who would enjoy this game. Other benefits to the lite-gamer is the relative quick (aka "compressed") play of the game and the very straight-forward rules.

Great Description: "it's similar to 'Risk,' but its over in an hour; and there's very little luck involved."

See comments to Memoir 44.

Great pictures for packaging the bits: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/408772/i-dont-normally-like-this-type-of-thing-a-rather

http://www.boardgamegeek.com/image/715182/small-world?size=original

SUBSEQUENT CONQUESTS VIS-A-VIS ADJACENCY:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/545700/a-race-separated-in-2-separate-areas-of-the-map-


SORCERERS ZAP (esp v-v Flying):
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/546807/flying-and-non-flying-sorcerers

RATING: 6
Rated 7 after just one 5-player game.

Weird fluke, that there isn't enough races for a five player game. Once everybody has one race in decline, there is only four races left to lay up and chose from?!
____________________________________________

After more plays ...
Stays a 7, and I wonder if the fun and flavor wouldn't be even better if they had stayed in europe and used real cultures and traits from a magical reality interpretation of history? 
So you could have Druidic Teutonians, Vendetta Samies or Etruscans in Viking longboats ... IMO the game would tell better and funnier stories that way.
___________________________________________

Even more games later: Down to 6.
Having the most pointy ears is too much of an advantage: First pick of races and free pick of starting areas to conquer. In the last round you score first, so the rest of the players will have to pound each other - increasing your margin.
With hidden VP's there really need to be a mechanism to even out the startplayer advantage.
If I did fractions, it would likely get 6½.

RATING: 9
This has become a heavily played game amongst my gaming group... its highly replayable due to the variation in which races/powers come up, the gameplay is fairly quick with little downtime, and there's plenty of opportunity for direct conflict between players without the bitterness of player elimination, due to the mechanic whereby players may select a new race. It's lustre is fading for me a little these days, but only because it has come to the table probably over 20 times.

RATING: 9
great gameplay
great replay ability
great theme
great quality
causes laughter in the same moment you have intense rival-inducing conflict
works great with 2 players and works just as great with 5

This is my top pick for a good competitive game.  I grew up on risk and love it but this outshines it by far.  Its a slaughter but the intensity stays at 10 where games like risk slowly die out.  If you think your crushing your opponent its more than likely their just crouching before they pounce. 
If a player is "killed off" they just come right back with more, faster than if you let them live.
This game does a great job keeping the same board but having the player be random.  The opposite of the norm and it works great!

the only thing keeping this game from a 10/10 is its not for everyone, the random deal even with it being out for all seems to bother the fair seekers

RATING: 9
Board Game
STRATEGY, Fantasy, Territory building, Area control/Area influence, Area movement, Dice rolling, Variable players powers

2-5
45'-90'

Complexity: M/L 2,37

Picking the right combination from the 14 different fantasy races and 20 unique special powers, players rush to expand their empires - often at the expense of weaker neighbors. Yet they must also know when to push their own over-extended civilization into decline and ride a new one to victory!
Brilliant strategy game with a humoristic touch and sheer endless combinations of races. Top notch!!

Played: 2016 - 2017

RATING: 6.5
The fantasy theme is very inspired and draws interest from nearly everyone I've played this game with. The feeling of starting your own race, conquering the world, is a magnificent feeling, really helping this game get repeated plays. The decline mechanic also helps, because no one truly seems left out for too long. However, there is always a feeling of sadness for your race with every decline. The gameplay, however and be a little dry with time, with every decision being somewhat obvious. The interaction of players is nice though, with battles being fought in a clash of chits and a cry of foul play. Not a perfect game, and not a game I will play hours on end, but a solid one. 

Edit: It's honestly not good enough. It's a decent game, but it's just too fiddly and the game is too straightforward. I can see why its popular but I don't think it holds up.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Small World is everything I wanted it to be -- and as an added bonus, it comes with the most amazing box insert and one of the best sets of components I've ever seen. The counter tray is brilliant.

It's an easy game to teach, but the interactions between the powers and races available and the ones in play, as well as the decline mechanic, put some meat on its bones. It also plays quickly, is just plain fun, and has the right amount of tension and strategy for its weight. Because there are so few turns, the game is brisk -- and every turn matters, from timing your declines to recognizing a scoring opportunity based on a particular race or board condition.

The inclusion of separate boards for 2-3-4-5 players, plus the "rules in one page" summary sheets, really adds more gravy to the gravy that is Small World, too. This could rise to a 9 with more plays.

---

Having now played it with 2, 3, and 4, I can say that it's a lot of fun with 2, really shines with 3, and is saggy and boring and overstays its welcome by about 45 minutes with 4. With 4, I could wander away from the table for 10 minutes, come back for my turn, and leave again -- and I wanted to. It sucks ass with 4.

---

It expands well, adding variety without rules overhead (my sweet spot for expansions). I had to move to a tightly packed Plano box after adding a couple expansions, but it works well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
A really fun Area Control game. Normally in area control i struggle with the war mechanics of dice, cards, bluffs all compounded by special player abilities. BUT here the simple 2+1per obstacle system makes it so easy. The simple scoring of areas each turn instead of lasting for rounds and rounds means you can bank points and then react, instead of hoping to rebound. The ability to build and empire and then scrap it and start over makes this SO MUCH fun! add in the "hidden" scores, means you always feel like you are in the game!  

Purchased 6/29/17 (Titan)

RATING: 10
Tons of conflict, good for 2-5, very pretty, close finishes, hard decisions, diplomacy, replayability, comedy theme - though rather fiddly. The lack of balance is marked in 2 player games, but in 3-5 - look out if you get what is perceived as a killer attacking combo: you're going to get pounded! Great family game, good laughs. 
Picked it up cheap on iPad; eliminates fiddliness but the AI is weak; it is totally inept against an aggressive opponent and it is essentially trivial to win games by scorelines of about 100-60 by going on all-out attack.
Update to Small World 2 pretty great; still easy in 2-player but gets more challenging and thinky with more players, because the aggressive approach described above collapses.
Have upgraded my rating to 10 on replayability of app; have played hundreds of games against the computer as a few minute timekiller, and I still enjoy it.

RATING: 9
I love small world.  It is such a simple game to learn but difficult to master.  

The thing I love about the game is how little randomness is involved.  While the race/adjective combinations are random, knowing which one to pick to maximize your position on the board to a key to victory.

Really my 2 main complaints about the game are the reinforcement dice, which adds a dynamic I do not like to the game, and the fact that I think the dwarf race is a little underpowered.  Even on my best round with the dwarfs I have only gotten 6 points...I tend to feel that if they don't show up as a first turn pick, it is best to pass them for a better race.

Overall this is a great game and I can't wait to add it to my collection.

RATING: 8
A solid game. The most critical decisions are what race to select and when to decline. Small mistakes in these decisions can easily cost the game. As such, the game feels somewhat unstable. But as long as it's kept moving and not bogged down in AP, it's always enjoyable no matter how bad your position.

As a player, you really need to figure out who you think is in the lead and take it to that person. Some race combinations, if left unmolested, can really run away with it. The temptation is often to take the immediately best move for you. But the right move is often to damage the leader as much as possible and get your big scores later.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
GAMEPLAY: An area-control and variable-player-powers eurogame. The game has 14 races and 20 special powers which are randomly paired. Each player selects a race-and-special-power combination and uses corresponding race tiles to conquer regions on the board. Players decide when to put their race into decline and select a new race-and-special-power combination. Players score victory points based on their special powers and the number of regions they control at the end of each turn. The game ends after a fixed number of rounds which varies depending on the number of players.

WEIGHT: Medium. The basic rules are not complex but it takes a number of plays to become sufficiently familiar with the abilities of the different races and special powers.

PLAYER INTERACTION/CONFLICT: High. Players frequently conquer regions held by other players, removing one of the other player’s race tiles from the game.

PLAYER COUNT: Scales well from two to five players. Each player count has its own game board. An excellent high-conflict two-player game.

LUCK: Low. Players sometimes use a die roll at the end of their turn to attempt to conquer one region using fewer race tiles than are normally required, but the players’ tactical decisions will nearly always far outweigh the die rolls in determining game outcomes.

RATING: 5
Area control games with very simple rules. Strong though superficial theme with nice emergent humour from the random combination of races with powers. Decent and attractive components with several game boards being a bonus. Overly slow gameplay for such simplistic rules and shallow strategic depth. Long downtime while waiting for other players. Not a good entry game for non-gamers, or a good game for casual, filler or party situations because of play and waiting times, and not a good game for experienced gamers because of the time-versus-depth ratio. Low replayability because of simplistic mechanics.

Rather unsatisfying for strategically-oriented players, for witch El Grande might be a better alternative with richer though familiar mechanics and similar session times.

RATING: 8
Conçu par Philippe Keyaerts dans la droite ligne du jeu Vinci, primé à plusieurs reprises, Small World plongera les joueurs dans un monde habité par des nains, des mages, des amazones, des géants, des orcs et même des humains. Ces peuples luttent sans merci en envoyant leurs troupes à la conquête de nouvelles régions : les civilisations les plus faibles seront impitoyablement chassées du monde de Small World !

En choisissant la bonne combinaison entre les 14 Peuples et les 20 Pouvoirs Spéciaux au bon moment, les joueurs pourront étendre leur empire, souvent aux dépens de leurs voisins ! Cependant, leur civilisation finira par s'essouffler - il leur faudra alors en choisir une autre pour remporter la victoire.

À vous de choisir le bon Peuple au bon moment et de défendre la grandeur de votre empire face aux ambitions de vos voisins... car le monde est tout petit !

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I don't enjoy war games, as I feel the long-term planning is too tedious, especially when the dice play such a crucial role in determining the victor.  Having said that, Small World isn't a war game at all, despite the fact that it hides underneath a war-gaming theme.  There's virtually no combat between players, and the game is all about choosing the right combination of power and race, using that race to its fullest potential, and then abandoning it for a new one.  I like the idea of having to switch to a new race once the current one is stretched too thin, as this unique mechanic really separates this game from most other games I've played.  After two plays, I'm definitely liking Small World, although I'm worried that its entertainment value will fade with time.  This one hasn't hit the table in a while, and it frequently seems like there are other games we'd rather play.

Pretty chaotic strategy/ light wargame with a captivating map. Or more accurately, maps, since there are three total included, scaled to the number of players. Best with three or four players, I reckon, though can be played with 2-5. This one starts to get fun after a few playings, and people start to understand the mix and match combos. But it starts to get tedious pretty quickly after that. I will add that this game is beautiful. Days of Wonder did it up right.  I wish there was a little more depth to the combat, or to the game as a whole, but the simplicity is a plus in many circles. Not very good as a 2 player game since whoever gets the most unbalanced combo first has a big advantage. The iPad version is a lot more fun for me, as many of these simple games tend to be. Removes all the setup and upkeep.

Edit: I have been playing this quite a bit recently on the iPad again, and I am reminded about an almost unbelievably annoying part of this game: the die rolls. Normally die rolls don't bother me at all (I am a long time wargamer, after all), but here they just swing the game too much. They are annoying in this game in the same way the die rolls are annoying in Summoner Wars.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Ooooh, saving myself some time, copying from my comments on Underworld. 

This one is more interesting than I thought it would be on the surface - I somehow thought it would be more Risk-like in play, but the deterministic combat and the way the race+abilities work makes it feel more like a puzzle. Calculating your maximum score for any given turn is one thing, but the focal point of the game is in timing your decline correctly, and considering your choice of race as they are far from equal. Also, the way the powers on the board work can change things up a bit (making things less straight forward).

The downside is that ultimately, if you are the one that gets the least beat on - you'll probably win, but that is more of a player issue (though the hidden scoring makes it easier for a player to mistake another for the leader - If you track so it isn't much of an issue, but that won't always be the case (though if that isn't the case then open scores most likely wouldn't change things either based on my experience)).

Enjoyable, goes by quick and you get to feel clever when you perfectly time your decline so you not only get to steal the perfect race from someone else, but also then use it to force an unwanted decline for another player. The idea of harassing the active rather than the declined race is something people quickly grasp (forcing them into decline to be able to do anything, which will wipe the current race in decline off the board as well).

A good game, this one has the clearer map than the underworld one, and expansions that fit it better, so it might get the nod if you plan to expand on it - but from what I gather Underworld has a bit more interesting races and artifacts/locations that add some more stuff to the game which might give it the nod if just comparing base games.

Can see this being one to play with family and wife, but pretty hefty price tag if I only play it a couple of times.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Game in a Nutshell: Use different races with their own special powers to outnumber the masses across a board and score points for territories controlled. Spread too thin? Grab another race and run over those in decline.

Played as: 3,4 player

Pros: Quick to learn, relatively light, loads of variety in the races and special power combination's, but mostly it's just balls to the wall fun. There's no holding back in this game you just cream people as far as you can, then rest until the next chance to do it again. There's almost no incentive to hold back since you can always start a new race and use that to cover more territory. It's nice to see a combative game not so reliant on luck and the bit there is is a nice edge. The artwork is beautiful, theme well implemented, and having four completely different boards for the different numbers of people playing is a great touch.

Cons: The game play, as you probably can already tell, is pretty straightforward. There's only a few real meaningful decisions to make: What race to choose, where to enter the board, and what time to go into decline. Everything else will simply play itself out if you let it. I haven't played a two-player game, but I can't imagine how it would be worth playing as such.

Other: The amount of confrontation needs to be considered with some players; it's either going to be a big plus or a big minus. All the negatives I've mentioned are non-existent to me because I just love the positives so much more, but I mention them as potential downfalls that others might find stand in the way of their own enjoyment. 

Best Use: 3-5 people who want a fast, confrontational game and don't want to hold back.

RATING: 8
A re-themed Vinci (which I like). Very nice components, and the fantasy theme that is thick as Vegemite.

The game is quick to learn and has tons of replayability, even without the myriad of expansions. 

It has surprising strategic depth, especially when playing with thinkers. 

What makes this game especially fun (aside from the artwork, theme, mechanics, and so on) is that is plays according to the group - if you have a fun, roleplaying type of group, it lends itself to that. As mentioned above,  if you have serious strategic gamers, it has enough depth and options to give you a challenge, especially when it comes to planning where to reinforce, who to be diplomatic with, and when to put a race into decline. With reckless players, or new players, you can experiment and simply enjoy yourself. It handles 2 players well, all the way to 6, and with the Reams expansion has modular boards and scenarios...

For the money, it's an "efficiency must" for any collection.

RATING: 5
A reasonably entertaining Euro, with all of the usual caveats. It's pretty with some nice mechanics and seems to be well balanced. The random pairings of race and special talent works well and is alternately interesting and amusing. Combat is highly abstracted, and as usual it's all about play balance rather than anything that resembles real combat. Still, it's reasonably enjoyable, in no small part due to the fact that it's a very acceptable length. I gave it a 6 immediately after a first play, but with some time to reflect, I'm going down to a 5. It's in the upper 5 range, higher than most other games of its type that I've played, but still with all the flaws and aritificialities that annoy me. I'd rather play this than, say, Age of Empires III. But I'd rather not play either.

Rather than being annoyed, I find it amusing that it keeps getting nominated as a wargame for the Golden Geeks. Squint how you may, this is not a wargame. Anyone who calls this a wargame is a person whose judgment is not to be trusted in important manners. This is a wargame the way beef is a vegetable. But so it goes. The admins have made it clear that they don't care, so we might as well point and laugh.

RATING: 6
American-style to the core, but offers sporadic fun to this Eurogamer.  Take control of a fantasy "race" and start placing your control markers on the board from outside-in; on subsequent turns you expand inwards.  The more spaces you control, the more resources you get.  When you get tired of a race (or use it up...), transfer to a different one.  Races have different powers, and the a/b combination of powers probably makes for interesting replayability.  Tactical considerations are helpful, in terms of how you play up your race's abilities in order to gain resources (coins).

RATING: 8.5
An excellent re-make of Vinci.  The terrain rules and combat rules are simplified (making the game easier to explain to new players), and the map has much more information on it.  

In this game players choose a race from a set of randomly drawn tiles (which all have special powers) and then take over terrain to score victory points.  The game has combat in it (you can attack other people's provinces), but the combat is simple (and mostly predictable) and easy to resolve.  Players can also go into "decline", meaning that they still score points for their current race, but then get to choose a new one to start up with.  So, even if you get beaten, you can come back again (and knowing when to decline is critical, as you can essentially get double points for a few rounds).

This is a great update of an already-great game.  The simplification of the rules helps, the better map helps (though I wish it were a bit less busy graphically), and the vastly-improved bits make the game much easier to play (since each race now has unique cardboard units, rather than colored cubes).  The victory points are secret (rather than open), which removes the king-maker problem of Vinci, and the game has a set number of turns (which removes the slightly-annoying "if they get 17 points then they'll end the game, but if I do this and this other person does that then they'll only get 15, and the game will go one more turn") reasoning in the original.

All in all this is a great game made even better (though it is now a bit simpler than the original, so some tactical options are lost).  But given that we can now play a 5 player game of this in 1 1/4 hours, I'd say the slightly simplification is worth it.

RATING: 5
Draft race tiles and conquer territory for most points.

Plays: 1.
Type: VP race = a game where you race to collect victory points (fastest/most).
Complexity: Medium.
# of players: See BGG.
Playing time: See BGG.
Player interaction: Conflict and Competition for scarce resources - races and territories.
Randomness: Low – tile drafting and dice with low impact.

Replayability: Pretty good. Every game will be different depending on the races available in the draft. It's also pretty quick, so why not play again?
Fun: Decent. The art is deliberatly cartoonish and the race-power combos can be somewhat hilarious. The presentation helps a lot to create a fun atmosphere. The actual gameplay isn't very much fun though, the best play is often fairly obvious and deterministic.
Memorability: Low, it’s a VP race that doesn’t create stories. But again, the presentation makes this better than most.

Thematic integration: Weak. The presentation is great in this regard. But it's a reimplementation of the (almost themeless) game Vinci. So we know that the "theme" is completely decoupled from the mechanisms. It's just lipstick on a pig.
Components: Good, the race tiles in particular are done in a distinctive style.

Who will like this: Casual gamers that don't notice the decoupling of theme and mechanisms. It's probably good as a gateway to games with conflict. The cartoonish style makes it hard for anyone to get serious about it.

RATING: 6
First and foremost, this is NOT, I repeat NOT a wargame except in only the slimmest sense so please don't introduce it as a wargame. There is no sense of military maneuvers or strategy and no sense of achievements of meaningful objectives so forget it. In fact, if you try and use military strategy its not likely to work.

Having said that, quite simply this is an area control game and it works on that level very well. I like the game and enjoyed playing it as the simplicity and constant change is fun. The tribes and powers are amusing. 

I do wonder if this game works better with an odd number of players and probably 5 which doesn't allow anyone to avoid getting hammered as happened in the 4- player game I played.

RATING: 8
The initial appeal of this game was seeing all the race/power combos.  After a while of playing this game, that's maybe lost a little bit (and only a little) of the excitement, but the game has firmly settled into a thoroughly enjoyable mental puzzle on how to be the most efficient with your race/power selection, how to best use them, do I make enemies, and if so, when, how do I time going into decline... lots of great decisions to be made.  I would also argue that the game is enjoyable at all player counts, though quite different.  2p is very much all about conflict, whereas higher player counts keep the player politics flowing.  Love this game all around.

RATING: 7.5
Nice, quick territory grabbing game based on 'Vinci'. It has elements of Britannia and 'History of the World' where new nations/ tribes rise and take over land held by older civilisations. The original element is that tribes each have their own attributes which are randomly allied to special powers. This gives each play a different feel as one time you may be playing with Flying Wizards or Wealthy Wizards or Pillaging Wizards etc. The other element of the game is picking the right time to have your current race go into decline before taking control of a new one. Overall - enjoyable and easy to learn - kids will pick it up easily and enjoy the slightly silly tribe types.

RATING: 7
in Smallworld geben sich die Spieler ordentlich auf die Omme, denn Jeder möchte gerne die meisten Gebiete, in dem kleinen Fantasyreich, für sich beanspruchen. Das bedeutet also, dass Smallworld ein reinrassiges Area Control Spiel ist, allerdings mit einem ziemlich collen Kniff: Die Rassen in Smallworld sind erstmal typisches Fantasyklischee. Da gibt es Elfen, Zwerge, Hobbits, Skelette, Riesen, Menschen, Wassermänner und noch einige mehr. Jedes Volk hat dabei eine einzigartige Fähigkeit. Die Orks z.B. sind ein sehr kriegerisches Volk und erhalten zusätzliche Siegpunkte, wenn sie Gebiete erobern, in denen sich bereits ein anderes Volk ausgebreitet hat. Aber diese Fähigkeiten machen Smallwordl noch nicht so besonders. Zusätzlich gibt es nämlich noch weitere Fähigkeiten, die durch modulare Pappteile, immer wieder neu und unterschiedlich, den einzelnen Völkern zugeordnet werden. Dann kann es in einem Spiel Smallworld z.B. Fliegende Skelette oder Heldenhafte Ghoule geben. Alles ist möglich und somit spielt sich jede Partie Smallwordl anders. Das täuscht ein bisschen darüber hinweg, dass die grundlegenden Mechaniken in Smallworld eher einfach sind. Unter´m Strich bleibt ein gutes und spaßiges Area-Control Spiel.

RATING: 6
Tighter, quicker and probably more accessible version of Vinci although some of that games good features were lost in translation (eg maintaining cohesion, not being able to have a declined and a new empire together, some of the terrain combat bonuses). The shorter length is the main improvement over Vinci, though, so its more likely to get played by those who need to play three games inside 4 hours. I suppose the theme is cute but I'm a bit over kiddy fantasy motifs. The hidden scores don't stop seem to stop leader bashing so the scores may as well be displayed on a track. Like Vinci, the combinations of powers and races will help this game's replayability. Despite my minor quibbles I'd happily play either Small World or Vinci.

Update: Small World is a bit too repetitive and oversimple and plays to long for what it is. Not a bad game but a bit dull.

RATING: 7
Крепкий середнячок. Полуабстрактный варгейм-контроль территорий. Идея довольно интересная: править нацией несколько ходов, потом бросить её и взять другую.
Основное, над чем надо думать — это какую расу взять, и когда ей прийти в упадок. Тактическое управление юнитами играет второстепенную роль, и иногда совсем очевидно, как ими "ходить". Союзы (а следовательно, общение) с другими игроками здесь редки, так как при развитии расы просто высчитывается максимальная выгода, а кого при этом приходится гасить — вторично.
Короче, от "варгейма" здесь осталось мало чего. Это следует иметь в виду, при выборе данной настолки.

RATING: 6.7
Edit 2015-06-22: Finalement, je me décide à essayer de vendre pour la première fois des jeux (une quinzaine). C'est le premier à être parti!

Décembre 2013: 8.2
Mars 2013: 7.7
Février 2014: 7.3

Une seule partie depuis mars 2013 et on dirait que le coeur y était et y est un peu moins pour ce jeu...

**

À mon avis, on ne peut pas considérer Small World comme étant un jeu "familial". Dernièrement, une dame s'est plaint à un commis d'un magasin de jeux de société de la complexité du jeu. Ce dernier répondit "pourtant, c'est un jeu assez simple", ce qui a probablement contribué à ce que la dame se trouve vraiment bête!

1) Les règles prennent plusieurs pages et ne peuvent être expliquées en moins de 10 minutes. Il en faut peut-être même une quinzaine...

2) C'est un jeu de conquête, d'attaque des autres joueurs. Ce n'est pas usuel chez le joueur occasionnel;

3) Outre la longueur de la règle, l'aide-mémoire est lui-même complexe! Grand carton (que l'on ne sait pas trop où poser sur la table étant donné que le jeu lui-même prend beaucoup d'espace) recto-verso. Un aide-mémoire aussi gros illustre la pluralité des règles du jeu.

4) Outre la longueur de la règle, il y a dès le départ six combinaisons de deux pouvoirs à assimiler. À cela s'ajoutent d'autres règles (combinaisons) au fur et à mesure que le jeu avance. Il s'agit, après avoir choisi une tribu, d'expliquer quelle nouvelle tribu devient disponible, ainsi que sa caractéristique. À la fin d'une partie, le nouveau joueur n'a probablement pas vu - encore moins expérimenté plusieurs tribus et combinaisons;

5) Outre l'aspect "attaque" qui n'est pas commun à tous joueurs, le concept de "déclin" et le timing pour l'exécuter n'est pas très tangible. Ne rendons-nous pas vulnérables les cases que l'on contrôle en perdant un tour complet pour passer en déclin?

6) Il y a une multitude de façons de gagner des points et des parties. Le contrôle de territoire par la tribu active, ainsi que celle en déclin, certaines cases donnant des bonus à certaines tribus, les points bonus des tribus rejetées par d'autres joueurs, etc.

7) La fin d'un tour permet au joueur de bien se repositionner défensivement, ce qui n'est pas automatique chez le joueur occasionnel;

8) Une grande quantité de matériel (de petite taille) et de détails sur la carte. Les pièces de tribus sont empilées afin de laisser visibles certaines informations de cases (les mines, par exemple), et la valeur défensive de chaque endroit se calcule par le nombre de pièces de carton sur cette case, ce qui n'est pas toujours visible au premier coup d'oeil;

9) La visibilité peut aussi poser problème concernant toutes les tuiles en déclin, qui se ressemblent les unes des autres, ainsi que le contour des cases variable d'une à l'autre - tout à fait différent d'un plateau quadrillé du style "échiquier".

10) Un grand nombre de choix d'attaques à chaque tour;

11) Ce qui motive chaque décision repose sur deux critères, forts différents l'un de l'autre: A) les bénéfices à court terme et à moyen terme, c'est-à-dire les points à récolter dans l'immédiat et plus tard dans le jeu, en fonction des forces et faiblesses de chaque camp. Ceci n'est pas simple à évaluer; B) le score actuel de chaque joueur, afin de travailler à obtenir des points aux dépends du meneur. Hors, les points étant cachés, il n'est pas si simple d'être certain de qui doit être la cible d'attaques;

12) Le bien-fondé d'une décision s'évalue selon son résultat. Hors, le résultat de toutes décisions dépend en partie de comment les adversaires réagissent. On peut prendre objectivement (avec l'expérience) une bonne décision mais le résultat peut être catastrophique si, par exemple, plusieurs adversaires nous attaquent simultanément suite à cette "bonne" décision prise. Il est donc long et difficile de se faire une expertise juste du jeu.

13) On peut terminer une partie de Small World en étant un peu fâché contre certaines décisions d'adversaires, qui parfois, nous attaquent "à tord" et laissent en paix les joueurs pourtant en avance dans les points ("king making").

Bref, je classe ce jeu comme ayant une difficulté "Medium", et je désapprouve qu'il soit classifié "familial". J'ai réussi à expliquer et à jouer une partie complète de mon jeu préféré, Tigris & Euphrates, avec mes parents, deux joueurs très, très, très occasionnels. Je n'ai pas réussi avec Small World! Certes, T&E est plus complexe. N'empêche, Small World n'a rien d'un jeu si simple lors des deux, trois premières parties...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I think it is better than Vinci. I like how there is a different map for the number of players. The powers and combinations are unbalanced, and a lot depends on if your opponents attack you. That said, it's a fun game, just don't try to take it too seriously.

RATING: 7
Mechanically a very straightforward game - you have one active race which invades its way across the land until too thinly spread to expand further, at which point they go into decline and you start with a new race.
The difficulty is that each race and power combo tweaks the fundamental rules, making each combo a unique ruleset in its own right.  Even a shortlist of 6 available combos still means 6 unique sets of rules to grasp before starting a new game.
Plenty of fun once the game is actually under way.

RATING: 8
As a longtime Vinci lover, I can't help but focus on the differences between this game and the one that inspired it.  I really dislike the reinforcement die, which adds an extra and significant luck element to the game, and I'm also not a fan of the fixed number of turns as opposed to Vinci's "magic number" endgame condition.  The scaled maps are a welcome change, though, and ultimately, it's a fine game on its own.  I'll play this almost anytime, but there's no way I'm trading away my copy of the superior Vinci, and I don't feel any compulsion to own both games.

RATING: 9
Am AMAZING update/remake of Vinci. I like nearly every change that was made (though having cool minis for each race would have been awesome... but I wouldn't want to spend $100 for the game so I understand!). My only issue - and this is based on a single play so take it with a grain of salt - is that the 5-player game seems one round too short. Another round would allow for the chance to decline two or three times rather than just once or twice. It's easy to fix if this turns out to be the case and is probably a matter of taste more than anything, so I can't even call this a flaw - just a preference. If you like Vinci, this is a must play, if not a must buy. If you didn't like Vinci, this may change your mind as it makes some much-needed improvements and the theme feels right and just makes sense.


***UPDATE*** While I still enjoy the game and probably always will, a few things have crept in after multiple plays that bug me (and these would apply to Vinci, as well). I like the hidden scoring, but the politics become a HUGE factor. Instead of just simply bashing the leader (which I also hate - the leader in points may not be in the position to maintain that lead and bashing him over the 2nd or 3rd place player is often a bad move), there's a constant, "Well so-and-so scored 10 points that one round so you need to attack him" or "I just scored 4 points so leave me alone." Hard feelings and bitching and moaning are WAY too prevalent and you really need to be careful about who you play this with because of this. I also feel that the last player has a HUGE disadvantage. Once you do your turn in the last round, you are golden... nobody can affect your score. So, given the choice of attacking a player whom you can't affect or taking points away from someone that hasn't gone yet, who do you think gets screwed? I really think a mechanism needs to be in place - maybe give each player a starting total of additional VPs based on turn order, i.e. start player gets 0, 2nd gets 1, etc.

RATING: 10
When I was younger I loved to play Risk with my brother and anyone else who had several hours to spare for a game.  Massing an army, conquering territories, and evaluating tactics was a lot of fun.  Unfortunately, Risk games can go on for a terribly long time, and even the mightiest armies can be defeated by unfortunate dice rolls.  I think Small World has a lot of what I love about Risk, but also fixes a lot of the problems too.  Each player takes turns selecting a race / power combination and receives a specific number of armies to enter battle.  On subsequent turns the player can either choose to continue conquering with that combination, or put them in decline so that they can choose a new combination.  The designers did a great job of adjusting the game based on the number of players.  There are different maps and turn counts for each number of players. The variety of races and powers are interesting and well balanced.  There are so many combinations that the game has quite a lot of replay value.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
In most area control games players' starting locations decide where their base of operations will remain for the rest of the game. In Small World players get the opportunity, in fact are compelled, to enter the board in new positions 2-3 times per game. This freshens the calcified territorial battling that occurs in other area control games and gives the game an almost generational feel.

The number of possible adjective-noun combinations of the  abilities and races makes every game different. The inclusion of multiple game boards, one for each number of players from 2-5, allows the game to scale well, although 5-player games tend to drag on.

The lush colors and humorous, cartoon-like art make the game is a visual treat.

Decided to cull Small World from my collection as I felt Blood Rage had similar mechanisms, but surpassed it in theme and execution.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Yes, I am a sucker for beautiful bits and fantasy-themed games, which this has both of.  This is also easily taught and the plethora of race/special ability combos is dizzying, making subsequent plays always fresh and interesting.

At the heart of the game you essentially are taking your tokens and conquering areas on the board by adding +2 tokens to whatever is on the area.  Blank area = 2 tokens to conquer, one enemy = 3 tokens to conquer, and so on.  Every turn you acquire a point for every area you conquer.

The great part of this game is that you choose a race and a special ability during the game that will give you bonuses for different areas to conquer, and different abilities to help you conquer them.

After many plays of this it has cooled off quite a bit.  I still enjoy it, but it is not jumping onto the table again for a bit.

RATING: 6.5
It's a sequel.  As an equal, can I get this through to you?  BGG hype-train of 2008, played in the middle of 2009.  Results?  A resounding 'meh'... but a "meh" I'll play with the right people.

I can't tell if it was the retheming of the game, or the game engine itself.  But after three games, I'm not finding a lot of deep appeal here.  The skirmishes are pretty straightforward, the numerous combinations aren't as numerous as you'd think, and the game plays predictably.  This game is more or less played out already, and that's a sad ROI on a $50 big box.  Expansions help with replayability in the same way that expansions help Dominion, at $10-15 a pop.  But even then, if you're paying attention to other players, it's obvious who you need to attack and when.

That said, for $10 on the iPad, it's a steal.  Also, I can get this game off the shelf and played with my sweetheart and other casual gamers, which is more than I can say for my copy of Twilight Struggle.

RATING: 5.2
[2010/01/13]

Played one practice/real game... with 5 plp... all 5 were new to the game... 2 of the people were new to me, and 1 of those 2 new people couldn't figure out the rules all game

i think this game relys on the phrases:"wow, what a cool combo", "let me see what that does" 

the strategy aspect is mostly based on the combinations that you get.... and i swear that my choice of combo was always outdone by the next persons choice.

It also seems like this game relys HEAVILY on opponents trying to figure out who's in the lead and attacking them... I'm not a fan of this game play necessity.. i think it allows some players to play with no regard for who's in the lead, and this can easily make the match-ups uneven skewing the entire competitive nature of the game...

in our game everyone played "for themselves"... and the result was a non-enjoyable game, where at the end, the guy we suspected to win, won... go figure... by the end of turn 4 i was wishing the game was over

could this be fun.... yeah... but i think it would take a really good crowd to make it work... i know that any game can be better if the players all know the rules and have played the game before... but this game needs more than that...


I'll won't refuse to play this...  and it is a "neat" game... but this is a strecth for a "Strategy" game... its more of a  "Strategy-ish" game


recommended for people who like pretty games

RATING: 6
It's an easy-to-learn (albeit with a few rule vagaries), easy-to-play fantasy battle game with more of a Euro approach to conflict, and certainly a Euro-style scoring system (in which coins rather than dead fantasy race pieces are added to achieve victory). 

I prefer fantasy battle games with more individual combat ratings and conflict (rather than simply awarding territory based on having sufficient pieces to claim unoccupied territory or more pieces than that of an opponent to occupy territory). 

Of course, "Small World" has the usual gorgeous production from Days of Wonder. 

Purchased in November 2010 at 40% off. Purchased expansion, "Be Not Afraid," in December 2010. Sold the base game and "Be Not Afraid" expansion in February of 2011. A good game, but nobody in my family was going to play it, and my personal taste in fantasy conflict games runs more toward war and elimination than bumping opponents' pieces off territories.

RATING: 8.45
A quite fun and simple area control game! There aren't many new gamers you could convince to play Risk! But, this is a great medium weight...and possible gateway game for newcomers! The artwork and design is awesome and humorous! This game is requested to play again and again...therefore it is seeing regular plays! Replay ability is nice, and the game will only benefit from an expansion...looking forward to it! New race variety's and special powers will only make the game more incredibly enjoyable! 2-player games are a little in your face; but, 3to 5 player games are awesome! 

Each player selects a race and connected special power! Bring your stack of race tokens onto the board! Try to win as many territories as you can each turn to win victory points! Decline your race at any time and start a new one! That's it, but so fun!

RATING: 7.5
心得:
還不錯玩的佔地遊戲 
APP 2 3 4 5人幾乎稱霸了
要贏的訣竅有幾點 
第一選到相對優勢現況的種族
第二不要被聯手針對
除了要想如何進攻，也要思考如何防守
當然運氣還是有點重要的
規則:
1.起始5分 六個種族可選
2.新種族要從邊緣進去，每回合開始就種族可回收任意數量然後繼續佔地，但是必須相連，如果全部回收，就必須重新從邊緣進入
3.衰落秏一回合，且必須輪到你就決定，即使有僵屍也不能使用
4.打敗死一隻 其它回手，該進攻方結束時可在分配防守

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A streamlined version of Vinci. I prefered the Vinci theme to fantasy, though it seems to be doing wonders for their sales. Hidden VP is a bad idea and the game is improved by playing it open. That way you attack the leader, not the perceived leader.

Ultimately (IMO) the gameplay is slow, has a lot of down time, few decisions and is thus boring.

Choosing a new civilisation is mainly a case of estimating the value of each civ on offer (i.e. counting), and each civ is worth almost exactly the same to each player, so there's no real strategic or tactical assymetry or gradients, only counting. 

The icing on the cake is the poor art (hard to pick out the dull greenish-brown counters from the brightly coloured board or from different brownish-green counters) and iconography, the player aids are required though oversized. This uphill battle makes Small World barely worth playing, and certainly a waste of valuable playing time if there are better games available. I didn't care for the 'comedy' artwork.

RATING: 7.4
This game is basically a quicker and arguably better version of Risk, (less random chance thanks to minimal die rolling). The game adds a bit of strategy to the standard war game thanks to the option of going "in decline" where you will still earn points for each space you occupy on the board, but they no longer can attack. One of the best things about this game for me personally is it has a TON of expansions. You can get so many more armies and abilities that you can assure yourself you'll never have the same game twice, which I always love. However, attacking other players is usually one of my least favorite aspect of a game, and this game is nothing but attacking. As far as attacking games go though, this is very fun and if you enjoy attacking games, you should check this out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very nice!

Rework of a very boring game (even if some very nice ideas were present) that should be used as an example in Successfully Reworking Games class!

Players control civilizations, each with its own unique set of powers, and then go to war to conquer the known world. After their civilization starts to lose steam and conquest becomes hard they can put in decline, pick another one and start over. Conquered regions are worth points and the player with the most points at the end of the 10 rounds is the winner.

The the special powers and the map maneuvering make for very interesting decisions in a relatively short playing time. It's really a fun game to play! 

I only own the iPad version (which is really awesome in every way), so I've only played it 2 player so far.

RATING: 8.5
Fun Factor: 8 (Very fun.)
Components: 9 (Solid, high quality components for the price.  GREAT art direction.) 
Theme: 7 (Kindof wacky.  The abstract fantasy is maybe not the greatest implementation, but it suffices and doesn't detract.)
Mechanics: 9 (The mechanics work for the game.)
Theme + Mechanics: 8
Replay Value: 9 (Vastly replayable.)
Scaling/Players: 10  (Scaling fantastic.  The multiple boards for various numbers of players wins.)

The design delivers in some way, and I can't fault it, but it just doesn't sometimes seem "gamey" enough for me...

RATING: 6
To become a great Smallworld player, you would have to analyze and chose your races in relation to the ones already on the board, compare them to those available and the one in use by others. The problem is that doing this slows the game a lot and the advantages are sometimes very minute, too obvious or without any incidence. Players will most likely gun for the most overpowered races and rely on luck for the rest since the differences between races do not have a major impact on the number to territories you can invade. Nice look, easy game for beginners and kids, but not much else. Hugely overrated for the mature gamer.

RATING: 8
I find the mechanics of the game pretty simple, and that is a very good thing. The trick to get this game right is to pick your races properly and timing when to send a race into decline. I would also argue that a player that knows the races/traits better is at an advantage, so I make a point to illustrate what my opinion is about the available races to new players. I also find this a very good game for people that are interested on board games, but are not ready for really long games. I bought a couple of the minor expansions, and I am considering getting the necromancer expansion, but I think there is really no need to get any of those as the base game has enough to keep everyone busy. All in all, this is not my first choice game when I want to play, but it is almost surely one of the first ones when I am aiming to entertain other people.

RATING: 6
Small World is to Vinci what Risk Godstorm is to Risk 2210.  Vinci and 2210 are fairly well balanced and have a more serious approach. Small World and Godstorm, while employing similar systems to their parent, have far more chaos and wildly different powers. Radical alterations of the board from turn to turn vrs the attrition-like approach. Both are good games (Small World and Godstorm) but not the same level as their respective parents. 

Small World is the beer and pretzels version of Vinci. And the more beer, the better the game.

In many ways the chaos that permeates the game reminds me of Cosmic Encounter. I enjoy playing these types of games but they are not for a serious gamer.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Area control game where you lay tiles instead of mobile troops. Funny, and cute. Very low stress for an area control game. 
In essence, you have a randomly paired race and special power which determines both your abilities and the number of tokens you get. You place the tokens on the board regions as effectively as you can and then hope nobody attacks your position. If you are attacked, you might chose to swap to a new race, if not you might chose to sit, or try to take more areas with what you have left.

The key to the game is knowing when to let go, but truthfully there are few hard decisions to make from turn to turn.

Hunting for the race tokens in the insert and looking up the abilities in the booklets can get tiresome.

:star: Art and components
:nostar: Innovative mechanics
:star: Handles 5 or more players
:star: Good with min or max players
:star: Low time between turns
:nostar: Comfortable complexity
:star: Re-playability
:star::nostar::nostar: Enjoyment

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Small World is a somewhat entertaining Euro-style wargame/area control hybrid with a novel theme and interesting character/skill permutations.  All of that stuff sounds great to most gamers...but for some reason it just doesn't click with me.  It isn't that the game isn't fun, it's that it isn't ENOUGH fun.  Some of the classes are monstrously overpowered (Sorcerers, I'm looking at you), and screw-your-neighbor is absolutely essential to win the game.  
This much conflict starts to feel personal for a lot of players.  Me?  I don't mind being targeted, but there is no way to develop a different strategy when you have to keep your current race active for two more turns and then lose an entire turn when you go into decline...I just don't understand why modern designers would put such a dated mechanic in the game.  With AP players and some bad timing, you can literally sit and watch other people play for twenty minutes before the turn where you can actually do something comes around.  
All that aside, the game is popular.  But so what?  It doesn't make it good. Meh for me.

My one gripe is that it's a "beat on the leader game," but victory points are hidden, so it becomes a "beat on the perceived leader," game.  I've played in games where people were clearly beating on the wrong person, which can be blamed on the players being bad at estimation, but still, not so fun.  This can be solved with a house rule, "add a victory point track," if everyone is willing.

Another solution is to play with two, in which case this doesn't matter. The two-player game is my favorite version of this.

RATING: 7
Small World follows a similar objective to Risk, mainly take over the world. It improves upon Risk in many ways though. There is less luck involved as you don't roll dice to take over other factions territory. Most attacking and defending is decided by the sheer number of pieces you are willing to use to take or defend each individual space. There is some die rolling involved toward the end of turns when you can roll to determine if you will receive one, two or three reinforcement units. 

The mixing and matching of different factions and special abilities also leads to a lot more interested and dynamic playthroughs. Although even after about ten games I feel like I have seen many of the different combinations and there is far less diversity than I originally thought. 

Small World can become stale after playing it repetitively in a short time period, but I'm almost always down to play it, especially after its been a while since the last time. It's definitely a must have standard.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
I really thought I would hate this game.  But it does have some merit.  The vast number of combinations among the various units is really cool.

At the beginning of the game a set of armies (with their own special powers) is combined with an additional special power.  Player can choose which army/special power combo to take.

Basically you get a multiplayer conquest game where players need to abandon their gains and start over at the right time.  They do this by letting their existing army go in to decline and choosing a new army to fight with.  Armies in decline continue to earn the controlling player points for territory held but can no longer do anything.

The available armies are there for everyone to see.  The various special player powers add a constantly changing set of unique armies whose powers need to be taken in to consideration.

The art is terrible.  So bad that its hard to look at the pictures of some of the armies.  The last thing I want to see is a bunch of slobbering dwarfs in front of me.  The board is also garishly cartoonish.  It's confusing and annoying to look at.  If you want to draw people (especially kids whom the art seems to be aimed at) into a game like this you need to make it "cool" not "dorky".

Additionally the game is horrifically fiddly.  Each of the many armies has a set of chits.  Many of the special powers also come with chits and markers of various kinds.  Everyone needs a full size cheat sheet to explain all the special powers.  Two different boards printed on both sides for a total of four maps are included.  A different map is used for each of the player configurations (2 to 5 players).

In the end we have a fun quick light conquest game with high quality, if terribly ugly, production.

RATING: 6
Risk meets D&D Monster Manual. With over 10 different types of civilizations that you can place to gain strategic footholds on the board - each civ. has unique aspects to them. The game feels new and exciting with a bunch of possibilities, but once the honeymoon phase is over you start to realize that each civ. really only plays a certain way and there is not much outside of how they operate that Small World offers.

That is not to say that it is boring. Small World has replay value in sheer combinations of civs. you play, but it does not have nearly as much options in gameplay that it lends itself to have.

It is less boring than Risk though, and can make those who normally hate those strategy area control games reconsider. Definitely a gateway. It has just enough different flavor and fantasy elements to draw wide appeal.

RATING: 5
[b]RO[/b]: [i]12/17/2016[/i]

An early acquisition in my honeymoon phase with the hobby. I've always felt like Small World should have gotten more love from my group, but the sad fact is: nobody ever wants to play it. Descended from the game Vinci (which I have never played) it has you randomly pairing races with powers for interesting, and often hilarious, combinations. I've always felt like the rising and declining of the various races fells very restrictive and I think the others in my group feel the same way. But this is a good game if you're looking for a game [i]similar[/i] to Risk, but marginally more interesting, slightly less luck-y, and a lot more lighthearted in tone.

RATING: 6
The aspect of Small World that I find most enjoyable is the combining of different races with different special abilities.  It's so exciting to sit in suspense and wonder if you are going to get to pick the combo that you think is cool.  Each combo has advantages and fun ways to play, so it makes the game replayable.  I also like the mostly diceless combat system.  

But overall, it's not as exciting as many other games because I don't get thrilled with direct conflict games. So while the components are pretty and the game is quick playing and enjoyable, Small World is not a game that I'd want to always play.

RATING: 6.75
Played twice with 3 players.  

I am conflicted on this game.  First, what I like about Smallworld.  I enjoy the theme, and I feel the random combination of race+modifier is a neat idea. Also, it plays quickly which is a plus without much downtime between turns.  The components and board(s) are high quality and nice to look at.

My problem with Smallworld is that it seems that the only major decision to be made is when to put your race into decline and pick a new one.  The attacking seems pretty obvious - attack until you run out of tokens.  Defending seems nearly impossible if a race has Dragon Master, or flying, etc.  Some race/ability combos are so much better than others that if you are the unlucky person to get the weak combo you are toast - as there seems to be no way to use tactics typically.

Regardless of my percieved flaws, I would play it again - but its not a game I would purchase or push to play.

RATING: 6
We were fortunate enough to be able to borrow this game from a friend.  We played through once and IMMEDIATELY played it again - then went out and purchased it.  There are so many great and original concepts in this game.

The replay value of this game is VERY high.  With the number of combinations for type and skill vs type and skill for every player...you could probably play this game every day for the rest of your life and still not experience every combo.  So cool!

We have played a few games with 5 people and I wouldn't recommend it.  With 5 players there is just too much down time.

We've since worn out on this game and have traded it away.  I still enjoy it and would have hung onto it had there not been another person in our play group that has it.  It is a fun game.
