RATING: 10
This game is a blast.  I love seeing what combinations of Races and Powers come up so it's a little different every time you play.  It's easy to learn and has a good amount of strategy in Power/Race combos and where the optimal place to attack is.

Rick's Rules of Thumb:
1 - Always* take Ghouls if they come up early game.
2 - Always* take Merchant.
3 - More tokens are better, but make sure you are scoring plenty of coins each turn - that's what matters.
4 - Going in decline earlier than you should have is always* better than later than you should have.

*OK, maybe not 'always' but 'most of the time.'

RATING: 5
I do not like about this game that the map is uniform. By  that I mean that there is no clustering of any terrain types or special symbols. This removal of spatial elements (especially in combination with the ability to withdraw your race and enter the map from a different side) destroys most of the fun I expect from a light, tactical war game. Even though the rules are not complicated, this game is still hard to bring to table with new players, since there so many special abilities to explain.

Small world is a fairly simple game. Players purchase races with which they try to occupy areas. The more areas a player occupies the more points they score. Races are made up with a combination of two special powers that change from game to game. Some of these make conquering areas easier, some score victory points. At any time players can abandon their present race and get a new one.
The whole thing is quite clever, and provides a clear optimisation challenge (its firmly in the Eurogame mould except for its much heavier stomp the other players option). However, it has one huge flaw, the rules are badly written. Not the core rules, no, but the special rules for each race are often ambiguous and unclear.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

3 as a result, especially when one changes powers and basically forfeits any activity that turn there are long periods of player downtime and boredom.

RATING: 9.5
We first played the Underground version of Small World with our friends Kieth and Conney. 

I liked it a lot- I compare it to a mix between Risk and Magic The Gathering, simplified and stylized for everyone.

Huge fan of simplistic games here, especially when they can give way to multiple win paths and re-playablility like Small World does.

We bought the base version, this one, and can't stop playing it. Small World is a Great game. Here is what I like:

1) I can teach this game to anyone in about 2 minutes. No need for rules, just start playing and everyone can start playing on their turn. Do a 'fake game' run through for a round or 2, then poof! everyone knows how to play.

2) The game boards and pieces are super high quality, just awesome. Amazing artwork. Fun too.

3) Simple to learn, hard to master. Lots of re-playability.

4) 4 game boards. The first has a 2-player and 3-player side, then 2nd has a 4-player and 5-player side. This, above all else, wins me over to Small World. It is so important to have game balance AND multiple player variations. 

5) Each game is much different than the one before.

6) Accessible to hard core board/card gamers and casual monopoly/rummy player types too. All ages.

What I don't like:

1) Sometimes species-ability combos are overpowered. Commando on turn 1. Spirit Ghouls in the hands of an experienced player. House rules take care of both of these right away. 

2) Sometimes combos are difficult to figure out. There are 3 pages or errata. This is a problem, if you don't do the work. We read up, printed errata, and learned them all. Once one player knows the quirks, they can help others learn the correct rules and combos.

3) The Biggie. While the components are just the best, and the box has slots for all of them, which is a huge bonus in my book, there is one problem. The tray that holds the species units, is a monster. It is not labeled, and often the squares get stuck or wont come out without a lot of diddling around.

We used sticker labels to keep everything sorted out, it works well enough. I have seen newer editions of Small World that appear to have resolved this issue. However:

Whoever thought that a TOP-LOADING tray was a good idea for SIDE LOADING pieces was a moron. Why is this tray not designed like sugar-packet trays at restaurants? You know- with the pieces each popping out by pulling from the front- with a sort of cut-out slot in the front of each tray? 

That would have been a simple fix, just changing the plastic mold for the tray, and would save us a lot of time every game. It was the most disappointing part of buying Small World. 

**
The first two negatives are mechanic things that are resolved with a lot of play-time under your belt. The 3rd, the tray, is a permanent problem. Stupid of them to build it that way, just stupid.

4) Thats it. I have no other negative concerns. This game is top notch. If it was not for the tray-stuff, this game would get a 10 hands down.

I can't give a game a 10 with such a pain-in-the-kisser kind of physical design mistake. Ignoring that, this is one of my favorite games ever. Mindy loves it too, and everyone we play it with has a good time. 9 point five.

RATING: 7
Based on one 3-player game.  My one big complaint about 'Vinci' is that the beginning, middle, and end game all feel identical, which is a bad thing for a 2-hr game.  'Small World' addresses the issue by shortening the playing time.  I think the duration of the game is now perfect for what it offers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Pandering, bash-the-leader, nonsense. Don't bother thinking of a path to victory; this game will dicate it for you. Due to predetermined ability-pairings, your (at times, imbalanced) strength in Small World is attained with no discernible effort, and thus your strategy is scripted. "The quietest player wins" is what someone quipped about this game. Too true. I was left alone, avoided conflict when I could (half my game spent 'Diplomatic') and won with over 90 points. This was my first play, in a group of experienced gamers that were too busy bashing each others' heads in to notice.

It's almost comical how well-received this is, as I can think of numerous entry-level area majority and/or area control games that surpass it by various degrees: First and foremost, Olympos (Keyaert's later title), classics like San Marco, Web of Power, and El Grande, niche titles like Quebec, and the more modern and ultimately more streamlined, Ethnos. These aren't all ace games, though a select few are stellar, but they are certainly stronger alternatives to this snoozefest.

RATING: 8.2
Really streamlined, and simple, wargame. Easy to teach and play. The complexity of the game comes from the race and special power combos. It's disappointing that some of the strategy elements from Vinci are gone, such as the rule of cohesion and the changed dynamic of mountains and forests. Simplifying the game probably makes it play quicker, but I think a lot of the quicker play time comes from the set number of turns in the game. Changing to a set number of turns is a huge, welcome change over Vinci, as the end game was one of the things I disliked the most. The game is perhaps too streamlined now, but it is still a lot of fun, definitely more accessible, and can play in a much shorter timeframe.

RATING: 7
I don't have a really strong opinion on the Vinci vs. Small World question.  Small World was certainly fun, but I didn't think hidden score was any great improvement, nor did I think having separate race tokens (as opposed to player tokens in easy-to-distinguish colors) helped.  I also think they oversimplified things just a bit.  Vinci's innate defensive bonus for mountains was kept, so why not forest?  And why negate much of the interest of mountains by (mostly) getting rid of the advantage of attacking out of them?  That was the balance that made up for the extra difficulty in getting into them!

All in all, it's fun because it's a fun system, but I wouldn't insist on playing either version.

RATING: 7
area control game that plays kinda like a war game. not much randomness, although lucky starts can happen. crazy combos pop up in the race/power market, but they're somewhat mitigated by the breadcrumb trail of victory points a player has to leave behind to take one. i love the agony of deciding when to go into decline and how hard it is to miss a turn, although everyone will encounter that at least once (probably twice!) during the game. 5-player can feel a little chaotic and 2-player can feel a lot like a knife fight (why waste time on neutral guy when you can just stomp all over your opponent? it's mean and it's nasty and sadly it's effective), but the differently balanced maps for each player count really help to fit the situation. very fun game! quick to teach, despite all those many powers. not sure why this game gets so much hate, unless it's from the direct conflict vibe. yeah, that should bug me, but i'm often having too much fun to take it personally!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
[color=#CC0000]


    [i]"I like Chicken McNuggets."


        Of course you do. Everyone does. Chicken McNuggets were designed by a committee whose goal was to create a food considered "good enough" by a maximal number of Americans. Small World went through the same process.

            S.
[/i]










Just not a lot of decision-making here.  The game plays itself very nicely for the most part, occasionally asking you for a bit of input.

Decisions do occur when it's time to decline, and there was some interest there for me on a couple of occasions.  That doesn't happen very often though -- the bulk of the game is GACMITS and I didn't find it compelling.  It's just not a game that requires very much thought.  The game plays itself.

Very pretty package though.  Days of Wonder sure knows how to fill a box.  I understand that this game is geared towards the family market, and I should consider it in that light -- it's an intentionally soft play.  But soft doesn't have to mean uninspiring, and I think that's happened on this one.  For kids I think some of Days of Wonder's other titles would be a far better choice - Pirates Cove, Ticket to Ride or Memoir '44 all come to mind, largely because their theme has some edge to it and you can put your own personality into the play.  Small World lacks that.  You can leave the table for a bit and have other people take your turn for you without it mattering very much.

[b][u]Here's the real disappointment -- there's the remains of a game here that got stomped on.  [/u]

If you could eliminate multiples of an opponent's pieces in a territory you would have some level of tactical action in the game.  You'd have to worry about defense, and position, and consolidation.  Territory would have meaning.

Or, if you could press your luck with that cool six-sider on [u]every[/u] advance it would make for a press-your-luck element that would really require you to make tough decisions and live with the consequences.  You'd have to measure your options carefully, splitting troops with care, not boxing yourself in -- you'd own your game.  Even the one special ability that allows you to use that die each time offers it [u]prior[/u] to the attack decision (and the rule is carefully written to indicate that, as if someone did it the other way during playtest and mistakenly stumbled across too much joy.)

[i]Alas, none of that is the case.  What remains is a very simple, very tepid game, a slice of milquetoast that consumes itself while you watch.  I'm very surprised it's getting the attention that it does.[/i]
[/b]
[/color]

RATING: 5
I love the concept of this game -- a tribe sweeps through an area and is slowly picked apart before making way for a new tribe. The game is about timing -- should I pull out this turn or make a final push? I also really like the different powers and how they can be combined in various ways. The box insert is also probably the best I've seen.

As it turns out the gameplay is pretty dull and mechanical. You're usually just going for the hills or the swamp or whatever. The biggest choices you have to make are whether you want to go in decline and which new tribe to choose, but these choices are mechanical too as you're just counting off potential points. I love maths but this is just tedious for me.

The saving grace of this game is the app which speeds everything up, but I still don't often feel like playing it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Visual Appeal: (5)
I really like the unique style of the creatures in this game. The artist presents some of the usual tropes in quirky ways that really attract gamers from the moment they see the box. The creatures/powers fit together nicely.

Components: (4)
This is great component quality overall. There are so many little chips and all of them are nicely organized in the convenient custom box insert. I don't like how hard it is to get them out sometimes, so I hot glued the end of a ribbon in each section. If you place the chips on top of the ribbon, you can simply pull it and they'll all pop out. The board is nice looking, double-sided, and the regions are easy to see.

Theme: (5)
I've heard that this is a re-working of an older title called "Vinci". I don't know enough to compare the theme because I haven't played it. I can say though that the theme works just fine here. The simulation of empires rising and falling over time is nicely done with the in-decline mechanism. All of the creatures and powers are very flavorful and work just like you'd expect them to with the theme. Berserk creatures have random attack bonuses, Halflings have hidey-holes, and Trolls have caves. None of them really feel out of place or broken.

Learning: (4)
The main point in teaching this game is really just to make sure the players understand how "in-decline" scoring works. Everything else is basic math! I have not experienced anyone having trouble learning the game. From what I recall, the rules are fairly succinct and clear. They also provide a great full description of all the creatures and powers.

Gameplay: (5)
There is backstabbing galore in this game. As soon as you go into decline, you can expect players to jump all over you like a dog on a bone. One of my favorite things to do is to convince people that another player is a threat. Since VPs are hidden until the end of the game, a few good rounds will make you a quick target to anyone not wise enough to keep score in their head. It is a huge benefit to know which power combos are actually powerful and which ones will burnout quickly.

Overall Fun: (5)
This is one of my favorite games and I've played it to death. The expansions add more variety, without changing the basic game, and that's  a good thing. This is not a game that gets strength from complexity. I think it's a great game and most of my friends agree. The ones who wanted more were usually looking for something like a strategic area control game.

Fun game that is easy to learn. Like to play with newer gamers.

RATING: 8
Some great pros on this one: nice art and components, and extremely easy to teach due to very simple rules make it a perfect game to introduce to non-gamers. The problem with this game is the way the winner is decided. The quiet player is most of the time the winner. And lets admit it, when you suffered a genocide from player A, it is difficult to put logic over revenge and go for player B. And if you do, you will most probably manage to have both players A and B ravaging you.
Nevertheless, if people in you gaming party aim for fun, then go for it! Small world will not let you down. If they are competitive and play to win, this game could be a trouble.

RATING: 6
Can't help but compare it to Vinci, and the comparison isn't all good, nor all bad. I'm not really into the fantasy theme and the graphic design hurts my eyes, but I do like the addition of the attack die and all the little expansions they've developed for the game. Hidden points and fixed rounds you can easily implement in Vinci should you choose - I've played Vinci with and without these tweaks for years. When all is said and done though the two games are very similar. It'll come down to a preference in theme and appearance for many gamers. I find the decline tokens in Small World hard to distinguish and prefer the playing pieces and board of Vinci. Theme wise I find it easier to comprehend what each civilization tile does in Vinci than races in Small World. I'm more than happy to play either game, but I prefer Vinci.

The simplicity, the combination of powers and choices make both Vinci and this the wonderful games they are. You have to look ahead and choose what combination will work best for you, where to bring it onto the board, how thinly you want to spread yourself out and defend versus how many victory points you want, and then when to go into decline. It's simply fun.

With hidden victory points it's the player who through one method or another manages to be hit the least will win the game. It's actually easy enough to keep a running count of the points scores, should you be taking it seriously, but who's doing that!? I find hidden points turns the game into a hit the perceived leader exercise instead of a hit the actual leader exercise. Players who like to table talk and con others will enjoy the hidden points. Who cares: Small World is not a deep strategy game, but rather gaming mostly for the social experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Small World corrects a number of issues with Vinci, streamlines the rules, and snazzes up the theme and art.

The goal is gold! (Or victory points. They're one and the same.) You get gold by successfully managing a series of civilization through their rise and decline.

Each player starts with one civilization, expanding it across the map. At the end of your turn you gain one gold for each territory controlled by your civ. Each civilization is unique and may give you bonus gold for controlling certain areas, or make it easier to conquer certain territories. At some point, you may put your active civ into decline. A declined civilization loses its extra units, most of its special abilities, and can no longer expand, but it can still give you gold every turn.

You may only have one civ in decline and one active. Knowing when to decline is one of the big game decisions you make.  Each civilization is a complement of two tiles: a race and some characteristic. For example, Flying (characteristic) Dwarves (race) get +1 gold for controlling areas with mines, and can expand into any territory, not just adjacent ones. The combination of tiles also grants a starting number of civ tokens with which to expand. Generally, these tokens cannot be replaced if lost through combat. This accumulated attrition is what leads to your decision to decline.

You chose your next civilization from a queue of five. The civ tiles are randomly paired. If you decide not to pick from the top of the queue, you must put one gold on each civ you skip. The player who takes a civ also claims any gold on top of it. This provides a nice balancing mechanism as some combinations are clearly more powerful than others.

The game ends after a preset number of turns. Both the map size, and the number of turns, are dictated by and scaled to the number of players.

A great Civ game that can be played in about two hours.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Small World has all the hallmarks of an Ameritrash classic -- pretty bits, variable player powers, aggressive territorial in-your-face conflict, a dash of pick-on-the-leader. The one thing from the genre that it's missing is the random element that allows one to gamble and hoot and holler and upset everyone's plans -- fighting is very deterministic, for the most part (although the addition of a last-gasp Reinforcement die does help with this a bit). Some will find the lack of Lady Luck to make the mix unpalatable -- not so for myself, but I certainly don't begrudge anyone who misses it.

Our five player game went 90-120 minutes and moved along at a pretty good pace. Plus, we had Pillaging Amazons, Diplomat Skeletons, and Dragonmaster Halflings. That's a Tuesday evening well spent, in my book. Scores were reasonably close despite groanings from certain corners of the table -- the spread was 90-75, I believe, making every victory "coin" spent on choosing a race valuable.

By and large I found Small World to not be a significant departure from its prior edition, Vinci. There are plenty of small tweaks, sure, and none that I could identify as hurting the design, but small tweaks they remain.

RATING: 7
I love these reworkings of old classics that make the game more balanced, more playable, more fun and more presentable. 

Small World is better than Vinci in many ways. I like the hidden-VP scoring, as you focus more on who's strong on the board (and who potentially will be strong) than who really is in front. The fixed game ending (10 rounds) makes it less chaotic and random to make decisions near the end of the game, and also gives players who are behind something to work for (maximizing their score by the 10th round). Also, it makes it more conducive to newbies, because they can focus on having fun, since they don't realize you're actually quashing them by 30 points until the end of the game, at which point they're ready to move on and conclude this is a fun game anyway. The player scaling is great with the maps. Vinci should have been designed for 2-5, like Small World is, since having many players just creates downtime. The reinforcement die is excellent because it mitigates one of the worst aspects of Vinci downtime: when somebody places all his tokens, finds he's 1 short of his plan, then decides to do everything completely different to see if he can do it in a different way, then tries again, then...

And I haven't even touched on the components. The zany, beautiful artwork means this game is usually filled full of laughter, which really helps to mitigate the hurt feelings that can come from the intrinsic nastiness of the Vinci/Small World system. My games of Vinci have been quiet, tense and "DAMN YOU!", whereas I don't feel that bad when I'm attacked in Small World. I'm too busy wondering what happened to my lone Halfling with the Flying Sorcerer (alien abduction + clone...ouch).

Small World has fewer combinations than Vinci, but I like that these combinations have more thought put into them through the stratification of race and power, as you sometimes get some weird civilizations in Vinci. It's also nice to see familiar faces in the races every game. What this takes away from the strategy space, Small World also adds. The 10-turn game length means it's actually viable to just decline once in the game, and try to use a long-lasting 2nd combo for the entire game. There are tiles that actually do this in Small World, whereas there was only one in Vinci.

90 minutes of playtime full of laughter, solid mechanisms. And this game is enjoyable by newbies and experienced players alike. 

The downside is that there is significant downtime, especially among score-optimizing players. This can be mitigated by playing with fewer players. The deterministic combat also means this game is more abstract strategy than Euro/War, and is best with 2 or 3.

4+3
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Area control game with variable powers and abilites set in a fantasy world.

Pro: Components are great (as expected for a Days of Wonder). Variety in the combinations of Racial Powers and Special Abilities is great, and makes for ridiculously high replay value. Very simple mechanics, but still room for lots of strategy. Minimal luck factor.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I'm already a fan (and owner) of Vinci who does not get to play it near as often as he would like.  Needless to say, there has been very little interest on my part in picking up a copy of Small World.  Despite that, I was interested in giving a whirl if the opportunity to present itself arose.

The best place to start seems to be the near legendary Days of Wonder production values.  Everything about the game, from the board to the counters to the storage tray, is top notch.  Just as would be expect.  However, as others have noticed, once game play starts, the board becomes a chaotic mess.  This is in stark contrast to the spartan and (to me) more utilitarian components of Vinci.  There was also some problem with the gray wash of the declining side of counters, particularly when looking at them from across the table.  For the most part, we were able to work with this.

As for the changes, I'm not overly enthused.  The hidden VP's I can take or leave.  I'm not really fond of how the races and abilities come back into the game once they leave.  While separating the races and abilities seems to work well enough, I prefer the method used in Vinci.  I don't feel like the 8 turn limit really works for five players.  It seems to place too much of a constraint on the game.  Granted, I think that forces you to be a little more careful about your timing as you are playing against a very hard wall.

My biggest gripe is the presence of a somewhat reverse kingmaker scenario.  What I mean is that in the final round, all other things being equal, it is much more to your benefit to attack the people that follow you in turn order as they are the only ones whose score you can affect.  This seems to give a pretty significant afvantage to those who go first.  In addition, there seems to be an advantage in the first turn of the game as well which falls to the first player as they get the best pickings for location.  These two things together seem to give too much of an advantage to the first player.  By its nature, there should be a similar problem in Vinci.  However, no one has ever commented on it like seems to happen with Small World.  I suspect that it substantially related to the strict turn limit.

Overall, though, there is nothing terribly wrong with the game.  I would play again if asked.  However, I would certainly prefer to play Vinci, so the rating on this one will be a little less.  Given that I don't play Vinci enough as it is, none of the changes are interesting enough for me to obtain my own copy.  It is, however, nice to see the system once more easily available.  Thank you Days of Wonder. [05/23/2009]

RATING: 7
Small World -- Played once; four-player.

I've never cared for war games.  I can think of several reasons:
• Games are my escape from unpleasant realities (so war as a game theme fails for me -- I just don't enjoy the idea)
• I don't care for direct conflict.  I much prefer games where pursuing the goal does not involve player elimination, or even elimination of the players' tokens.
• I find it disheartening to play out a game when I've deployed my troops poorly, and now it's just a matter of making the motions until someone mercifully finishes off my remaining pieces.
• I've just never been good at war games.  (And while I usually enjoy games regardless of whether I win or lose, it's hard to enjoy a genre in which you feel hopelessly under-equipped intellectually.)

Small World is a war game even I can enjoy.  The fantasy theme ameliorates the associations with real war.  The conflict doesn't result in real elimination, since a player can just bring in a new race.  The ability to begin anew addresses my issue of disheartenment with playing out a position which has become unfun (if not untenable).  And while Small World [i]is[/i] strategic, its depth of strategy is within my range.

Furthermore, I happen to enjoy the lighthearted fantasy theme. The mix of racial abilities and special powers makes for fun choices when selecting races and provides varied gameplay over time.

RATING: 7
Played once (with a couple of expansions) with 6P. Arguably the best thing in this cute game is the ability to put your race into decline. Given that it is a practically mandatory action to perform at least once throughout the game, choosing when to do so becomes a skill of careful timing and positioning. Having to deconstruct something that you've gradually built up is an amazingly organic concept which isn't seen much in other games, so Small World gets props for that too. The second best thing is the ingenious mix-and-match system of abilities and races, which uses humourous tropes and opens the game up to endless possibilities (of expansions, that is).

It is strange then that Small World doesn't quite click with me. The combat system is too calculative and sterile for my liking, and at odds with the zany artwork. My ideal combat-based game is an all-out dice-brawl, not just an abstract game with a die roll at the end as a kicker. And while the artwork looks great on individual components, the riot of colours once the game is in motion makes it difficult to read the board situation at a glance. Lastly, some combinations of races are much better than others. This is obviously a part of the game, but luck sometimes leaves you with subpar combinations.

RATING: 3
The game sounds like a good idea, but ultimately is boring and repetitive. Best before 5 plays. The only meaningful decision in the game is when to go into decline and what race to pick, but this only happens maybe three times in the game. Conquest practically goes without saying. As in most eurogames, victory is determined by the discretion of the other players, i.e. try to always only receive the second most points!

This game is probably the only one where the die bugs me. Every turn you can practically risk getting -1 or +1 VP. Distributed amongst several turns, this can make a big difference, especially if you are able to hold for long a space you won with the roll of the die.

The graphics are nice though.

I'd rather try VINCI one day.

RATING: 4
Right off the bat this feels less abstract than Vinci, which is a good thing.  It is a much warmer design.  Sadly, while some of the changes are welcome (the new powers are fun, and the die is entertaining), most of the changes are, I think, a detriment to the game.  

The game is drastically shortened, so you don't get to see any real rise and fall.  The game plays so quickly that you can only take on two or three civs.  There is no clawing your way back into the game.  You just see what you can do with little, then add up the points at the end.  

I also hate the hidden points.  I thought I'd be a fan, but the system is set up to attack the leader, so people now gang up to attack the perceived leader rather than the likely real leader. So, the problem isn't gone rather made less efficient.

Still, it is an alright game.  I'll play it, but I'd rather play the original.

UPDATE: The more I play this the less I like it.  I think that attacking the perceived leader issue is too much of an irritant for me to enjoy.  I also have an issue with the last turn as turn order grants huge disadvantages to the players moving last as everyone just pisses down the line attacking those that are still going to score.  This could be solved by having one last scoring again after the final round.  

With the exception of the die, every change from the original game is inferior.

RATING: 6
While the race & special power are interesting (most interesting part of the game I would say), the actual game play feels somewhat lacking. It felt like the decision of where to attack was obvious most of the time for each player given their race and special power. It's also very obvious when is the best time to decline a race. That means the most interesting and important part of this game comes to down which race to pick when one goes into decline, and you only get to do that two or three times in a 5p game, which could take a while between turns. I probably won't reject an invite to play this game, but will not suggest playing it.

RATING: 7.5
This is a super fun area control game.  It's not just the game play mechanics that are fun, but the theme itself, along with the artwork, really add to it.

Though seemingly simple, the game has some depth. And though the game has some randomness (the races and powers get coupled up randomly each game), this did not detract from the game at all, even for my group of friends who really appreciate strategy games (with little or no chance factor).

The randomness of the races each game mixed with the unpredictability of each player really give this game some lasting appeal.

RATING: 6
I found the first few games of Small World boring. Every round felt the same. Spread your guys out until most of them are dead and then go into decline. 

BUT, after playing with a group who knew how to play well I fell in love with the game. The strategy comes in when you are choosing your races. Do you start with a race that  can spread out quickly and then go in decline? Or do you start with a race that can stay fortified while in decline and then try to hold two races the whole game? 

I really would like to get some of the expansions.

RATING: 6.5
1 play, 4er. Sadly, I was a bit disappointed. 

It's a simplified, streamlined, quickened Vinci, but it's still Vinci. Major improvements: faster play, hidden (but trackable) scoring, defined game length (9 or 10 rounds), more limited attribute combinations (always a race characteristic and something else). On the other hand, there is hidden scoring (why shouldn't you beat up on the leader?), and the graphic presentation was terrible: too colorful, too much artwork, too busy -- hard to easily see what's happening on the board. And the game seemed to end almost too quickly! I'll certainly play it again, but right now I think I prefer Vinci.

RATING: 9
(Thanks 2009 BGG Secret Santa!)

Very interesting game.  It's relatively light, but there's lots of tough decisions and the flavour just oozes... it's hard not to get sucked in.  

Sure, sometimes the race/ability combos that come up for you kinda suck, but it's still fun trying to make lemonade out of the lemons.

Excellent stuff.

Edit 05/27/09: After 4 plays, I'm beginning to think the luck of the dice might result in too much of a point discrepency... in a game solely determined by VPs rather than actual territory, the spreads can be massive.

Edit 12/30/09:  16 plays... yeah, luck plays a big role, but the game's so good, so thematic, so FUN, it just doesn't matter.  Small World isn't the game you get hung up on trying to win, it's one you just enjoy playing.  A lot.

RATING: 7.5
BestWith:4>3>5,2. Use Larry Levy's Variant for 4 or 5 players: Choose races in reverse order starting with last player. (Player 5 can choose his beginning civ, using the normal rules, or he can pass. If he passes, Player 4 now has the option. This continues until one player chooses a civ, in which case Player 5 again has the option to choose or pass, or until Player 1 is reached, in which case he must choose a civ.) With this variant, the late players get the advantage of choosing their civs at the optimal moment, while the first players continue to get the advantage of placing first.

RATING: 7.1
[i]Gameplay depth[/i] [b]6[/b]
[i]Immersiveness[/i] [b]6.5[/b]
[i]Elegance[/i] [b]7.5[/b]
[i]Aesthetics[/i] [b]8[/b]

Small World is [i]okay[/i], though definitely much worse than it is generally made out to be. The concept of race and ability combinations is the main selling point of the game, and is expertly implemented through the buying mechanism. The rest is unfortunately a bit underwhelming. What initially seems like a somewhat deep and strategical game, soon turns out to be quite shallow. The combat mechanism is quite elegant and works somewhat well, but it is much too simple. After you are done being impressed by the races and how they funnily combine with the abilities, you are left with a decent but ultimately uninteresting game.

RATING: 8
Small World is very sensitive to the Magic Circle as defined in game design theory. A mismatch of skill and antagonism/pacifism can create an unpleasant game for all involved. When players are psychologically well matched, the game flows well and is quite enjoyable. I really enjoy this game with the "right" group. It feels like a root canal might when playing with players with different playing incentives. Specifically, one player can choose to target another player for some perceived insult early in the game. Both players are guaranteed to lose, but it makes the experience much less pleasant for all involved.

RATING: N/A
Highly addictive landgrab gameplay with strategic depth and, best of all, racial/super powers. Easy enough that newbies can win on their first game, but complex enough that practice will make a difference. Accessible and has the right amount of luck to keep the vets from sure victory and the newbies from certain defeat. My favorite part about it, tho, is the massive level of replayability due to the number of race/power combos. No game is ever the same, and that's the way it should be. 

Can be a little intimidating to new players at first due to the sheer amount of information to absorb, but the rules are essentially streamlined and when you've learned how to play as one race/power combo, you've learned how to play all of them. My only real complaint is the setup/pickup time required, but with the help of one or two other players that drudgery is hardly noticeable.

RATING: 7.5
[DOW 2009 edition] {Fantasy civilization; card-drafting, dice-rolling, area-control; scalable}  Small world is a very good game.  It's well themed, interactive, tactical and fun.  It has a good design.  There are no over-powered combos, races or special cards.  There are many decisions in a game - which races to pick, which areas to conquer, when to decline a race, etc.  Each decision counts but it's not agonizing.  It supports both tactical choices and strategic planning.  Players have good control on the outcome and situations; yet, they can also take risk to score more points by using the reinforcement roll.  It is very crucial to decline a race at the correct moment.  A turn is usually fast, not much AP problem.  It is easy to learn the rules, although it takes some time to understand each race and special power.  It is a suitable for both families and gamers.  Highly recommended.

Similar to other DOW games, the components are very nice.  The 4 different boards for each number of players are very nice.  The player aids are handy. The information on the cards and board is effective.  The token tray is good.  Some people do not like the artwork but I find it interesting.  In all, everything is well produced.  Thumb up!

RATING: N/A
Small World è un divertente, buffo e spensierato gioco di civilizzazione, nel quale 2-5 giocatori si affrontano per la conquista e il controllo su una mappa che è semplicemente troppo piccola perché tutti abbiano il loro spazio! Scegliendo la giusta combinazione tra le varie razze fantasy e poteri speciali unici, i giocatori devono espandere i loro imperi- spesso a scapito dei loro vicini più deboli. Tuttavia devono anche sapere quando abbandonare la loro civiltà, ormai giunta ai limiti della sua crescita, nel declino e portarne una nuova alla vittoria.

Elenco elementi di gioco:
2 Mappe, stampate su due tabelloni a doppia faccia
14 Razze Fantasy con i rispettivi vessilli e segnalini 20 cartellini Potere Speciale Unico
10 Tane dei Troll
6 Fortezze
9 Montagne
5 Accampamenti
2 Buche-nel-Terreno & 1 segnalino Turno di Gioco
2 Eroi & 1 segnalino Draghi
109 Monete Vittoria
6 fogli Prospetto di Gioco
1 Dado Speciale Rinforzi
1 libretto delle Regole

RATING: 5.5
I guess if you bid for turn order this game is OK, but it's clearly not balanced as a "random first player" game.  And yes, you can balance it in-game by hammering on the first player, but shouldn't there be a more elegant solution than that?

That aside, it's a cute game (much like its predecessor) but largely plays itself.  The optimal point-scoring moves on any given turn tend to be self-evident, and the game can easily come down to whether a player brings in a new race HERE or THERE.

So, fun, but hard to attach much meaning to the results unless you're willing to politic relentlessly to improve your position.  I'm too old for that.

RATING: 6
I received this game for my birthday back in May 2010 and we have yet to even punch out the pieces. However, I recently downloaded the iPad app and can confidently say that this is the best new board game I have played for quite some time. Gameplay is a satisfying mix of random and deterministic mechanics. The variations in racial powers and abilities make it highly unlikely that any 2 games will turn out the same, the placement and combat rules are satisfying and in my experience so far don't lead to too much downtime due to analysis paralysis. There's even a smidgen of dice rolling thrown in for some drama. Outstanding! 

As much as I like this game it doesn't hit the table because of long setup and play time. There are too many components and I much prefer to play on the iPad.

RATING: 7
The theme and hidden victory points were improvements to me over Vinci, and I have found the games generally tense and fun.

A few nits though - 

a) Takes too long to set up and pack up, some of the pieces are difficult to identify when in decline, and the tile holder that comes with the game is annoying (constantly getting a couple tiles stuck in it.)

b) The three player version does little to overcome the common problem with 3 player games - i.e., kingmaking by virtue of the first attack.

The races are interesting in their versatility and allow for some "surprise" moves and sneaky plays.  The decision of whether or not to decline is not always cut and dry, which is nice.  And the game plays rather quickly without unnecessary downtime (at least with up to 4... maybe not with 5).  Enjoyable, but we'll see if I'm still playing it in a year.

RATING: 5.75
Interesting game of back and forth, but it has no secret combat element which makes it fairly straight forward. Also, if you get a good race / ability combo you'll often never decline which makes the game really boring (Bivouacking Elves).

First game: I got Commando Dwarves and got a few points before being overrun by Mounted Ghouls and Swamp Halflings. Then I picked up the Bivouacking Elves and made a fortification along the bottom of the map, collecting between 8 and 10 points a turn. The combination of encampments and the fact I couldn't love units ment I had a high attrition value. The Stout Skeletons and Flying Amazons couldn't attack me without giving up land to each other. This ultimately let me just sit there and rack up an average of 9 points a turn by doing nothing. The game ended with me getting 85 points, second place had 84 points, and last place had like 75 points.

I wish there was an expansion that added a secret element, like hidden cards that you could play to help or hurt battles or break the rules unexpectantly. Would make the game more interesting.

Want to try again with 4 players and maybe open VP.

RATING: 8
Fun game of conquest.  I love the variety of races and powers, and gameplay is fast and dynamic.  I'm not convinced hidden VPs is such a good thing, however; I don't like the 'whine' element of the game.  Reference sheet has some flaws, and there are some confusing powers.

Hint for keeping track of who is in the lead: Keep a mental count; assign a player 1 point when they score 10 or more in one turn, -1 if they score 5 or less.  Count a 15 or more as 2. Then track the score by placing your VP tokens in piles. Gives you a rough estimate without needing to track exact values.

RATING: 8
Conquest game with several different interchangeable races and special powers, which provide the game with variety and longevity due to the ever changing combinations between the two. The key to success in Small World is knowing exactly how far to extend your race across the board and when to put them into decline (it's very tempting to keep a race going for just one more turn). Knowing which races work best with which special powers also proves to be advantageous, although some races/powers seem to be stronger than others no matter what they're paired with (I'm decidedly unimpressed by the dwarves for example). It's a game that doesn't take itself too seriously, which means there's a lot of fun to be had when playing and one game invariably leads to several others in a session.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Played it a tons of times online. The app is not the best, but the game provides quick fun - there is no setup time after all. My major issue with Small Worlds is that it is extremely luck dependent and there are some unbeatable combos, like the were-elves, while others can be pretty useless, like the imperial white ladies. Another issue with the game that it does not scale well - you need four to six players in order to make it possible to compensate for some of the luck-dependent unbalanced combinations mentioned before. After more than a hundred games I can still recommend the game, even though, I was not ever really enthusiastic about it.

RATING: 8
A mechanically great re-implementation of Vinci. Like any multiplayer combat game, Small World has kingmaking (lessened from Vinci by hidden VPs), meta-gaming, and headbutting, but it also has challenging and entertaining mechanics.

The graphic design is poor. Races cannot be distinguished quickly, especially in decline. Heraldry and national flags provide hundreds of years of examples of good practice in such design. Small World isn't the only game to botch this easily executed task, but it's one of the worst offenders.

The first two race/power expansions are good.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Two words "Risk Killer"  It solves many of the problems with Risk, feels like Risk, but has a better theme than Risk.  The exciting combinations of races and powers also add to this games replayability.  Seriously, this deserves to be on your shelf.

3/20/17 Update: I have bumped this from an 8 to a 9, I have had the game for quite a while now and still love it.  Our last play reminded me of just how good a game it is without as much worry/stress as a game like Risk.  As simple and fun as you can get while still preserving strong tactical elements.

RATING: 8
Loved it, was really easy to grasp the rules, played like the first few rounds of Risk before it starts sucking.  The whole verb/race system is brilliantly done, it adds unique combinations and insures each game/choice is a little different. Other then that, the art is great, the pieces are great, the theme is great.  The board that modifies itself based on how many players you have is also nice to see.  All round an enjoyable experience, something I'm absolutely buying the expansions for.

RATING: 9
I was very sceptical at first. It seemed like a poor copy of "Britannia" and "Barbarian, Kingdom & Empire" with a tacky fantasy theme.

Boy was I wrong!

This game is great! The tacky theme works perfectly with the variable special powers - it wouldn't have been credible without the theme. The game system is simplicity itself, the components are top notch, replayablilty seems virtually endless, it plays fast, it has special maps depending on the number of players...

My guess is this one will hit the highest grade in due time.

I'm trying to find something negative to say about it, but right now I'm drawing blank.

RATING: 7
Started with a few 2 player sessions, then a few 5's and a few in betweens. For a light-hearted, fairly quick-paced game, the 5-player sessions dragged. I think 3 or 4 player is the sweet spot. My son complains that 2-player is too predictable. Although accumulated wealth is kept somewhat secretive, it was fairly obvious by the middle rounds who had the best chance at victory and who had no chance. Board gets quite busy with tokens everywhere (it's a small world, after all!). Somewhat difficult to determine token ownership when races are put into decline due to relatively similar muted shades (although the small symbol on the back of each token is supposed to help). I like the game, though, and it works well when playing with a mix of kids and adults. I would say minimum age for the kids to understand and keep interest would be around 9-10 YO. YMMV.

RATING: 3
Is this suppose to be a Euro or a War Game? Really it's not much of either. It's also not much fun. 

The map is cluttered and lacks any distinctive features or need for tactical game play. 

Your army is constantly shrinking. The most armies you will ever have is on the first turn of a new race. 

Conquering new territories is extremley unsatisfying as it's pretty basic in the fact the larger number always wins. 
4 armies vs. 7 armies forget about it you have no chance .... the larger number always wins. 

It's unsatisfying as a Euro as you have very few meaningful decisions. 
You play like 9 rounds and the most important decision you will make is what race/ special ability you will select. 
You do that twice maybe three times a game. So you make at the most 3 big decisions. 

Don't get me started on all the bits and the stupid insert that holds them. It's a chore to take races in and out of the insert. ... 

Overall it's more like work (tedious and monotonus) that gaming (fun).


 
BE SUSPECT OF ANYONE WHO RECOMENDS THIS GAME!

I think it could be better though, if everybody knew the game, and if you play it with more people. But I'm afraid it will never get that far. explaining it to more than 1 person at a time seems daunting, and the one I already explained it to showed little intrest in playing it again someday. Seems like a pity though...

RATING: 5
I ran extremely hot and then rather cold on this game. For starters I really loved both the race combinations and the simplicity of the combat. Knowing that taking a territory was just # of items + 2 was super simple and easy. I also liked the different board sizes to balance player count. As I ran colder on it more aspects of the game struck me as unfun. For example, the idea of decline and picking a new race is cool in theory, but in practice it means that many turns your "action" was just flipping over a bunch of chits and picking out new ones, it was kinda a killjoy for a concept that the game was based around. Also the board got really hard to read for someone with bad eyesight when there were a bunch of in decline races on the board. It was very important to see them, but the "declined" colors were very faded. Also the ability to scoop up and redistribute as needed seemed to remove some of the tactical aspects to me.

RATING: 5.5
Fun, light, whimsical. Not sure it's worth owning. Honestly, I didn't think I'd like this game, due to the theme and it being so light for what is ostensibly a conquest/empire-building game. But, it's breeziness, quick playing time, and vast array of possible combinations and powers for the races made it much more enjoyable than I'd have thought.

The whole "is it a wargame" question comes up here, and I think those who said "hell no" have more of a point here than they often do in those types of arguments. It's more area control, sure, but at the highest possible level of abstraction and the highest level of simplicity, I still think a case could be made that this does qualify as a wargame, albeit one with a fantasy theme and one which is clearly aimed at non-wargamers, kids, and for introductory purposes for someone who has no concept at all of conflict over territory.

RATING: 7.25

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Unlike most games which go down hill for me after a few plays, Small World has been growing on me with each successive play. I started off not being particularly impressed, but then played it again and liked it a bit more, and then a little more after the third play, etc. Now I've played it 5 times and just purchased a copy. Strangely enough, it was the announcement of the fan-designed expansion contest that ultimately prompted me to buy the game. I found that the fan-designed expansion contest worked very well for the Mr. Jack Extension, so was hopeful that it would be just as successful for Small World. The greatest appeal of Small World comes with the many possible combinations of races and special powers, so the addition of even more races and special powers to increase the number of combinations significantly is a very welcome addition for me. I'm particularly happy with the fact that Days of Wonder included four different boards to accommodate two, three, four, and five players. Being someone who is picky about the number of players in a game, it's very nice for a publisher to acknowledge that different player counts require different boards, rather than just turning a blind eye to that reality and slapping as broad a player range on the box as remotely feasible. The heavily saturated colors of the board and units do make it somewhat difficult to step back and get an overview of the board position, but I enjoy the game as a light and fast romp, rather than a slow and tactical game, so this isn't much of a problem with the right opponents. Lastly, I'll say that the decision of when to send your civilizations into decline is wonderfully tense. I'm often so hesitant to pull the trigger on a decline or over eager to do so, and often regret my decision after the fact, but that just gives me more impetus to continue revisiting the game and tailoring my approach.

Purchased: September 24, 2009

RATING: 6
It wore out it's welcome fairly quickly.

I don't love Small World.  It's not that it's a [i]bad[/i] game; it's okay.  I do like seeing the race combinations and evaluating which combination works best... but the rest of the game bores me.  

You'd think there would be interesting decisions in this game, but invariably it seems that most of the decisions are fairly obvious, or when they're not obvious they're equivalent.  Usually there is a race that is better than the rest, a starting point that you should use, regions that make sense to attack, etc.  Even choosing when to go into decline tends to be obvious.  

There just isn't a lot going on here.  It's just attack, attack, attack, decline, repeat.  There's not a lot of room for doing anything new or different.  Every game I've played feels like every other game with a spritz of a different race for flavoring.  I'll still play it occasionally, especially as my son likes it, but it's not something I'd seek out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The different powers of each of the fantasy races are the best part about this game, as choosing which race you're going to play next is probably the most fun and interesting decision in the game.  Overall, it is an interesting experience but I don't quite understand the mass appeal.

RATING: 6
In Small World, players vie for conquest and control of a world that is simply too small to accommodate them all.
Designed by Philippe Keyaerts as a fantasy follow-up to his award-winning Vinci, Small World is inhabited by a zany cast of characters such as dwarves, wizards, amazons, giants, orcs, and even humans, who use their troops to occupy territory and conquer adjacent lands in order to push the other races off the face of the earth.
Picking the right combination from the 14 different fantasy races and 20 unique special powers, players rush to expand their empires - often at the expense of weaker neighbors. Yet they must also know when to push their own over-extended civilization into decline and ride a new one to victory!

RATING: 6
I like the fixed game length and different maps for different numbers of players, and don't mind the minor rules changes. HOWEVER. The graphics are terrible. The Vinci board is ugly but functional. The Small World boards are much uglier and also much less functional - there are spaces that appear to be multiple spaces, spaces that are hard to tell the type of, and the general appearance is extremely busy and makes it hard to read the board. The different counters for the races look nice in isolation but work very poorly with the boards, and are not a great idea from a functionality perspective - Vinci's disks in PLAYER colors work much better. Without these issues I might rate this as high as 8, and buy it, but as it is I'm rating it 6 and not buying it. (There are also an annoying number of ambiguities in the rules for the powers, but at least those can be fixed.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I was looking forward to playing this game ever since its release, and I am happy to say that it does not disappoint. The quality of its components is staggering, from the gorgeous artwork right down to the thickness of each counter. The counter tray seems to pack everything too tightly, but otherwise every component fits the box splendidly. Best thing about its execution though is that the game comes with two double printed board of different sizes: Each for a specific number of players. As a consequence, it plays very well even with two players. Gameplay wise, the large number of race/power combinations ensures replayability and the game's length is perfect for playing two games in a row. Never played Vinci, but I would love to play this game again.
UPDATE: Played it a bit more, and it is starting to lose its appeal. Somehow, my last game felt a bit cold and clinical. Also, the game is much better with four players than it is with two (despite the special two player board).
UPDATE2: Regained interest in playing this game with two, thanks to the excellent Tales & Legends expansion. Using this, as well as the Grand Dames and Cursed expansions, the game felt much more exciting to me. Also, the game is much better with three than it is with two.

RATING: 6
08/2010:7
Played this game twice with two players, once with each player controlling two factions.

I am mixed on this game. I love the concept of the game but not really the execution. First, I like the idea of a declining race and the constant switching between forces. I feel like the pace of the game play is fast and furious and a little light hearted (I mean who wouldn't like merchant trolls and diplomatic orcs?) I also enjoy the very colorful bits and great production values for the game.

However, I do not like the fiddliness of the game. There are lots of bits and they can be extremely confusing when it comes to getting victory points. I think this is most likely a common problem for other players as well.

With two players, this game DOES NOT shine. I feel like certain races are way too powerful and if you get them early, you can quickly gain a foot hold that is insurmountable. I have a feeling this game shines with 4-5 players.

That said, for some reason, I don't like the theme nearly as much. I bet I would love a more serious theme. I remember playing history of the world and I absolutely loved it.

I will give this game a little bit more time to develop and see if it has staying power.

052613: Does not do much for me. After a few more repeated plays, this game will be on the for sale or trade list shortly.

RATING: 7.5
This is a well designed game.  The base rules are consistent (ex. can't lose army on offense, defenders doesn't have to roll anything, how a starting army attacks, etc.) and intuitive (ex. each map area is distinct, how an army moves, etc.) requiring nothing more than basic math to resolve the size of attacking army required.  The specific rules for each of the badges/races overlay quite nicely over the base rules.

Two aspects that deserve HUGE praise is that there are different game boards for each of 2, 3, 4 and 5 players (with each being appropriately balanced with an even # of different regions).  I've never seen this done before ... obviously the designers REALLY care about game balance.  In addition the army tokens tray can be removed from the box itself (which is really handy).

The only thing preventing me from giving this game an even higher rating is my low amount of plays with only the 2 player option.

RATING: 4
I would rather listen to the Disney song for an hour straight than play this miserable excuse for a game again.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

After playing a game that took almost 2.5 hours, I probably won't play this ever again. Even when it only lasts 45 minutes, I still don't find Small World very enjoyable. Since the board is constantly changing, there is almost nothing to think about between turns, making downtime dreadful. The decisions are usually very easy to make. The main decision a player makes is when to go into decline, but this only happens 2-3 times per game. Additionally, many races are overpowered, giving some players a distinct advantage. I realize that there is more strategy than there seems, but I just don't find this fun. I would rather play most games over this.

RATING: 7
I like this game, but I feel like it doesn't work well at all for five players or possibly even four.  The downtime between turns is immense with that many players, which is a big problem.  Smallworld works best for me with two or (at most) three players.

That being said, it is really enjoyable.  It requires you to be incredibly flexible in your thinking and pretty solid at risk analysis.  There's very little hidden information in this game, which is a good thing, but the random combinations of powers and races adds a ton of variety.

I think my wife and I might start a one-on-one series for this game.  

Another point: the box insert for this game is a bit frustrating.  I might just pull the insert and put everything into baggies.

RATING: 6
Pros: area control game, fun theme, highly strategic with moderate level of tactical play, high variability

Cons: strategic imbalances, player interaction limited to conflict, can overstay its welcome; prone to kingmaking

I have no knowledge of its predecessor Vinci, so to me, this is simply a decent gateway area-control game with a fantasty theme. The elements of the rise and fall of civilizations in this microcosm is especially fun. Some balance issues with race powers knock it down a couple points for me, however. On top of that, the game discourages any sort of cooperation or alliances, so in my experience it is very difficult to convince others that a player with Pillaging Skeletons or something similar is a threat that necessitates working together against. Plus, the wife hates it.

RATING: 7
I feel like Catan is to Monopoly as Small World is to Risk. Just a better designed, more streamlined, funner version.

I love the race/power combos and how they interact with the board. It's really dynamic and I can't see any game playing out the same way twice. I love how you constantly have to think in both the long and short term: what to do with your active race, when to put them into decline, and what new race to choose. Random chance plays a role, but there's tons of strategy if you look for it. Even trying to figure out another player's agenda and not get in their way. Great fun!

The obvious downside here is the setup and cleanup, but I hesitate to harp on that too much as it's the best it can be, and it's not too bad given the game length.

RATING: 5
Oct 2017:  Rating -1

Good game, but not a favorite for us.  Definitely better with 3-4 players than it is with 2.  With 2 players it's better if we run through the turn limit twice, giving us more time to battle for control of the board.  Maybe a slightly heavier end gateway game, though it only works if players are able to understand and make use of their special abilities.  (Not every race should be played with the same tactics, meaning your own tactics will have to change as you progress through the game.)

Some race/powers are very OP, especially when combined.  Merchant Titans or Merchant Ratmen, for example, can give you a huge lead pretty quickly that is difficult for anyone else to catch up with.

RATING: N/A
Picking the right combination from the 14 different fantasy races and 20 unique special powers, players rush to expand their empires - often at the expense of weaker neighbors. On each turn, you either use the multiple tiles of your chosen race to occupy adjacent territories - possibly defeating weaker enemy races along the way, or you give up on your race letting it go "into decline". At the end of your turn, you score one point (coin) for each territory your races occupy.

2-5 (best 4)

Area control, variable player powers

RATING: 4
I wanted to try [gameid=60] for the longest time, and when this reinvention came out, I thought I was set. The production is up to  [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgamepublisher/1027]Days of Wonder's[/url] usual high standards, and there's high replayability here, with different race/trait combinations to keep things fresh.

The gameplay, though is disappointingly vapid. Rather than a truly dynamic experience, it devolves into a dull exercise in pulling down the (perceived) leader. It's also too short. Adding on turns won't solve this problem, as the game doesn't have enough meat to make a longer gameplay experience interesting.  Add in a luck factor and a problematic player-to-my-right importance with race availability, and the game is both unsatisfying and frustrating.

I've since played Vinci, and I realize now that this is a problem with the system, more than a problem with the game.  If you're looking for light dudes-on-a-map, go for [gameid=1159], [gameid=94246], or [gameid=15363] instead.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Satisfyingly well-designed game with deterministic combat- no unlucky dice rolls here!

A large part of winning is about identifying which of the available race/power combinations you want to play as, and how to best play them to exploit the edge you get. As such, inexperienced new players will usually get annihilated (although wealthy halflings won me my first ever game!).

It does have an "elect the leader" problem, where if everybody gangs up on one player, there is no comeback for them. But the crowds I've played with are normally pretty good at bashing the actual leader rather than just the player everybody assumes will win.

I have enjoyed every game I've played, winning or losing, and it's short enough that if you're losing you don't need to sit in misery for long and there are still interesting decisions to make in the meantime.

I've also seen a few impressive turnarounds where outgunned players have switched to a particularly good new tribe and come from behind to win.

RATING: N/A
In Small World, players vie for conquest and control of a world that is simply too small to accommodate them all.
\13\\13\
Designed by Philippe Keyaerts as a fantasy follow-up to his award-winning Vinci, Small World is inhabited by a zany cast of characters such as dwarves, wizards, amazons, giants, orcs and even humans; who use their troops to occupy territory and conquer adjacent lands in order to push the other races off the face of the earth.
\13\\13\
Picking the right combination from the 14 different fantasy races and 20 unique special powers, players rush to expand their empires - often at the expense of weaker neighbors. Yet they must also know when to push their own over-extended civilization into decline and ride a new one to victory!
\13\\13\
Note:Small World: Curseda expansion and Small World: Great Dames expansion are store in the base game box.

RATING: 6
I was looking forward to buying Small World after Days of Wonder started running their very successful teaser ad campaign for it. Fortunately, I managed to play someone else's copy before I did. It's not a terrible game, it's just far too simple. The random pairing of different racial bonuses and civilization traits for each session is a very cool mechanism, but the rest of the game lacks meaningful decisions. The lame invasion rules feel less like a fantasy war game and more like a Mancala variant.

I want to love it, but I just can't shake the feeling that it could have been so much more. Playing it is like going down to the local tavern and sitting in front of the Guinness tap and ordering a Bud Light.

NOTE: The digital version (Smallworld 2) improves things quite a bit. The game hasn't changed at all, but with the computer tracking scores, managing chits and making set-up and take down instantaneous my appreciation for it has grown. As a quick 15-20 minute game, the simplicity of the rules make a lot more sense. Sell your hard copies and get the app, you'll have much more fun.

RATING: 6
My description of Small World is always 'Risk but actually good'. Everything about Small World is fine and works well, but ultimately it's just not my thing.

I will add this, though - as charming as the racial and special abilities and their pairings are, if you see past all of that down to the pure math of what you can achieve in what time, you'll obliterate the competition still too caught up in role-playing their flying bears or whatever. Honestly, I don't often turn into a cold machine but it just isn't fair what I do to people in this game. I don't know that I should take the full blame for it, though - perhaps there isn't enough in the game to 1. obscure the math and/or 2. protect/defend against it. I dunno. The optimal action including going into decline and purchasing races at what price with what cash bonus seem to all be way too easy to extrapolate at each point of the game.

RATING: 6.5
Small World reminds me somewhat of Risk but redesigned in such a way that it plays in half the time, with less slavish dependance upon sheer luck with dice rolls, while seamlessly introducing unique player powers to create deeper interest. In short, I think Small World is a delightful game that has enough variety and strategy for gamers while being approachable and fun for non-gamers. It scales well from 2-5 players and the art and graphic design are wonderfully charming.

I think Small World is everything Risk wishes it could be but never knew was possible before now.

RATING: 7
Shorter and better than Risk.  Too bad the great American populace will never embrace Small World as the standard light wargame that sits on everyone's shelves.  Just a few too many special rules, I think - otherwise it could happen.

Other setbacks:

If you take the game seriously (which you shouldn't), turn order in the final round is problematic.  You've all heard the gripes, but just to restate: during the final round, players who go later in turn order are unable to impact the score of players who went earlier in turn order.  Once you score for the last time, after all, you're out of the game for good.

Then there are the inadequate/nonfunctional cheat sheets.  The point of a cheat sheet is not to have players constantly look in the real rules to track down the omitted (yet critical) exceptions or details that pertain to your chosen race or special power.

And don't get me started on the marathon-length FAQ.  The official rules clarifications (I lost count once they outnumbered my brain cells) should - of course - be integrated into an updated ruleset.  If this never happens, I call lame on Days of Wonder.

But even after all that, I like this game and would heartily recommend it to others.

RATING: 9
This game is what RISK would be if it was a Euro.

Great area control game that suits a nice range of players.  The core rules are relatively simple and straightforward (place 2 tokens plus one more for each extra thing on the space) so it's easy to teach, and it plays relatively quickly.   Almost all of the complexity comes in with the ability combinations, but for the most part those can be left unexplained until they actually come up.

The very minimal amount of luck involved in the game can occasionally lead to some AP issues, but it's generally not an issue.   With certain groups there can also be some tendency to "beat up on the leader", but having the victory points hidden helps reduce that somewhat.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I love the randomness, but this game does something that is always aggravating, it creates a possible hopeless situation for a player.

If you play a bad round, and only collect 6 or 7 gold, when another player collects 15 or more, the game is effectively over. If you can only collect 6 or 7 gold, then your race needs to go into decline, which means that next turn you're collecting that same 6 or 7, while the other player collects way more, effectively making almost certain that the rest of the game would be nearly pointless.

In a game of 4 or more, this can mean that you're waiting for 10-20 minutes each round before playing your 2 or 3-minute turn. And when you go into decline, that's effectively a pass, meaning you could be waiting 20-40 minutes before doing anything, which isn't a worry if you're not in a hopeless situation.

When this doesn't happen, and everyone has their strategy contend with others evenly, this is a fun game. But too often have I seen someone trudge through the 2-hour session in a 6-person game after hitting a moment like this in round 3.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
[CK]

How can you improve on Vinci? How about extracting the basic framework and then taking a page out of Strange Synergy by implementing randomly modular races and powers - neither of which are particularly balanced - and then compound matters even further by randomizing the order in which players obtain said combinations, ensuring that the first to choose receive the strongest pairs while later folks are simply in an inferior position, and might have to pay victory points or suffer an even worse fate? (In my first game I went first and took Seafaring Amazons at no cost, which progressed at 7,10,11 points per turn before the decline. Second player took Fortified Humans at no cost and scored just as many points if not a tad more. The other three players were not only forced to settle for inferior pairings - Bivouaking Sorcerers, Flying Elves, Berserking Orcs - but also had to pay an extra VP so as to skip the self-contradictory Hill Dwarves!) The worst part is that these "decisions" about race/power selection and their eventual rewards are incredibly easy to eyeball, so the game feels more like dull, limited optimization than a playground of options and possibilities. Of course, races and powers are hardly balanced; Giants and Tritons are strictly worse than Amazons unless you're planning on knocking over five coastal or down-the-mountain regions in one turn, Trolls WTF BROKEN WILL NEVER BE ATTACKED AFTER DECLINE. Powers are similarly busted - Fortified, Wealthy, Stout, Dragon Master are all exceptional, the others are at best situational and variants on the same "+1" mechanic. Naturally some races and powers can be incredible, but only at certain times or with certain combinations, further expanding the divide between how turn order and chaos ultimately decide the victor, with a little shaft-the-winner thrown in for good measure, because - y'know - that's preferable to actually starting players on an equal footing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
A very easy, quick, and fun 'wargames' to have that accessible to everyone. The replyability isn't endless, but It's definitely up there among others. There's just a lot of combination, that even when playing in the same map, I have never felt like I'm playing the same strategy over and over. The game also scale well so naturally it quickly become the most played game in my collection.

But it has its problem:

1) Sometimes your opponents get all the good combination and you're stuck with the bad ones with little room to affect things.

2) Setting up and cleaning up the game is a chore

3) Even with experienced players the game played a bit longer than it should for a light game.

RATING: 9
New review:

Well, after pretty much ignoring this game for ... a couple of years even, I decided to brake it out the other day with my partner and have done a complete one-eighty on this game!
Maybe it was the fact that I RE-learned the rules (which, I might have been less clear on the first few times) or it might be the fact that I've learned the nuance of how to actually gain the victory points that determine the outcome of the game.  
Once you understand that your race is dispensable, and that by the time your opponents have finished their turns, you may not have a race worthy of keeping, you can actually form somewhat of a longer term strategy - valuing not only the synergy of special power and race, but also active and in-decline races.
Also, understanding when to be passive verses aggressive [and to WHOM you should be aggressive] makes a HUGE difference.  Sometimes attacking your opponent will actually net you LESS victory points than simply expanding into unoccupied territory, or even simply passing up any movement whatsoever.  I missed this strategy completely when we first played Small World, opting instead to almost always go for the throat - and then ending all our games baffled as to why the victory points didn't match what we thought were our successes in combat.  
Now that I've figured this game out I have no doubt it will be one that is long lived in our gaming group.  Like Cosmic Encounter, I'm itching to play with different combos of race and power, and to pick up any and all expansions that facilitate those myriad of combos. 

Old review (I gave it a 6):

I think i'm missing something whenever i'm playing this game.  Mechanically it seems to work.  But the it's just not... not as fun as it should be.  
The area control and race selection mechanics are good.  In fact, I love the race selection.  It lends itself to interesting combinations of powers, similar in a way to those of Cosmic Encounter.  And you get to play as more than one (you put your race into "decline" and purchase a new one to champion).  
I think a key flaw in the game is that when you do give up on a race, you must essentially skip your turn.  and in a game with limited turns, that means you'll do very little for at least one or two rounds of a game.  
Also, there is the fact that the rules are somewhat vague for certain races/abilities.  The quick reference sheet isn't bad, but with so many races and abilities, you'll be looking at that sheet and clarifying rule vaguenesses for longer than you will be actually moving troops on the board.  
 Again, I feel like i'm missing something that I can't quite put my finger on.  The alternate/expansion, Underground, adds some "item" and "location" mechanics that make the area control a bit more focused - with out it, your movement choices often come down to "am i strong enough to screw over my opponent here? or am i better of not being combative and just pick up points in another empty place?"  The board is small and SHOULD make interaction and "screw you over" happen more often.  But I feel like you never get ahead when you "screw over" people, so why bother?  Atleast the items/locations in Underground make an enemy location more tempting.
I'm not sure what could fix this game, but it just isn't that fun.

RATING: 7
As with [thing=60]Vinci[/thing], there is a lot of downtime, especially with new players, but otherwise a game of subtle strategy and puzzle-solving, really.  Warring is represented, but less as conflict, and more as a predictable occurrence.  You can conquer all day long and not win.  The key is in maximizing your "income" with both your live civilization and your declining one.  The feel is almost identical to [thing=60]Vinci[/thing]; however, having different boards for the different numbers of players can only be an improvement.

The mix-and-match of peoples and powers provides some nice variability and replay value.  It also makes it very easy to expand, as [company=1027][/company] and numerous BGG users have deftly demonstrated.
[color=#ffffff]Small World 2[/color]

Great components, artwork, and theme. It's easy to grasp what you should be doing in the game, if a little harder how to do it as efficiently as possible. The powers and races are great and pretty much make the game.

Own most of the expansions (except that Realms modular stuff).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The different combinations of all the powers are really neat (and the art is very nicely done). Plays briskly. Really nice that there are separate boards for 2, 3, or 4 players. Dependent on judicious leader-hosing, but at least usually ends up with quite close scores.
